000.01.title: Métronome
000.01.keywords: contemporary, installation, figurative (body as site), photography
000.01.subject: vertical photograph depicting a digital output of a heartbeat superimposed over a scene of clouds.
000.01.description: installation: unframed photograph with two speakers and wires
000.01.references:
Steinman began her artistic practice using video, and extended her work to include elements of sculpture. Cenotaph was a pivtoal work in this sene, combining sculpture and video in a monument to victims of political oppression that acts particularly as a Holocaust memorial. Steinman often focuses on the dispossessed, immigrants, refugees, in her work.

“For Barbara Steinman, the incorporation of the sound of a human pulse in her installation adds an inter-sensory dimension that is mesmerizing. In Metronome, the sound of a manipulated, irregular heartbeat stands in for the material body. Shaped like a cruciform, the work instils a melancholy mood that speaks of life, loss and transformation. A vertically suspended photograph depicting a graph of a heartbeat superimposed on an image of clouds is placed in the centre. On either side are speakers from which the hypnotic sound emanates. The unbroken cadence and the evanescent quality of the clouds allude to the fleeting nature of mortality and the infinite, transcendent dimensions of life that take place in memory, through history and within the realm of the transformative unconscious. If the human voice is the “symbolic substance of human life,” then the hypnotic sound of a beating heart, subtly heard and placed out of body, suggests the essence of being: becoming and surviving. The work becomes a haunting metaphor for the constancy and inconstancy of life.” (Karen Antaki, “Edging the sublime,” Between Body and Soul, 1998: 7-8; footnote: See Michèle Thériault, Positionings = Transpositions: Mona Hatoum, Barbara Steinman. Art Gallery of Ontario, 1993, 11.)

Metronome  can be related to the earlier work, Icon, which combines two photos of a Mdaonna with two video screens, one showing an empty test tube, the other a test tube that repreatedly fills with blood as the video loops, while a voice from a speaker asks viewers to take a deep breath. The work involves issues surrounding health: not only physical health, but the health of our institutions and spirituality. Its references to body, blood, and spaces of spiritual contemplation are piccked up again in Metronome, where the heartbeat and red tubing is related to the cruciform and the photograph of endless blue sky.

“The sound of Metronome, an altered, irregular heartbeat, permeates the space (...) The sound of this abstract, cruciform-shaped piece links the many forms of martyrdom and life in the exhibition. Bloodlines are suggested by a tangle of red and purple-red wires that tumble to the floor and return to two speakers placed high on the wall. The iconic, heartbeat printout between them visualizes sonic waves. In its pulsating rhythm, allusions to mortality, and embodiment of the silenced Metronome  is reminiscent of Signs, the controversial installation work from 1992, which the artist made from flashing red ‘silence’ signs (...)”  (Reesa Greenberg, “Glass Echo” - see article or bibliography in file)

“We move (...) to inner self in a strange, heart-stopping installation by Barbara Stienman. This piece, titled Metronome, consists of a vertical graph, presumably the results of an electrocardiogram. Emitted from somewhere nearby is a percussion sound of a heartbeat, regular but somehow not especially reassuring.” (Henry Lehmann, “Gallery cashes in with bankès help” - see print-out in artist’s file)

000.02.title: Ring Bearer’s Pillow
000.02.subject: irridescent glass pillow with metallic gold fringes, placed on hive blanket, on queen excluder, on box
000.02.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l'artiste
000.02.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 2000
000.02.references:
See Between Body and Soul catalogue
see Mark, Lisa Gabrielle. Aganetha Dyck: Working in the Dark. Toronto:         DeLeon White Gallery, 2000.
See Ordinary Magic: Aspects of Ritual in Contemporary Art catalogue.


Part of The Extended Wedding Party  series, in which “bridesmaids. dresses, wedding gifts, shoes and accessories evoked a silent image of transmutation and decay.” (Karen Antaki, Between Body and Soul  catalogue)

Dyck places objects in beehives in order to allow comb to be built on them, referring to transformation and decay, to the labour and organization of the hive.

“The domestic creativity of the home and the nature of the community is parallelled in the hive, a world that exists parallel to our own. Since 1991, Dyck kas worked with beekeepers and their bees, the product of which is seen in the installation titled The Extended Wedding Party. In this work (...) is the experience of Aganetha Dyck’s vision - its accessibility, mystery, provocativeness, suggestiveness, but most of all, its magic.” (Shirley Madill, Winnipeg Art Gallery catalogue, p. 6)

“Dyck’s sense of beauty is intimately connected to a sense of the well-worn, the used, the secondhand, to objects that make up the fabric of daily existence.” (Madill, Winnipeg Art Gallery Catalogue, p. 8) The idea of the used or leftover object is pertinent to Dyck’s encapsulation of the wedding party objects, yet here she is working with objects that are only used once, as part of a precious ritual, and which become monumental because of this. 

Dyck says, “The ritual of the wedding and the cult of the bride are as fascinating as the reproductive rituals of the honeybees and their queen.” (Quoted in Madill)

“The remainder of the assembled props and accessories, despite their glittering sumptuous surfaces (areas are painted and layered with a gold metallic sheen), appear like leftover period costumes, screened and suspended within once functional Queen bee excluders which are now transformed into metal garment bags. Their grid structure and industrial material exaggerates the isolation, the insularity that surrounds the individual garments - empty talismans, remnants whose entombed presence exaggerates the peculiar and historicized weight of social convention circulating within their midst. There is a sense of loss, of time passed, of vulnerability, of decay buried within the luxurious folds and sensuous srfaces left behind. Bejewelled, regal, - suitable for a Royal wedding, or perhaps an attempt to legitimize the Queen bee’s insatiable appetitie, a ritual to sanctify her excessive procreation.” (Joan Borsa, essay in Winnipeg Art Gallery catalogue, p. 57) 

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

 Also part of The Extended Wedding Party series, Aganetha Dycks’ Ring Bearer’s Pillow shows another prop of the wedding party honey-combed and spray-painted, presented on a blanket that has also been subjected to the work of the bees. At once symbolic of both preservation and decay, the ring-bearer’s pillow is like an object abandoned, part of a series of things carefully made or chosen only to be used once in one of humanity’s most elaborate rituals.

000.04.title: Arlequin
000.04.subject: Harlequin
000.04.credit: Collection of the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery, Concordia University, Gift of the Max and Iris Stern Foundation / Collection de la Galerie Leonard et Bina Ellen, Université Concordia, don de la Fondation Max et Iris Stern
000.04.source: Gift of Dr. and Mrs. Max Stern / don de Dr et Mme Max Stern, 2000 (Fondation)
000.04.references:
written by Martine Fournier for the “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Paul-Émile Borduas earned his diploma from the Montreal École des Beaux-Arts in 1927. He is best known as the leader of the 1940’s group of Montreal Abstractionists, les Automatistes, who based their artistic practice on surrealism and the notion of allowing the subconscious to free itself through the act of painting. In 1948, Borduas he wrote a manifesto entitled Le Refus global. Largely a critique of the Church’s influence in Quebec, the Refus global was a call to arms to the people of Quebec, and to artists in particular, to break traditions and to live freely on their own terms. In 1953 Borduas moved to New York city because of the political repercussions of the manifesto, and spent the rest of his career there and in Paris. 
    Borduas’s early abstract painting was based chiefly on the idea of juxtaposing horizontal daubs of colour with a vertically painted background. After his move to New York, these little surface objects began to explode outward from the centre of the painting, instead of hovering statically on its surface. Still later in his career, he experimented with the contrast between large black forms and white ground. Harlequin was done shortly after Borduas first began experimenting with abstraction during the early forties, and is part of a 1942 series of gouaches in which he gives his imagination free rein while painting, raising symbols from his unconscious mind in a surrealist manner.

000.05.title: Landscape, Brittany
000.05.subject: landscape with trees
000.05.credit: Collection of the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery, Concordia University, Gift of the Max and Iris Stern Foundation / Collection de la Galerie Leonard et Bina Ellen, Université Concordia, don de la Fondation Max et Iris Stern
000.05.source: Gift of Dr. and Mrs. Max Stern / don de Dr et Mme Max Stern, 2000 (Foundation)
000.05.references:
written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Second-generation Impressionist painter James Wilson Morrice’s intimate subjects recall the works of Bonnard and Vuillard, but he traveled extensively and came under many different kinds of artistic influence. In 1890 he went to Holland, and from there to Paris to study at the Académie Julien. Not finding the Académie stimulating, he left to work under the Barbizon master Henri Harpignies, and was influenced by his decorative landscapes. Morrice’s early city scenes and seascapes, however, were inspired by the work of Whistler. From 1896-7 he was working in Venice with Maurice Cullen, and his style grew richer in colour and more energetic. While Morrice maintained ties with Canada and painted Canadian scenes such as sugar farms on visits home, his career was in Paris, where he achieved great success as both a landscape and figure painter. Between 1905 and 1910 he developed a distinctive style in which he used thin washes of paint, sometimes rubbing the pigment into his canvas with his hands, allowing the grain and whiteness of the canvas to show through. By 1910 he had also become aware of the work of Henri Matisse, and while maintaining his new thinness of colour application, began to organize his canvases into flat colour planes, emphasizing surface design. Landscape, Brittany exemplifies this new technique, with its thin application of paint and strong presence of white canvas which lends the landscape a light, airy feeling.

000.06.title: Nude
000.06.subject: a seated nude woman
000.06.credit: Collection of the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery, Concordia University, Gift of the Max and Iris Stern Foundation / Collection de la Galerie Leonard et Bina Ellen, Université Concordia, don de la Fondation Max et Iris Stern
000.06.source: Gift of Dr. and Mrs. Max Stern / don de Dr et Mme Max Stern, 2000 (Foundation)
000.06.references:
written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Goodridge Roberts entered the Montreal École des Beaux Arts in 1923, and from 1927-9 studied at the Art Students’ League in New York City, under Max Weber and John Sloan. Sloan, who was associated with the famous Ash Can School, had a great impact on Roberts, insofar as he was interested in the potential of the human figure to be used as a means of creating abstract formal order in painting. Throughout his career, Roberts would remain a figurative painter of landscapes, portraiture, and still life, but would use these subjects in an exploration of rhythmic shapes and colour planes. Settling in Montreal in the late 1930’s, Roberts steared clear of the Automatiste and Plasticiens movements of the 1940’s and 50’s. By the same token, he sought to depict landscape in his own straightforward manner, not romanticizing or heroicizing it as the Group of Seven chose to do. This study of a nude reflects Roberts’ ongoing interest in the human form, here portrayed using cross-hatch technique to bring out diagonals already in place, such as the slant of the sitter’s legs toward the bottom left-hand corner of the frame.

001.07.title: Untitled/sans titre
001.07.keywords: tapestry, Group-Painters Eleven, Canadian Group of Painters
001.07.subject: black abstracted figures dancing on a white background
001.07.credit: Gift of/don de Thomas O. Hecht, B.A. 1950
001.07.source: Gift of Thomas O. Hecht, B.A. 1950 / don de Thomas O. Hecht, B.A. 1950, 2001
001.07.references:
Untitled represents a major addition to the Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery’s permanent collection of Canadian Art.  Harold Town was a significant Canadian artist whose career spanned more than forty years.  Town’s accomplishments included founding membership in Painters Eleven, he represented Canada at the Venice Biennale in 1956 and 1964, participated in Documenta in 1964, and was given a major retrospective at the Art Gallery of Ontario in 1986.  In addition, his work has been collected by the Canada Council Art Bank, the National Gallery of Canada, The Solomon R. Guggenheim, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the Museum of Modern Art.  

Harold Town was one of the original members of the group that came to be known as Painters Eleven (1953 to 1960).  Town’s paintings during this period were abstract, much in the character of  American Abstract Expressionism - ranging from the earlier, gestural work to the broader, flatter work of the later 1950s.  Town was a ceaseless experimenter, and his work is perhaps best characterized by the series he did rather than a progressive exploration of any style, media or technique. During the 1970s one of his two main series were the Snap Paintings, in which he loaded string with paint, stretched it taut across the canvas and snapped it.  The technique produced a surface emphasizing both the pictorial plane and pictorial space through the optical mixing of colour.  The second major series was the Toy Horses which he began around 1976, and perpetuated his long time interest in collage.   

The tapestry acquired by the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery was part of a commissioned project, initiated by Fay Loeb of Toronto, who asked twenty-three artists to design a tapestry.  Each tapestry was issued in a series of twenty-five, and completed by craftspeople in Mexico.  The artists chose the colours from fabric samples and approved trial fabrications before the series went into production.  The method used is termed punch hooking, a hand process in which the yarn is punched through the canvas, hanging in loops on the back side.  After the hooking is completed the back is sprayed and brushed with latex to secure the yarn.  The tapestries were shown concurrently in five venues, (Vancouver, Calgary, Winnipeg, Toronto, and Charlottetown).
The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery has one other work by Harold Town in its permanent collection.  Top Banana (1956) is an example of Town’s autographic prints series, accomplished between 1952 and 1959.  The addition of Town’s untitled tapestry to the gallery collection serves to broaden the understanding of the artist’s overall production within the context of the collection and represents a significant addition to the University’s holdings of Canadian art.

001.08.title: Exile
001.08.subject: still life (fish, knife, lemon, on a table) in front of landscape
001.08.color: black, blue, green, white, orange, yellow
001.08.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l'artiste
001.08.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 2001
001.08.references:
Exile represents a major addition to the Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery’s permanent collection of Canadian art.  Tom Hopkins began to get major recognition in the mid 1980s when figurative work reemerged on the art scene.  Since that time he has continued to develop his interest in addressing the traditions of landscape and the figure in painting.  Over time Hopkins’ work has continued to evolve in terms of both quality of representation and paint handling. His paintings are typically large scale, textured oils which he renders in increasingly thick impasto and rich, sensual colours.  Exile comes out of Hopkins’ most recent series in which he continues to work out his longstanding concerns with the relationships between pictorial space and the tensions that are created within the canvas through its manipulation. 

Tom Hopkins has maintained a solid exhibition history, with solo shows across Canada in galleries such as Hart House and Mira Godard (Toronto), Paul Kuhn Gallery (Calgary), Equinox Gallery (Vancouver), Studio 21 Fine Arts and the Anna Leonowens Art Gallery (Halifax) and Galerie de Bellefeuille in Montréal.  Hopkins had a solo exhibition at the Concordia Art Gallery in 1987, and has participated in many group exhibitions nationally and internationally since 1979. Hopkins has completed three major commissions, and received “A” and “B” grants from the Canada Council, and the Ministère des affaires culturelles du Québec. His work is in the collection of various corporations, such as the Bank of Nova Scotia, Bell Canada, Esso Canada, Heenan Blaikie, Microsoft Corporation, Toronto Dominion Bank and Sun Life Canada, government agencies, such as Lotto-Québec, the Canada Council Art Bank and External Affairs, as well as numerous public art collections such as the Art Gallery of Windsor, Memorial University Art Gallery, Owens Art Gallery, Mount Allison University, and University of Toronto, Hart House.  In 1993 the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery also purchased one of Hopkins’ works on paper (Serajevo no. 4, 1993).    

Exile is a more typical example of Hopkins’ art than the other work in the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery collection (Sarajevo no 4), which is figurative but less complex pictorially.  This work enhances our collection of Canadian contemporary representational painting, and serves to further expand the conception of Hopkins’ oeuvre within the context of Canadian art, and represents a significant addition to the University’s holdings of Canadian art.

002.07.title: Série É, no. 7, Sex Machine
002.07.subject: abstract hard-edge shapes
002.07.color: green, pink, white, black, red, yellow, silver, gold, purple, blue, orange
002.07.credit: Gift of/don du Diane Pelletier and/et Michel Gauthier
002.07.source: Gift of Diane Pelletier and Michel Gauthier, 2002 / don de Diane Pelletier et Michel Gauthier, 2002
002.07.references:
Série É, no 7, Sex Machine represents a major addition to the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery’s permanent collection of Canadian Art.  Guy Montpetit emerged on the art scene in the 1960s and 1970s amid that period of Conceptualist art.   Belonging to the group of Canadian abstract hard-edge painters, Montpetit’s oeuvre is colourful, structured, and in keeping with conceptualism, explores the idea over the object.  These are large format paintings which pay homage to life and the machine.  Montpetit has consistently considered geometry, similar to historical figures such as Vitruve, Alberti and more recently Le Corbusier, all in search of an alternative to the assertion of aesthetic beauty.  Included among Montpetit’s contemporaries are Yves Gaucher, Guido Molinari, Françoise Sullivan, and Claude Tousignant.

Montpetit graduated from the École des Beaux-Arts in 1961, the Université de la Sorbonne, Paris in 1965, the Atelier 17 de S.W. Hayter and the Institut Nationale des Sourds in Paris.  Over the last thirty years, Montpetit has worn many hats, including professor, event organizer and social activist.  He has sat on numerous administrative boards and committees, and has been involved with bringing art to prison and school populations.  The recipient of many prestigious federal and provincial grants, most recently Montpetit has been involved with projects integrating art and architecture.  Montpetit’s work has been exhibited in solo and group exhibitions at the Musée des beaux-arts de Montréal and the Musée du Québec and the Musée d’art contemporain de Montréal.   His work has been collected by major museums in Canada, including the Musée des beaux-arts de Montréal, Musée du Québec, Musée d’art contemporain de Montréal, the Art Gallery of Ontario and is represented in many international, corporate and private collections.

The large acrylic on canvas acquired by the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery is from a series of sixteen works produced between 1969 and 1970.  Montpetit’s conceptual paintings of this period are concerned with the playful multiplication of aesthetic concerns, as if these were similar to the technical multiplications of the robot world.  The title of the series, along with the combination of colour and mechanical parts indicates another multiplication of meaning: one of sensuality and sexuality, no doubt a reference to Duchamp’s The Large Glass.

The Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery has no other work by Montpetit in its permanent collection, thus Série É, no 7, Sex Machine serves to augment our representation of significant Quebecois artists.  This work not only enhances our collection of Canadian contemporary painting, it serves to introduce Montpetit’s oeuvre within the context of Canadian art, and represents an important addition to the University’s holding of Canadian art.

002.10.title: Kirkman
002.10.subject: portrait of a man with glasses
002.10.credit: Gift of/don de Roy Lacaud Heenan
002.10.source: Gift of Roy Lacaud Heenan / don de Roy Lacaud Heenan, 2002
002.10.references:
Tony Scherman is a significant Canadian artist who has established an international reputation.  Born in Toronto in 1950, Scherman was trained in London, England.  He has been exhibiting his work nationally and internationally since 1976 in the UK, Germany, Sweden, the Netherlands, the United States, and Canada.  His work is represented in several public, private and corporate collections throughout Canada, the USA and Europe, including The Canada Council Art Bank, The Art Gallery of Ontario, the McMichael Collection, Art Gallery of Winnipeg, Montréal Museum of Fine Arts, Musée d’art contemporaine, and in the Los Angeles County Museum, The Denver Museum of Art, the Library of Congress in Washington, DC, The Arts Council of Great Britain, Contemporary Arts Society of London, and the Fondation Guerlain in France.

Portrait Kirkman, is an example of Scherman’s ongoing exploration of historical figures.  His technical proficiency in regard to encaustic is commonly acknowledged and his work is compelling both formally and conceptually.  For several years he has been investigating historical, literary and mythological figures in series of pseudo portraits, often approaching the subject with a cinematographer’s sensibility as he dwells on details and close-ups of the figure, creating emotional resonance through the sensuous, luminous surfaces he builds.    

This painting has been accepted into the Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery collection, joining a series of works (encaustic sketches from the French Revolution series) donated by the artist in 1996.  It represents an important addition to the collection, as it pre-dates the latter work and signals the direction in which his oeuvre was moving.

002.11.title: Sprinkler in the Rain
002.11.subject: sprinkler on lawn in rain
002.11.credit: Gift of/don de Roy Lacaud Heenan
002.11.source: Gift of Roy Lacaud Heenan / don de Roy Lacaud Heenan, 2002
002.11.references:
Sprinkler in the Rain represents a major addition to the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery’s permanent collection of Canadian Art.  Mary Pratt began to get recognition in the early 1970s, when she produced dozens of works representing the many aspects of everyday existence.  Pratt makes extraordinary the “vicious reality” of keeping house.  In critical discourse, Pratt’s paintings have been examined within the larger context of their relationship to photography, to religious imagery, to advertising and to femininity.  Historically, Pratt follows a long line of women artists painting the genre of domestic interiors including Mary Cassatt, Berthe Morisot, Judith Leyster, Clara Peters, and her contemporary, Audrey Flack.  Pratt’s use of photography has been examined in comparison to American Photo-Realists Richard Estes and Chuck Close.  

Pratt graduated from Mount Allison in 1961 and her first solo exhibition was in 1967.  By 1971, Pratt was exhibiting her landscapes and domestic interiors regularly in New Brunswick and Toronto.   As one of seven artists chosen from across Canada, curator Mayo Graham invited Pratt to participate in the 1975 exhibition Some Canadian Women Artists at the National Gallery of Canada.  Pratt arrived on the art scene at just the right time to be taken up by the women’s movement.  Her emergence in the 1970s coincided with feminism and realism, and accordingly she received enough media attention to make her familiar.  Pratt’s work has been collected by numerous major museums in Canada, including the National Gallery of Canada and The Art Gallery of Ontario,  and is represented in many international, corporate and private collections.

The mixed media on paper acquired by the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery is representative of Pratt’s production from the 1980s when her career was accelerating and she established an increased presence in Canadian art.  During this period she was exploring the female nude and the still life, but also reinterpreting old themes, including domestic aggression.  In 1988, twenty years into her career, Pratt’s work traces the changes in her life through both direct and indirect references to her past.  

The Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery has no other work by Pratt in its permanent collection, thus it is important to represent this significant Canadian artist.  This work not only enhances our collection of Canadian contemporary representational painting, it serves to introduce Pratt’s oeuvre within the context of Canadian art, and represents a significant addition to the University’s holding of Canadian art.

002.12.title: Profile
002.12.subject: profile of a woman from chest up
002.12.credit: Gift of/don de Roy Lacaud Heenan
002.12.source: Gift of Mr. Roy Lacaud Heenan / don de M. Roy Lacaud Heenan
002.12.references:
Profile represents a major addition to the Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery’s permanent collection of Canadian Art.  Michael Snow is a prolific Canadian artist, filmmaker, and musician whose career has spanned more than forty years.  He graduated from the Ontario College of Art in 1952 and his first solo show was held at Hart House (University of Toronto) in 1956.  Between 1962 and 1972, Snow lived in New York City, returning to Toronto in 1972.  He has been featured in solo exhibitions at museums throughout Canada including the Vancouver Art Gallery, The Art Gallery of Ontario, Powerplant, The Agnes Etherington Art Gallery and the Musée d’art contemporain in Montreal.  He was also represented in Expo ‘67 in Montréal, the 25th Venice Biennale in 1970, and has had two solo exhibitions at the Georges Pompidou Centre in Paris (1978, 2000), as well as many other international exhibitions.  Snow’s work has been collected by major museum in Canada, and is represented in many International, corporate, and private collections.

Michael Snow is perhaps best known for his Walking Women series, dating from the 1960s, and as an experimental filmmaker, but his visual art production has encompassed many media.    His visual art includes figurative work (of which the object under review is an early example), a foray into abstract painting, photography, holography, film, music, printmaking, sculpture and installation.  His ongoing concern in art making is often cited as exploration of the nature of visual perception and meaning. Snow’s work during the period in which Profile was produced, was influenced by early Modernist artists such as Matisse, and Abstract Expressionists such as de Kooning and Gorky.  During the 1950s, Snow was doing figurative work and this piece may be viewed as a precursor to the Walking Women series which he started with his collage work of 1962.

The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery has two other works by Michael Snow, Rolled Woman II (1961) and an untitled photo-silkscreen (1974), a sequential image of a chair in distortion.  The proposed work, Profile, represents Snow’s early career and points toward the motif utilized in his later explorations.  It relates directly to Rolled Woman II, already in our collection, and serves to broaden the understanding of the artist’s overall production within the context of the collection and represents a significant addition to the University’s holdings of Canadian art.

002.13.title: Diego Chairs #1
002.13.subject: Interior - boy standing on carpet, leaning against table; five chairs
002.13.credit: Gift of/don de Roy Lacaud Heenan
002.13.source: Gift of Roy Lacaud Heenan / don de Roy Lacaud Heenan, 2002
002.13.references:
Painter and experimental filmmaker, Jack Chambers, was born in London, Ontario in 1931.  He took his art training at the San Fernando Academia de Bellas Artes in Madrid, graduating in 1959, and remained in Europe until 1961 at which time he returned to London.  He had his first solo exhibition in Madrid in 1960, and during his lifetime he built up a strong exhibition history, showing in Montréal at the Musée des beaux arts, the National Gallery of Canada, the Art Gallery of Toronto, the Winnipeg Art Gallery, and several exhibitions in New York.  His work was also presented at the Canadian Pavillion at Expo ‘67, and he was represented by the Isaacs Gallery in Toronto.  In 1967 he co-founded Canadian Artists Representation with Tony Urquhart and Kim Ondaatje, and in 1968 he founded the London Fimmakers Co-op.

During the mid 1960s Chambers ventured into experimental filmmaking, a journey which would affect his painting by taking him away from his former concerns of revealing experience and memory through representation, to concerns with the perceptual experience of time, light and space as “a different realism”.  His abiding subjects were family, home, the city of London and its surrounding landscape.  The work acquired by the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery, Diego Chairs, #1, exemplifies this interest and is part of a series of works he completed with his son Diego as subject (i.e Diego Night, No.1 through 5 , 1969-70, and Diego Sleeping, 1972).

This work is the first piece by Jack Chambers added to the permanent collection of the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery, and marks the representation of a significant Canadian artist.  This work greatly enhances our collection of Canadian art, and adds depth to the notions of regionalism and nationalism in art.

002.16.title: Les Soudeurs
002.16.keywords: Group-Contemporary Arts Society, Canadian Group of Painters, Figurative
002.16.subject: two men and machinery
002.16.credit: Gift of/don de Freda and/et Irwin Browns
002.16.source: Gift of Freda and Irwin Browns / don de Freda et Irwin Browns, 2002
002.16.references:
Les Soudeurs represents a major addition to the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery’s permanent collection of Canadian Art.  Louis Muhlstock was an essential figure in the Quebec art scene, whose significant contribution in the field of modern painting and drawing since the 1930s, focussed primarily on his compassion for the dispossessed.  Frequently captivated by the simple and the quotidien, Muhlstock was always attentive to the human condition, but also towards animals and the natural world.  Themes in Muhlstock’s work include urban scenes, including the homeless, the unemployed, the aged and visible minorities.  However, parallel to these socially conscious subjects, he was also devoted to the female nude, which he painted with sensitivity for over thirty years.   

Muhlstock was born in Narajow, Poland and immigrated to Montreal in 1911.  Between 1918 and 1928, he studied with Edmond Dyonnet and Joseph Saint-Charles at the Conseil des arts et manufactures, The Art Association of Montreal and the École des beaux-arts de Montréal.  In 1928 he studied with Louis-François Biloul in France.  Returning to Montreal in 1931, he exhibited regularly in the Salon du printemps of The Art Association of Montreal from 1925 to 1960, as well as the Royal Canadian Academy of Arts from 1925 to 1950.  His work has been collected by major museums in Québec and Canada, and is represented in many international, corporate and private collections. 

This charcoal and pastel on paper acquired by the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery is from a body of work the artist completed during the Second World War.  In 1943, Muhlstock regularly visited armament factories documenting the workers, riveters and welders.  This drawing, Les Soudeurs (The Welders) is a typical example from this period.  The Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery has six other works by Muhlstock in its permanent collection.  Three early works, one nude and two portraits are examples of his paintings of women: Portrait of a Woman (c.1930), Portrait of Rachel (1931), Portrait of Molly (c. 1932).  De Bullion Landscape (1947), and Autumn (Isola) Val David, Laurentians (1975) are landscapes and together with Begonias (1948) these are representative of Muhlstock’s themes of the simple and daily, around Montreal.  Thus Les Soudeurs is an example of the artist’s social-minded work, and its addition to the permanent collection fills a missing gap and serves to broaden the understanding of the artist’s oeuvre within the context of the collection and represents a significant addition to the University’s holding of Canadian art.

002.17.title: Wooden Angel
002.17.subject: statue of female angel; small man holding trumpet in lower right corner
002.17.color: blue, green, grey, white, yellow, beige
002.17.source: Gift of Audrey McLaren, 2002 / don de Audrey McLaren, 2002
002.17.references:
Alma Duncan was born in 1917 in Paris, Ontario.  She studied under Ernst Neumann, and Goodrich Roberts (1940-43) in Montréal.  In 1943 Duncan was given permission to document Canadian war industries and the Canadian Women’s Army Corp.  From 1936 to 1943 she worked for a Montréal advertising firm, and from 1943 at the NFB in Ottawa where she met photographer Audrey McLaren.  Together Duncan and McLaren produced animated films under the name of Dunclaren Productions.  Duncan participated in numerous Canadian and international exhibitions, including the RCA, the National Gallery of Canada, the Robert McLaughlin Gallery, the Winnipeg Art Gallery and the London Regional Art Gallery.  Her work is in the collections of the National gallery of Canada, the Canadian War Museum, the Canada Council Art Bank, the Art Gallery of Ontario, Il Museo Caccio, Lugano, and the Brooklyn Museum, as well as various municipal, university and private collections.  Duncan was also a participant in the 1941 Conference of Canadian Artists in Kingston, Ontario.

Duncan is best known for her World War II drawings of industrial workers, an exhibition of which was organized by Joan Murray at the McLaughlin Art Gallery in 1987.  Her oeuvre also consists of landscape paintings and portraiture, as well as a large proportion of figure studies, primarily of women.  Her training under Ernst Neumann had a significant influence on her early work, particularly detectable in her landscapes.  Duncan is associated with eastern Canadian figure painters of the period between c 1935 and 1955, such as Lilias Torrance Newton, Philip Surrey and Ernst Neumann.

The Wooden Angel (1947 - 52) recently donated to the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery, is not typical of Duncan’s work.  Created for a large religious conference held in 1947, it is a departure for this artist in both its experimental style and in its subject matter.  The piece was recommended to the Ellen Art Gallery for acquisition by Art Historian, Dr. Brian Foss and by NGC Curator of Canadian Art, Charles Hill.  Although the work is a departure from Duncan’s more usual academic style of painting, it is deemed to be of significance and represents an important addition to the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery permanent collection.

002.18.title: Artist as Combustible
002.18.subject: woman standing in centre of composition, fire coming from her head
002.18.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
002.18.source: Purchase - Special Purchase Assistance Grant, Canada Council for the Arts / achat - Subvention spéciale d'aide aux acquisitions, Conseil des Arts du Canada, 2002

002.19.01-03.title: Trinité
002.19.01-03.subject: various organic and quasi-geometric shapes burnt into plywood surface
002.19.01-03.source: Gift of Mireille Lehoux, 2002 / don de Mireille Lehoux, 2002
002.19.01-03.references:
Marc Garneau has been an important participant in the Québec and Canadian art scene for over two decades.  He obtained his M.F.A. at Concordia University in 1984, and has since had over 30 solo exhibitions in Canada and Europe.  His work is represented in numerous museum collections, including the Musée du Québec, the Musée d’art contemporain de Montréal, the Winnipeg Art Gallery, the Canada Council Art Bank, and has eight other works in the permanent collection of the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery.

Marc Garneau has been working with wood as a media for over a decade, moving from the earlier “recycled panels” to his more current incorporation of the panel’s surface into the composition.  Garneau has consistently taken an organic approach to the creation of his work - an approach which curator, Laurier Lacroix believes to come out of the automatiste tradition, in which the artist reveals the traces of his process.  Around 1995 the artist began to use fire as an element in the production of his work, scorching the surfaces of the his panels, and further marking it with gouges and incisions.  Although the work is abstract, it references landscape and creates, between its various elements, an internal narrative.  Yet the work remains coherent, compositionally unified.  Garneau retains certain modernist concerns in his artwork, such as his concern with the material nature of the artwork, its flatness, and its insistence on the art object as an object.  At the same moment, however, abstraction 
in Garneau’s work leans toward representation and through the use of shaped canvases and altered and collaged surfaces he metaphorically turns his back to the modernist insistence on purity of form. 

The work donated to the Ellen Art Gallery is from the series begun in the mid-1990s.  It is a triptych in the form of three conjoined crosses, and features the scorched, marked surfaces typical of this period.  Garneau is an important contemporary artist with a serious and consistently engaged art practice.  This triptych is an important example of his production in this medium and represents a valuable addition to the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery’s holdings of Canadian art.  The painting is in excellent condition.

002.20.title: Little Air
002.20.subject: abstraction, vertical rectangle in upper centre of composition with marks of many colours; yellow background with band of orange along bottom.
002.20.color: yellow, orange, green, blue, grey, pink, white, sienna
002.20.credit: Gift of/don de Elaine and/et Mel Hershenfield
002.20.source: Gift of Mel Hershenfield, 2002 / don de Mel Hershenfield, 2002
002.20.references:
David Bolduc was a significant figure in second generation Canadian abstract painting.  Born in Toronto in 1945, he attended the Ontario College of Art (1962-63) and studied in Montréal at the Montréal Museum of Fine Arts School (1964-65) with Jean Goguen and Arthur Lismer.  He has exhibited extensively since 1966 in exhibitions throughout the country, including solo shows at the Marlborough Goddard Gallery, Montréal, the Owens Art Gallery, Sackville, the MacKenzie Gallery, Regina, Southern Alberta Art Gallery, Lethbridge, Klondaris Inc. and Mira Goddard Gallery in Toronto.  In addition his work has had solo shows at galleries in Washington and Houston, Texas, and has participated in numerous group exhibitions internationally.  His work resides in many public, private and corporate collections, such as the Agnes Etherington Art Gallery, Kingston, the Beaverbrook Art Gallery, Fredericton, the Edmonton Art Gallery, Hart House (University of Toronto), the National Gallery of Canada, the Art Gallery of Ontario, and the Art Gallery of Windsor.

Little Air, is an example of Bolduc’s production from the late 1970s.  Bolduc’s work is typically painterly in its handling, and throughout his career Bolduc has remained faithful to his early interest in abstraction, continually exploring its formal possibilities.  Around 1974 Bolduc’s interest changed from field painting inspired by his contemporaries in the U.S., and he began to investigate the tensions created when a single figure was placed on an abstract field.  In her 1979 catalogue essay, Sandra Paikowsky stated, “Since 1974, Bolduc has focused his attention on the central image.  Regardless of its shape or size, it is often the cause and solution of the painting... In contrast to his previous paintings, the new work has verticality, gravity and tension by virtue of the introduction of a focal point”.

Little Air (1978) has been accepted into the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery permanent collection, representing the fifth work by David Bolduc in this collection.  The other works in the collection, untitled (lithograph, 1969), Sugar (1972), Wo (1976), and March Slide (1980) represent a progression in the artist’s oeuvre.  David Bolduc is an important figure in the history of Canadian abstract painting, who has consistently pursued this interest throughout his career.  This painting is an important example of his production in this medium and represents a valuable addition to the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery’s holdings of Canadian art.

002.21.title: Spatial Concerns
002.21.subject: abstraction of flat colour rectangles superimposed on one another
002.21.credit: Gift of/don de Elaine and/et Mel Hershenfield
002.21.source: Gift of Mel Hershenfield, 2002 / don de Mel Hershenfield, 2002
002.21.references:
Spatial Concerns represents a major addition to the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery’s permanent collection of Canadian art.  Born in the United States, Russell T. Gordon has lived in Montreal since 1974, where he taught in Concordia University’s Painting and Drawing Department from his arrival in 1974 until his retirement in 1997.  

Gordon graduated from Temple University, Tyler School, and received a Master of Science and a M.F.A. from The University of Wisconsin.  He has been the recipient of many prestigious federal and private grants and in addition to his professorhip at Concordia University, Gordon has been artist-in-residence at several workshops, proving a continued commitment to art education.  Gordon’s work has been exhibited in numerous solo and group exhibitions in Canada, the United States as well as internationally and his work has been collected by major museums in the United States, the Musée d’art Contemporain de Montréal, and the British Museum in London as well as numerous international, corporate and private collections.  

Gordon’s early work was figurative; everyday objects from his environment painted in his unique brand of surrealist pop.   Abstraction has characterised Gordon’s work since the 1970s, when the subject matter of his painting became art itself: Jackson Pollock’s drips and splatters, Jim Dine’s scribbled line, Frank Stella’s pinstripes and Roy Lichtenstein’s brushstrokes were featued in Gordon’s work, as if they were pages torn from an art magazine.  Spatial Concerns is from this late-1970s body of work, refrencings other artists’ paintings.  As Sylvia Brown notes, “the conflicitng demands of illusionistic space and the two-dimensional surface produce visual tension.  The highly realistic torn edges, often reinforced with [...] shadows, depict layers of planes receding in space [...] at the same time, the scribbles, splattes dots and drips [...] re-establish the physicality of paint on canvas[...]”.  More recently, the artist has been exploring his fascination with music, in particular jazz, which has informed his painting practice for the last decade.  Gordon states that “juxtaposition, ambiguity, and physicality are some of the very important elements in my work and my intention is to fuse these elements into something new.”  Included among Gordon’s comtemporaries are Leopold Plotek, Guido Molinari, John Heward and Yves Gaucher.   
 
The large acrylic on canvas acquired by the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery is typical of Gordon’s production.  The Gallery owns one other work by Gordon, Tall, Tan, Talisman (1984) a mixed media work on paper, thus, Spatial Concerns serves to augment our representation of a significant Québec artist.  This painting not only enhances our collection of Canadian contemporary painting, it serves to broaden the understanding of the artist’s overall production within the context of the collection and represents a significant addition ot the University’s holding of Canadian art.

002.22.title: Early Spring in the Laurentians
002.22.keywords: Group-Contemporary Arts Society, Canadian Group of Painters, landscape
002.22.subject: landscape with hills; trees in foreground
002.22.credit: From collection of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey Evans/De la collection du Dr et Mme Harvey Evans
002.22.source: Gift of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey A. Evans / don de Dr et Mme Harvey A. Evans, 2002
002.22.references:
Early Spring in the Laurentians represents a major addition to the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery’s permanent collection of Canadian Art.  Jacques De Tonnancour was a critic whose interest in art led him to become a student of Goodridge Roberts.  He began his career as a figurative painter, heavily influenced by Roberts’ landscape style, but moved into abstraction by the 1960s.  De Tonnancour’s mature work from the 1950s, for which he is best known, features sensitive landscapes and imaginative reflections on the Laurentian countryside.     

De Tonnancour studied at the École des Beaux-Arts in Montreal from 1937-1939 and was influenced by the work of Henri Matisse and Pablo Picasso.  Awarded a Brazillian Government Scholarship, he worked in Rio de Janeiro in 1945-46, and upon his return to Montreal, became a member of Prisme d’Yeux, a short-lived group of artists, including Roberts, Albert Dumouchel and Alfred Pellan.   De Tonnancour co-authored an anti-Automatiste manifesto with Pellan during this period.  In the 1960’s he taught at the École des Beaux-Arts in Montreal and through both his practice and teaching, he consistently promoted Québec painting.   The recipient of many prestigious federal and provincial grants, his work has been exhibited in many solo and group exhibitions since the 1940’s including shows at the Musée des Beaux-Arts de Montréal (1947 49), Musée d’art Contemporain (1966), Vancouver Art Gallery (1966), as well as internationally in the United States, Brussels, and Venice.  His work has been collected by major museums in Canada, including the National Gallery of Canada, Musée d’art Contemporain, Canada Council Art Bank, Musée des Beaux-Arts de Montréal, Musée du Québec and the Elliot Trudeau Collection.  He is also represented in many international, corporate and private collections.    

The painting acquired by the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery is from a series of landscapes De Tonnancour painted in the 1950s.  In his book Four Decades, the Canadian Group of Painters and their Contemporaries, 1930 - 1970, Paul Duval writes “De Tonnancour’s restless intellect has taken him through several contrasting styles, ranging from descriptive landscape to pure abstraction.  In the mid-1950’s, he returned to a series of straight landscapes of the Laurentians and Georgian Bay...”   This painting, Early Spring in the Laurentians (1956) is a typical example from this landscape series.

The Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery has three other works by De Tonnancour in its permanent collection.  Nude (1944) pencil on paper, and Jeune femme assise (1947) oil on canvas, are examples of  De Tonnancour’s early work.   These are studies of women, whose form is reduced to simple geometric shapes and planes, exemplifying the influence of Matisse and Picasso.  The third work in our collection is an oil on masonite and collage, Cruciforme (c. 1963).  This work represents the mid career abstractions.  The addition of De Tonnancour’s Early Spring in the Laurentians (1956) to the gallery collection represents an example of the artist’s mature work from his period of highest recognition, thus, it fills a missing gap and serves to broaden the understanding of the artist’s oeuvre within the context of the collection and represents a significant addition to the University’s holding of Canadian art.

963.04.credit: Gift of the Samuel H. Schecter Foundation/don de la Fondation Samuel H. Schecter
963.04.source: Gift of the Samuel H. Schecter Foundation / don de la Fondation Samuel H. Schecter, 1963
963.04.references: Born in Montreal in 1925, Robert Roussil has lived in France since 1964. He studied in the sculpture section of the Art Association of Montreal under Arthur Lismer, a member of the Group of Seven, and was subsequently hired on as a teacher. In 1949, following complaints about its obscene nature, his sculpture La Famille was imprisoned, along with Roussil himself. Subsequently, he was fired from his position as a teacher at the Art Association of Montreal, one year after Borduas was fired from the Ecole des beaux-arts for the publication of his Refus Global. 1948-52 marks his period as a "plasticien." In 1956, he received third prize at the Concours artistique de la province du Quebec. In 1951, a vandal broke a Roussil sculpture on exhibit at the Galerie Agnes Lefort. Exhibited at the Musee Picasso, Antibes (1956); Galerie Creuze, Paris (1957); Pavillon francais de l'Expo internationale de Bruxelles (1958); Symposium internationale de la sculpture, Yougoslavie (1963); Symposium de Montreal (1964); retrospective at the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal, "Twenty Years of Roussil" (1965-66). In the permanent collection catalogue of the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal, Pierre Granche writes "Figure energique dont l'oeuvre a tres tot suscite la controverse, Robert Roussil occupe un place de premier plan dans l'histoire de la sculpture quebecoise. Ses premieres oeuvres en bois (materiau priviligie par Roussil, qui a egalement travaille la pierre, le bronze et la ceramique), notamment La Famille et L'Envol, toutes deux de 1949, presentent deja certaines des traits qui feront la force et l'originalite de sa demarche : formes organiques (predilection pour la courbe) rappelent la figure humaine ou animale, thematique associes au cycles et mouvements de la vie, creation de formes en rapport etroit avec le materiau." For further, more extensive readings please refer to the artist's file, which contains the catalogue to the 1965-6 retrospective at the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal, and a catalogue from 1977.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

While strongly influenced by Borduas, Riopelle, and other Automatiste painters, Jean McEwen developed his own style of abstraction, using the relationship between fields of colour to create a sense of life, often painting with his fingers. During the early 1950’s McEwen met Mark Rothko and Clifford Still in Paris, and the early influence of of Borduas’s group gave way to theirs. He began to paint with luminosity and sensuousness, using oil and watercolour to explore light, colour, and fluidity of surface. He went from the Cellule series on cells of colour built up through layers of paint, to his Windows series of the early sixties, in which he superimposed colours on one another to show how they affected each other. From this he went on to cruciform shapes, playing with the importance of the four corners of the canvas, and then to a series of flags. By the late 1960’s he was using acrylic to experiment with hard-edge abstraction, and in the 1970’s returned to oil and varnish because of his strong desire to work with colour rather than line. Done at around the time that McEwen began to experiment with cruciform shapes, En remontant les mauves exemplifies his use of many layers of paint to create a wall of living colour, each colour reacting with the others to build a sense of layered space.

963.38.references:
1958 Gallery XII, MMFA. Joyce Miller, from a 1997 exhibition proposal submitted to the Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery: "The work of Anne Kahane is an entity unto itself. This does not mean that there is no progression or development. On the contrary, the works evolve with a consistency that is rarely seen in contemporary artists. Although aware of international movements and trends, Kahane has, throughout four decades of work, remained true to her inner vision. Yet within this unique individuality, Kahane has endeavoured to address the universal - she has sought to capture the essence of form and the spirit of humanity. This duality of purpose flows throughout her work. From the work The Unknown Political Prisoner (1953) and the futility and anguish of its expressive skeletal form, to the tragicomic statements on the human condition as seen in Delegation (1957), the dialogue between form and content endures. Within this duality of spirit and form, there are further contrasts - horizontal/vertical; tragic/comic; flat/volume - two versus three dimensioniality; association/isolation; exterior/interior; complexity/simplicity. FOr instance, the horizontal groupings of the work of the 1950s that expand, accordian-like, into space, have, by the 1960s, become singular or coupled forms accented by their verticality. Kahane is a social commentator and she speaks bluntly, often with a humour that gives her work a tragic/comic nature. Kahane recounts anecdotal situations encountered by modern man in his environment. These comments on society's mass mentality and the alienation of the individual that dominated Kahane's early work, have evolved and crystallized into a single form - the isolation of man. Within all of Kahane's work, there is an intimacy and a sensitivity to all that the form represents."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, p.143
-Included in the exhibition “Robert Ayre: The Critic and the Collection,” Concordia Art Gallery, Concordia University, 1992

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Guido Molinari studied under Marian Scott and Gordon Webber at the Montreal École des Beaux Arts from 1928-51, and embarked on a painting career in which he has explored precise, mathematical relationships between colours and shapes. During the 1950’s the influence of Les Plasticiens is evident in his canvases as he attempted to obliterate the distinction between figure and ground in painting, first through blobs of colour daubed in equal proportions all over the canvas, then in paintings juxtaposing black and white forms. He is best-known for his paintings of the 1960’s, in which he used vertical bands of colour to continue his work of disrupting the figure/ground relationship, as in Espace bleu no. 2 of 1962. Here, Molinari plays with how colours affect each other depending on their distance from one another, using red and black stripes painted on a blue ground. Later on, in his Quantifier series of the late seventies, he simplified this exploration even further by working with one single colour per canvas, finally completely eliminating the pictorial conflict of foreground versus background.

964.02.title: Le Crustacien
964.02.subject: abstraction
964.02.color: black, yellow, ochre, green and red
964.02.credit: Gift of/don de Mr./M. and/et Mrs./Mme Moe Nadler and/et Mr./M. and/et Mrs./Mme David Nadler
964.02.source: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Moe Nadler and Mr. and Mrs. David Nadler / don de M. et Mme Moe Nadler et M. et Mme David Nadler, 1964
964.02.references:
After completing his studies at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts (Quebec City), where he studied under Jean-Paul Lemieux (1951-55), Edmund Alleyn lived and worked in Paris, France from 1955-71. The works in our permanent collection, "Warrior I" (1961), gouache and "Le Crustaciem" (1961-2), oil on canvas both date from this period. While the works are abstracts, they also articulate the artist's corporeal intervention, both through the historicized traces of his gestural marks left behind by the inroads of paint on surface, and the physicality of the medium itself. This is especially true of "Crustaciems", a painting which is composed of a black ground with thickly applied yellow and ochre, green and red vertical blocks of colour. In 1960, Robert Ayre, the Montreal Star's art critic had this to say about Alleyn's gouaches: "I have suggested that the gouaches are rehearsals for the big performance to come, but this is misleading. They are complete expressions on their own, not preliminary sketches." Alleyn returned to Quebec in 1971, and from 1972 onwards has taught in the Department of Visual Arts at the University of Ottawa. In the late sixties and early seventies his style changed radically, and he became part of a wave of Pop artists in Quebec, whose European-influenced, conceptually based approach emphasized photo-imagery and questioned painting's relevance. An important source of this expression on the part of Alleyn can be found in the catalogue MADE IN QUEBEC - LA BELLE PROVINCE, an exhibition held at the Musee du Quebec (12 September - 7 October, 1974), and the Musee d'art contemporain (October 10 - November 10, 1974).
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, p.74
-See J. Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,“ 1977, p.344
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, p.373

964.03.title: Boy
964.03.subject: figurative, boy on a circular base with yellow shorts and arms folded
964.03.color: blond wood with yellow tint, white base
964.03.credit: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Watkins and Mr. and Mrs. Michael Katz / Don de M. et Mme Saul Watkins et M. et Mme Michael Katz
964.03.source: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Watkin and Mr. and Mrs. Michael Katz / Don de M. et Mme Saul Watkin et M. et Mme Michael Katz, 1964
964.03.references:
Joyce Millar, from a 1997 exhibition proposal submitted to the Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery: "The work of Anne Kahane is an entity unto itself. This does not mean that there is no progression or development. On the contrary, the works evolve with a consistency that is rarely seen in contemporary artists. Although aware of international movements and trends, Kahane has, through four decades of work, remained true to her inner vision. Yet within this unique individuality, Kahane has endeavoured to address the universal - she has sought to capture the essence of form and the spirit of humanity. This duality of purpose flows from her work. From the work The Unknown Political Prisoner (1953) and the futility and anguish of its expressive skeletal form, to the tragicomic statements on the human conditions as seen in Delegation (1957), the dialogue between form and content endures. Within this duality of spirit and form, there are further contrasts - horizontal/vertical; tragic/comic; flat/volume - two versus three dimensioniality; association/isolation; exterior/interior; complexity/simplicity. For instance, the horizontal groupings of the work of the 1950's that expand, accordian-like, into space, have, by the 1960's, become singular or coupled forms accented by their verticality. Kahane is a social commentator and she speaks bluntly, often with a humour that gives her work a tragic/comic nature. Kahane recounts anecdotal situations encountered by modern man in his environment. These comments on society's mass mentality and alienation of the individual that dominate Kahane's early work, have also evolved and crystallizedinto the single form - the isolation of man. Within all of Kahane's work, there is an intimacy and a sensitivity to all that the form represents."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, p.143
-Included in the exhibition “Robert Ayre: The Critic and the Collection,” Concordia Art Gallery, Concordia University, 1992

964.37.subject: variety of figures in an urban street scene
964.37.credit: Gift of Mrs. Florence Millman in memory of Leo Millman/don de Mme Florence Millman à la mémoire de Leo Millman
964.37.source: Gift of Mrs. Florence Millman in memory of Leo Millman / don de Mme Florence Millman à la mémoire de Leo Millman, 1964
964.37.references:
1949 retrospective, National Gallery of Canada, organized by C. Comfort
reproduced on the cover of  “Paragraphs in Paint: The Second World War Art of Pegi Nicol MacLeod,” by Laura Brandon, Canadian War Museum, 1999
“ After the war Macleod worked hard on an exhibition of her New York paintings from the 1940s “Manhattan Cycle,” which toured Canada beginning in 1947. ...She incorporated  two images that had stayed with her after the war: the victory parades in the street below her apartment .... In a letter to McCurry she attached her artist’s statement  for the exhibition, which included descriptions of her intentions in these two  works. Of “When Johnnie Comes Marching Home” she wrote:
The life of the block does not change much. Families remain for years. Girls marry neighbourhood boys, take flats across the street or nearby.  
“When Johnnie Comes Marching Home” exemplifies this feeling. Though drafted for years into the army, he returns to find everything the same.”  (quote from  p.13 of “Paragraphs in Paint”)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, pp.312, 346
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, p.186

965.08.title: Danse carrée/Il était un carré
965.08.subject: abstract
965.08.credit: MENTION OBLIGATOIRE DE LA SODART: « Yves Gaucher, Danse carrée / Il était un carré, 1965, (signe copyright), SODART 2008 ». Gift of/don de Mr./M. and/et Mrs./Mme Arnold Steinberg, 1965
965.08.source: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Steinberg, 1965 / don de M. et Mme Arnold Steinberg, 1965
965.08.references: • See review(s) in Artist’s File • See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.53, 76-79, 81 • See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.369-371 • Included in the exhibition “Robert Ayre: The Critic and the Collection,” Concordia Art Gallery, Concordia University, 1992 • written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition: After studying at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts in 1954, Yves Gaucher switched to the École des Beaux Arts, from which he was expelled in 1956, only to be readmitted to study printmaking for three years under Albert Dumouchel. Following a few years working as a printer, Gaucher went back to painting, joining the ranks of Guido Molinari and Claude Tousignant as a hard-edge abstractionist who studies the optics of colour and line. Using stripes of colour which he calls “signals” or “silences”, Gaucher plays with diagonals and the tension between symmetry and asymmetry, foreground and background, appearance and disappearance. In Danse carrée/Il était un carré Gaucher tilts his canvas to create a diamond shape, disrupting the usual stability of the square. Within this format, he then poses optical questions by placing a series of blue dashes and tiny blue, green, and purple squares through a bright orange ground, marks which appear to wink and disappear when stared at. One of his first attempts to bring previous experiments in printmaking onto canvas, this work launched a series of large-scale compositions on the theme of the minimalist “signal”, in which Gaucher creates problems that allow him to explore the optics of painting instead of simply working to resolve them.

965.38.title: Study of a Tree Trunk
965.38.keywords: Group of Seven-Associated, Canadian Group of Painters-Original member, Woodland Scenes
965.38.subject: tree trunk
965.38.credit: don de/gift of Simpson Press Limited.
965.38.source: Gift of Simpson Press Limited / don de Simpson Press Limited, 1965
965.38.references:
Born in Victoria in 1871, Emily Carr worked almost exclusively in B.C. and is best known for her images of the communities and carvings of the First Nations peoples, and her expressive landscapes and forest interiors.

Emily Carr est née à Victoria (Colombie-Britannique) en 1871. Après des études au San Francisco School of Art (1889-1894), elle part pour l’Angleterre et poursuit sa formation de peintre au Westminster School of Art. De retour au pays en 1905, elle passera les cinq années suivantes à faire des excursions dans des villages indiens de la côte ouest. Consciente de la disparition imminente de ces cultures, Carr s’efforce d’en faire un “relevé artistique”, transposant sur ses toiles et ses dessins leurs habitations et leurs scultpures totémiques, notamment. Après un séjour à Paris en 1911, où elle expose deux oeuvres au Salon d’Automne, elle doit mettre de côté sa production pour gagner sa vie. Elle ne reprendra ses pinceaux que quinze années plus tard, après une rencontre marquante avec le Groupe des Sept en Ontario. Elle passera ses dernières années à peindre, dessiner et écrire, au gré de ses excursions à travers la région de Vancouver. Elle meurt à Victoria en 1945.

Emily Carr est l’une des artistes canadiennes les plus importantes de notre siècle. Si on ne l’a reconnue que tardivement, il n’en reste pas moins qu’elle aura développé un style personnel au gré de ses recherches formelles constantes. Malgré un cheminement artistique difficile et son isolement - en tant que femme indépendante et en tant que peintre moderne - elle ne s’est jamais pliée aux exigences de son milieu. Emily Carr a ouvert les portes de l’art à l’ouest canadien.

A peine sortie des écoles, les premières oeuvres d’Emily Carr sont des aquarelles à sujets indiens. Exécutées avec un souci de réalisme, elles se veulent plus “documentaires” qu’artistiques. Sa rencontre avec les peintres du Groupe des Sept, en 1928, sera une véritable révélation. Jusqu’alors isolée dans son coin de pays, voilà qu’elle fait la connaissance d’artistes intéressés par les techniques modernes et des sujets canadiens, comme elle. Sous leurs conseils, elle abandonne les sujets indiens pour ne se consacrer qu’au paysage, les forêts de l’ouest en particulier. Avec sa vision symboliste et romantique de la nature, Carr cherchera dorénavant à traduire la vitalité et la force qu’elle lui inspire, ceci étant ce qu’elle considère la manifestation divine.

Elle abandonne l’aquarelle pour l’huile sur papier, qui lui permet la même mobilité, mais une plus grande variété d’exécution.

De fait, les oeuvres des années trente sont à mi-chemin entre le fauvisme et l’abstraction géométrique: elle travaille la composition, les relations des formes dans l’espace et la touche rythmique.

Le dessin au charbon sera aussi une part importante de sa production: il servira souvent de base pour des oeuvres produites en studio. Là aussi, on retrouve les mêmes préoccupations pour le rythme et l’espace.

Etude d’un tronc d’arbre (c.1932) démontre bien cette qualité expressive des oeuvres de l’artiste. Travaillant les jeux d’ombre et de lumière, la forme du tronc se réduit à une masse lisse dont elle ne retient  que les contours. D’un geste rapide, elle transforme les branches en des lignes sinueuses qui donnent à l’ensemble un équilibre et une fluidité dans les mouvements ainsi crées. On sent ici toute la force de l’arbre: solide, massif et plein; habité de cette “présence divine”.

Ses oeuvres des années trente annoncent en fait celles de sa période de maturité, de la fin de cette décennie. Alors complètement détachée de tout mouvement artistique - ou toute influence extérieure - Emily Carr a enfin trouvé sa voix et atteint une liberté d’expression sans précédent. Spring Time (1938-1939) en est un bon exemple. Schématisant les formes jusqu’aux limites de l’abstraction, sa palette claire  et sa touche vibrante ne sont pas sans rappeler Van Gogh, qu’elle admirait d’entre tous. L’oeuvre est habitée d’un flux d’énergie continuel, où le regard circule sans cesse. Carr équilibre la surface au moyen de la touche, qui détermine seule la forme des arbres.

966.17.title: Seated Nude
966.17.keywords: Eastern Group of Painters, Group-Contemporary Arts Society, Canadian Group of Painters, Figuration-nude
966.17.subject: nude female seated with a table and two large canvasses behind her, model was Helene Ouvrard (Pat Landsley)
966.17.credit: Gift of the Samuel H. Schecter Foundation/don de la Fondation Samuel H. Schecter
966.17.source: Gift of the Samuel H. Schecter Foundation / don de la Fondation Samuel H. Schecter, 1966
966.17.references:
1959/11/5-19 solo show, Roberts Gallery, Toronto 1960/4/8-17 solo show, Beaverbrook Art Gallery, Fredericton From the 1991 application for certification of cultural property: "[Seated Nude is a] seated full-length nude with body in three quarter profile; figure seated on green ottoman with tonal blue wall behind. ... This painting is an outstanding example of Robert's "classic" figure style. Painted in Montreal at the time when Roberts became a founding member of John Lyman's Eastern Group, is exemplary in its inventiveness and exploitation of plastic elements and ne of the first Canadian figure paintings to describe this new modernist attitude towards the nude. Influenced by the work of Cezanne and Matisse, the work exemplifies Roberts' early treatment of the nude through its use of low relief planes, flattened and silhouette volumes, and euqla balance of light and dark. Roberts' superb colour in this work reflects his instinctive grasp of the relationship of hue and value. This is one of the few extant examples of female nudes which Roberts painted during this period." (Sandra Paikowsky)

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Part of Tousignant’s famous Chromatic Transformers series, Stocastique VxBxMxR is a variation on the theme of the target, an optical exploration of colour using rings that appear to spin and pulsate when stared at. Stocastic, a mathematical term meaning that which involves a random variable, indicates Tousignant’s mathematical approach to the painting, and is also a reference to the creative process that is both calculated and spontaneous. Tousignant’s application of colour is deliberate, the VxBxMxR of the title referring to his selection of vert, bleu, mauve, and rouge as the players in the work, yet the term “stocastic” reveals the work has been partly determined by chance.

In the early 1960's, Toronto's storefront displays of women's undergarments convinced Burton that "the 20th century woman is a packaged commodity. She is presented in advertisements, the entertainment field, and men's mags as an inanimate object, divested of her humanity, leaving her only as a sex symbol." Burton was fascinated by what he describes as "the peculiarly significant individuality that underclothes give us all, especially women." "I

969.36.references:
"Lemieux's early interest in art was developed under the tutelage of Suzor-Cote and through his studies at Montreal's Ecole des beaux-arts. Further instructions in Paris in the early 1930s brought him into contact with Clarence Gagmnon. Like him, Lemieux was unaffected by the Parisian avant-garde, preferring to comment on conditions in his native province. On his return to Canada, he became part of a small group of painters who concentrated on depicting traditional quebecois ways of life." (Art Gallery of Ontario: Selected Works, 1990)

969.46.description: Transcendence was one of twenty artworks commissioned by the House of Seagram for the Expo 67 World Fair and was donated to Loyola College in 1968. The 10,000 pound, 24-foot stainless steel, multi-part structure represents man and space travel. The brass ball in the centre is a motorized globe. Viewed from the side, the piece suggests a human figure while from the front it looks like a rocket.

971.07.title: Untitled/sans titre
971.07.subject: abstracted figurative
971.07.references: Imbued with a violence in both its gestural and chromatic expression, Karel Appel's work expresses a state of mind specific to the socio-economic climate of post-war Europe. After leaving Amsterdam for Paris in 1950, Appel became affiliated with the Cobra group. These artists, coming principally from Copenhagen, Brussels and Amsterdam, sought to completely redefine the perameters of art. Within this "fresh start", Appel's work flouted classical traditions, and transmuted through humour the aggression of his assault. His artistic research emphasized materials and research into new techniques. According to certain poets and novelists, such as Hugo Claus, who closely followed the evolution of Appel's oeuvre, its extraordinary value rests on its humanistic expressivity, its anguished introspection into life and death as well as its ability to express both implicit and explicit desire. Through a highly diverse production, Appel explored a multitude of techniques, from woodcuts to polyester and aluminum sculptures. At all times, he drew his inspiration from the material itself, which consequently transformed into what he called a "magic space". The work in the permanent collection, "untitled", is a colour lithograph from 1969. Its expressively abstracted figuration in exhuberant tones of yellow, pink, blue and green provides an example of Karel Appel's central concerns.

971.12.references: William Brymner was born in Greenock, Scotland and raised in Montreal. In early 1878, he enrolled in the Academie Julian, where he was instructed by William Bougereau and Tony Robert-Fleury, both exponents of `grand manner naturalism'. As one of the first Canadians to study art in Paris, his formative experiences would in turn prove to have an inestimable influence on the succeeding generation of Canadian artists, through his activities as an art teacher and member of Canadian art institutions. Brymner stayed in Paris for eight years, and on his return to Canada in 1886 he took up a teaching position at the Art Association of Montreal, where he remained until 1921. He was president of the Royal Canadian Academy of the Arts from 1909 - 1918, and a member of the Canadian Art Club. Adrien Hebert, Emily Coonan, ... (plug in the artists as you come across them) all studied under him. Brymner specialized in intimate, domestic scenes rather than the large-scale, heroic canvases typical of French academy painting. "Portrait of Elizabeth Savage", a head study loosely rendered in charcoal and white chalk on a blue ground, is one of his later works (c. 1918-19). The study displays a careful treatment of light, and an intimate understanding of the force of a simple, emphatic composition.

972.06.title: Le Second couple hiératique

972.06.source: Extended loan of the artist / prêt prolongé de l'artiste, 1972
972.06.references: A major figure in the history of Quebec sculpture, Louis Archambault played a key role in the evolution of this discipline, both as an artist and a teacher. In 1948 he was a signatory of the the Prisme d'yeux manifesto, the response to Le Refus Global drawn up by Alfred Pellan and Jacques de Tonnancour. In the 1950's he developed an artistic process which resulted in a vocabulary of both semi-abstract and animal and human form, using ceramics, iron or bronze. "Le second couple hieratique" (1970) articulates aspects of this vocabulary that is abstracted figuration. As the title indicates, Archambault is concerned here with hieratic, or primary representations of the human form - the "couple" consists of two monolithic vertical constructions of plywood painted white, the taller ending in a zig-zag, the shorter punctuated by a circle two-thirds of the way up. The relationship between these three-dimensional objects and basic, or "hieretic" two-dimensional geometric shapes is clear. What also emerges is Archambault's articulation of the rectangle, the zig-zag and the circle to symbolize erotic dualities and interrelationships.
