Stephane Aquin writes “Goodwin first devoted herself to printmaking out of dissatisfaction with her painting and a stated need for self-discipline . With a serendipitous sense of experimentation, Goodwin pressed real objects directly into soft varnishes, then modified the resulting impression to emphasize the effects of transparency and opacity.” Vest Fragment One belongs to a series of prints produced in a four year phase in her work. From 1969-1973, “Betty Goodwin set her attention on objects charged with symbolic and emotional connotation. such as birds’ nests and vests. The series of works that resulted, among the most decisive of Goodwin’s career....The Print discloses the body through its covering, the vest, and is quite literally the physical imprint of it. The vest itself is imprinted with the form and movement of the body that inhabited it....” (Stephane Aquin, “Two Pioneers: Betty Goodwin and Irene F. Whittome See website http:/ www.collanaud.qc.ca/rtl/forget/ 22-deuxe.htm) Goodwin was 46 when she began doing prints based on vests, like the vests her father used to make. (Val Ross, “The wounding gifts of Betty Goodwin” Globe and Mail November 14, 1998 p.C5) “In 1969 Goodwin had begun a s series of bold etchings of men’s vests that did away with traditional artsy mark-making. Instead of drawing pictures of her subjects, Goodwin passed the vests right through the printing press, producing a direct almost X-ray record of the crumpled clothing....” “There’s certainly a note of elegy here- Goodwin’s dead father had had a vest-making business-but there’s no evident mourning. The commemorative work done by the vest is almost aggressive , grinding the past almost irrevocably into art’s present rather than looking back teary-eyed.” (Blake Gopnik, “More Strength than pathos.” Globe and Mail , November 14, 1998 p.C5) “She says she was something like 48 years old when she experienced what she calls “a profound breakthrough,” ...”and before I knew it I was etching,” adopting a process called soft-ground, in which the object to be represented is physically pressed against a copper plate. She started with gloves. Soon she moved to vests, old vests, ones she found at home first of all, then others she got from the Salvation Army.” (“ Secrets and Lies” Gerald Hannon interviews Betty Goodwin, Canadian Art, Fall 1998, vol. 15 #3, p.53) “If the etchings of the vests that she made in the early 70s are commonly thought of as marking the beginning of her artistic career, it is because here her desire to restore or recreate a semblance of life at the very point that she makes life’s loss palpable is first realized and becomes the impulse that sustains subsequent series of works. The vests whose very threads became dense graphic registers of corporeal presence, remain exemplary of the way Goodwin takes possession of her subject and creates a sense of lived time. Treated as emblems of life rather than as cast-offs 
the vests were imprints of actual clothes transformed in their passage through the press, condensed into ghosts of the absent bodies they once fit.” (Jessica Bradley, Betty Goodwin: Signs of Life
Art Gallery of Windsor 28 October 1995-7 January 1996 p. 13)

written by Martine Fournier for the “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

 By the time Alexander Bercovitch arrived in Montreal in 1927, his artistic practice already combined the influence of diverse earlier experiences. Born in Cherson, Russia, in 1893, he worked on theatre decor for Operas in Odessa and St. Petersburg as a young man, before going to Jerusalem to study under Professor Schatz at the Palestine School of Bezabel. From here he went to Munich, studying under Franz von Stuck (also the teacher of Vassily Kandinsky, the famous Russian Abstractionist) at the Munich Academy of Fine Arts, and absorbing the work of the German Expressionists. At the start of the First World War he returned to Russia, where he studied under Professor Denisov at the Leningrad Academy of Fine Arts until the revolution of 1917, when he moved to Turkestan and organized his own art school.  From his early training in Russia he had adopted an interest in the icon, and had learned of the tenets of Futurism and Primitivism. In both Jerusalem and Turkestan he was exposed to the decorative geometric forms of folk art, an influence he would carry with him to Canada when he moved to Montreal.
    After working here for several years chiefly on street scenes of the city and portraiture, Bercovitch had his first solo exhibition at a commercial gallery at Carter Studio in 1933. While critical reaction was mixed, most were favourably struck by the artist’s directness, simplicity of form, and what they perceived as a kind of truthfulness of vision. He was hailed by critics such as Robert Ayre, who favoured the humanism of his approach as opposed to the overriding obsession in Canada with landscape centred in Toronto around the work of the Group of Seven. Untitled Portrait (Female) provides an example of Bercovitch’s sustained interest in portraiture and ordinary human experience. It also reveals his embrace of the sensual and colourful over the intellectualism of Abstraction, which he felt should provide the structure of artistic production without robbing art of its ability to communicate simple human themes.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Philip Surrey was apprenticed at Bridgen’s engraving as a young man, then studied at the Winnipeg School of Art and under Fred Varley in 1929 at the Vancouver School of Art.  During the 1930’s he traveled to New York City, where he studied at the Art Students’ League, and in 1937 moved to Montreal. This city would become his favoured subject as he used its streets, taverns, and cafés as images of the Modern city. While maintaining traditional painting concerns in his work, the influence of abstraction is evident in his simplified, geometric forms. In this study for a painting of the bar at Hotel Russel, Surrey explores one of his favourite subjects, the tavern as last refuge for depressed and lonely men. The three men in this drawing sit isolated from one another, slumped over their beer or gazing into space, each lost in his own thoughts. Set against the bare geometric grid of windows and floor tiles they create a picture of dejection, brightened only by the occasional touch of colour. This was a favourite technique of Surrey, who liked to see bits of colour “singing” against drab browns and greys.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Anne Savage studied during the 1910’s under William Brymner and Maurice Cullen at the Art Association of Montreal, and in 1921 was a founding member of the Beaver Hall Group. During the 1920’s she painted landscape, chiefly working in the Laurentians, depicting both its scenery and inhabitants. She worked in a Neo Impressionist style that was influenced by the Group of Seven, and has been likened to the work of Tom Thomson and A. Y. Jackson. She also preceded the Automatiste movement in her rejection of conventional academic methods, and contributed to the modernisation of art education in Quebec. Known for her rhythmic sense of design and bright colour, she developed during the 1930’s an independent style with increased simplification of form and an even bolder palette, seen in Untitled (landscape with farm buildings), in which the red and white of the farm buildings appear vibrant against the green and yellow of the rolling landscape.

written by Martine Fournier:

Educated at the University of Saskatchewan in Saskatoon under Eli Bornstein from 194-8, and atending Emma Lake workshops throughout the 196’s, Dorothy Knowles has achieved a reputation as one of Canada’s greatest landscapists. While her painting career began with a focus on abstraction during the 1950’s, Knowles found her work moving closer and closer into the landscape realm, as if she were being pulled into it the way she once described herself as having been “swallowed up” by the prairie. Working both with large, monumental canvases and smaller, more intimate works, Knowles achieves landscapes in which signs of humanity are rarely present, yet a sense of peaceful unity is created between landscape and viewer. Prairie provides an example of how Knowles creates a world of calm using muted tones, mesmerizing the viewer with the dizzying brushstrokes used to create the praire, and in this case drawing the gaze in toward a focal clump of trees on the horizon.

975.04.02.title: Interaction of Colour: Commentary
975.04.02.subject: colour charts
975.04.02.credit: Gift of the Faculty of Fine Arts, Concordia University/don de la Faculté des beaux-arts, Université Concordia
975.04.02.source: Gift of the Faculty of Fine Arts / don de la Faculté des beaux-arts, 1975
975.04.02.references: Josef Albers was an important exponent of Bauhaus Utopian theory and an instrumental force in the dissemination of its educational philosophy. Founded by Walter Gropius in 1919, the Bauhaus was a German school of design, which included at various times on its teaching "staff" such artists as Lyonle Feininger, Paul Klee, Wassily Kandinsky, Lazlo Moholy-Nagy and Josef Albers. Although short-lived, its ideas produced waves of reaction not only in Germany, but also in North America where the influence went beyond design practice to especially affect art education. After emigrating to the United States in 1933, Albers taught at the Black Mountain College in North Carolina until 1949. From 1950 until retiring in 1959, he was Chairman of the Department of Art at Yale University. Based on the exploration of universal phenomena, Albers' work stems from the notion of art as experience, as "performance". At the very root of his colour studies lies the idea that single elements are at once independent and interdependent and that as such, parallel the relationships of real life. His experiments with colour and form exemplify his enduring interest in the complex and conditional nature of perception. To illustrate the significance of the context in which a colour is placed, he published several print editions accompanied by educational texts. The works "Interaction of Colour, Commentary" (paper, cardboard and fabric, 1963), "Interaction of Colour" (serigraphy, paper, cardboard and fabric, 1963[?]) and "Soft Edge, Hard Edge" (serigraphy, 1965) all form part of this sweeping investigation.

975.07.references:
William Blair Bruce of Hamilton, Ontario was one of the Canadian artists who became so involved with the Paris art scene that he never returned home. Starting in 1881 he studied under William Bougereau at l'Academie Julien, and like Paul Peel married a Scandinavian. His paintings were never exhibited in Canada during his lifetime. The work in the permanent collection, "Bluebeard's Wife" (no date) demonstrates that, in spite of his thorough academic training, Bruce was also heavily influenced by Impressionism, in his use of pure unmixed colour in small areas, applied in thick flecks and with short, small brushstrokes. his lifetime. The work in the permanent collection, "Bluebeard's Wife" demonstrates that,

written by Martine Fournier

Working in Victoria, British Columbia since 1972, Roland Brener uses large sculptures and installations, usually involving sound and movement, to comment on the relationship between humanity and machinery, the effects of mass communication, and what he calls the “debased figure” in society. Wall-Mounted Flying Stereotype is part of a later series that represents a departure from Brener’s previous large and technologically complex sculptural work. In the series of flying stereotypes, which includes a mobile of over-sized stereotypical heads such as a First Nations man in a feather headdress and a black boy in a straw hat, Brener works on a more intimate scale, yet is still concerned with the themes of debased person, of grotesqueness, and the impact of mass communication. Wall-Mounted Flying Stereotype is a small ceramic figure suspended from the wall, lit luridly with green light, face magnified by a lens placed in front of it. With this, and the rest of the series, Brener questions not only society’s racism but what we consider to be a present-day sense of liberalism.

From "Legal Perspective: Selected Works from the Collection of Osler, Hoskin and Harcourt". Catalogue to an exhibition held at the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, June 28 - September 13, 1992. "Since his first solo exhibition in Toronto in 1967, David Bolduc's work has shifted from shaped canvases and hard-edge pieces, through minimalist constructions, to watercolours and pastels, and on to what he terms "pure painting". The backgrounds have an all-over compositional quality marked by subtle modulations of colour wash. Bolduc usuallyincorporates an abstract image with a strong, totemic quality along the central, vertical axis - an image invariably characterized bya rich use of colour pigment applied directly from the tube.The titles often reveal Bolduc's interest in eastern art, particularly Oriental textiles." (p 14)

978.14.title: Untitled/sans titre
978.14.subject: abstract
978.14.references:
Claire Gravel, from a catalogue accompanying the 1992 exhibition Le dessin rebelle at the Saidye Bronfman Centre: "Between his neo-plasticien training with the painters Molinari, Gaucher and Goguen at Concordia University and his association with the Insurrection Art Company, a group of conceptual artists (Paul Heyer, Mike Haslam and Bob Walker) who showed unorthodox works at Galerie Media, Francois Morelli assumed a distinct position in an art milieu then torn by aesthetic antagonism. He experienced these in constant dialysis, as evident in his 1974 "action" where he attached two canvases to his feet and walked to Concordia University." From an artist's statement dated October 1978: "La Grande Baie and the surrounding regions are comprised of marshes and are situated near Oka, Quebec. They are the last marshes in the immediate vicinity of Montreal and are the nesting area for a large variety of migrating birds. The Government of Quebec, through the Minister of Tourism, Hunting and Fishing, has recently annexed this region to the Provincial Park Paul Sauve, thus protecting it from a similar fate of other marshes (e.g. Nun's Island), and protecting this region of major ecological importance. In May 1977, I was employed by this Ministry as a graphic artist. I was sent to Park Paul Sauve where I worked on several drafting and landscaping projects. During this stay, in collaboration with a group of biologists, I was able to observe the environment, its flora and its fauna. I completed my work in October, 1977. Since then I have been working on a series of pastels which would synthesize the luminous, temporal and spatial qualities of this period of my life. The series entitled "Marsh-Lite" is neither an impressionist rendering of a landscape, nor a literal account of an event. It is closer to a visual symphony; an instantaneous drafting of an ongoing natural phenomenon, a simulation of a natural environment and event through plastic (artistic) means, extending a traditionally visual art into the realm of performing arts, this performance being a celebration of this rediscovered part of nature - La Grande Baie." Karen Antaki, from a brochure accompanying an exhibition of Morelli's work held at the Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery in 1997: "Over the last fifteen years, Montreal-based artist Francois Morelli has developed a distinctive formal vocabulary that weds the gestural intimacy of drawing with the monumentality that attaches to sculpture and installation. Like dreaming, which casts both light and darkness, his production offers up the familiar and the fantastic in a place seemingly previously traversed, where that which is both known and mysterious presents itself and lingers. ... As a multidisciplinary artist whose pratice includes drawing, sculpture and performance, Morelli has traditionally concerned himself with the interaction of bodies and memory in space."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

979.41.references:
"Lemieux's early interest in art developed under the tutelage of Suzor-Cote and through his studies at Montreal's Ecole des beaux-arts. Further instruction in Paris in the early 1930s brought him into contact with Clarence Gagnon. Like him, Lemieux was unaffected by the Parisian avant-garde, preferring to comment on conditions in his native province. On his return to Canada, he became part of a small group of painters who concentrated on depicting traditional quebecois ways of life." (Art Gallery of Ontario: Selected Works, 1990) "Moody, simplified studies of strong sentiment, they celebrate 'la survivance' of the basic values of the true Quebec." (Dennis Reid, A Concise History of Canadian Painting, second edition, Toronto: Oxford University Press, 1988) "He remains reserved and ascetic, a master of luminous white and grey ... he softens the straightlaced harshness and brings it not only tenderness but grace ... He remains still, enveloping us as well as himself in the mystery and loneliness of space and time." (Robert Ayre, in The Montreal Star, 23 September 1967) "La periode "classique" de l'artiste (1956-1970) marque ensuite l'avenement d'une peinture qui maintient la perennite de la reference figurative chere a l'artiste tout en s'alimentant aux sources et aux pratiques constructives de l'art abstrait. Figuratif abstrait qui refuse en se sens la polarisation exclusive entre figuratifs et abstraits, Lemieux entend, en pleine maturite, poursuivre independamment une voie symbolique et expressive, engagee spirituellement. C'est ainsi que pendant quinze ans, il developpe un thematique des grands espaces dramatiques et desertiques, de tableaux d'hiver noyes dans le blanc, de personnages introvertis, de lieux insolites, de ruines, ainsi que la memoire des gens du pays et le souvenir proustien du temps passe." (p22, Marie Carani, from the Musee du Quebec publication "L'Effet Lemieux", on the occasion of the June 4 - November 1, 1992 Lemieux retrospective) "According to art critic Jacques de Roussan, Lemieux stands out from ... Borduas and Pellan by the fact that he could be given a figurative label. Like them, he knew the "pangs of the anecdotal", namely he painted scenes for their narrative values more so than for their subjective dimensions. But whereas Borduas and Pellan broke with realism, Lemieux sought to renew it. The stylistic analysis of the painting of Lemieux was his greatest strength. In the fifties, he was interested in simplifying space to focus solely on the geometric functions, In the seventies, he once again began to give greater details to his landscapes and characters. ... The work of Lemieux would not have been possible without the experiences and endeavours of the post-impressionists: cubists, But, according to de Roussan, Lemieux also developed his own vision and gave form to it in the typical Quebec landscapes and characters that he painted." (p 28, english synopsis of Jacques de Roussan text in Musee du Quebec publication, L'Effet Lemieux)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, pp.311, 344
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, p.289
-Included in the exhibition “Robert Ayre: The Critic and the Collection,” Concordia Art Gallery, Concordia University, 1992

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Jean Paul Lemieux studied under Suzor-Côté at the Montreal École des Beaux Arts, graduating in 1934, and went to Paris during the 1930’s, where he met Clarence Gagnon. Like Gagnon, Lemieux was relatively unaffected by the avant-garde art of Paris, and upon returning to Canada became part of a group of painters whose aim was to depict the traditional way of life in Quebec. Lemieux is famous for his depcitions of vast wintry landscapes, sometimes peopled by stylized figures, which express a deep sense of loneliness, reflecting both the harsh climate and cultural isolation faced by the French of Quebec. While he draws on abstraction to create simplified forms and highly organized spaces, he uses it only to further his figurative investigations. 
    Le soleil dans capricorne is from Lemieux’s 1956-1970 “classic” period, the time during which he focused on vast white winter landscapes, often broken by people, abandoned farms, or other signs of habitation. In this work the isolation of human presence is particularly palpable as it is visible only in distant, miniscule buildings, separated from the viewer by a huge, blank, intimidating whiteness of snow. It is a vision of a space at once universal and specifically belonging to Quebec and its people.

Jean McEwen’s artistic career spanned more than half a century. He became involved in the  Montreal art scene in the late 1940s, while still employed at a pharmaceutical company. His early work demonstrated the radical changes towards an abstract vocabulary that marked the decade, and that were defined by such pivotal Québécois figures as Paul Emile Borduas and Jean-Paul Riopelle. However, McEwen’s automatist tendencies soon  gave way to canvases that were influenced by the works of American painters such as Mark Rothko and Clifford Still whom he came in contact with while in Paris from 1951 to 1953. By the late mid-fifties, McEwen’s paintings were characterized by their chromatic play, luminosity and sensuous, fluid surfaces. Throughout his career, he was dedicated to creating abstract pictorial spaces that spoke of transformation, where purely formal investigations become sites of unique subjective expression.

 Jean McEwen’s first solo exhibition was held at the Galerie Agnès Lefort in 1951. He  exhibited extensively in important solo and group exhibitions, such as the 5th Biennial Exhibition of Canadian Painting (National Gallery of Canada, 1963), McEwen 1953-73 (Musée d’art contemporain de Montreéal, 1973), The Non-Figurative Association of Montreal (Concordia Art Gallery, 1983) and Jean McEwen. Colour in Depth (Montreal Museum of Fine Arts, 1987).

The artist has works in major national and international public and private collections including the National Gallery of Canada, Montreal Museum of Fine Arts, Musée du Québec, Art Gallery of Ontario, Museum of Modern Art, New York, Musée d’art contemporain, Vancouver Art Gallery, Walker Art Centre, Indianapolis and the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery, Concordia University.

Jean McEwen was a faculty member in the Faculty of Fine Arts at Concordia University from 1983 to 1993.  He was the recipient of numerous Canadian and Québec awards throughout his lengthy career including most recently the Prix du Québec Paul-Émile Borduas which he received in December 1998.
-Karen Antaki (wallboard installed for an exhibition paying tribute to Jean McEwen January, 1999.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

During his early career, John Fox was known as a leading figurative painter, having studied under John Lyman and Goodridge Roberts at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. In 1972 he realized that in fact figurative work did not satisfy his desire for expression, and he began to make radical changes, enlarging his canvas and experimenting with new painting tools such as spray cans, rollers, and masking tape. His interest lies in the physical process of painting, its sensuality and colouration, within which he seeks to create harmony rather than discord.  
   Ledaean was painted with a process developed by Fox which involves smearing two or three colours onto a canvas using a roller attached to a long cane, then adding masking tape to create lines through the colour. It is also an example of his introduction of metallic powder into the paint, which he uses to add luminousness and mystery, creating a reflective painting surface that is at once impenetrable and inviting.

written by Maritne Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

This work exemplifies Ewen’s longstanding interest in the potential of the works of nature, specifically meteorological phenomena, to be used as abstract formal artistic investigations. The thundercloud in Ewen’s lithograph looks as though it is based on a simple textbook drawing, a source Ewen often used to obtain his imagery, and is seen both as a force and as a shape that works within the bounds of the edges of paper. The circles, dashed lines and crosses also serve as both scientific and artistic language simultaneously.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:


    Born in China of Indian descent, Sam Tata studied at the University of Hong Kong and began to explore photography in 1935. Japanese invasions formed some of his earliest subjects, but he was mainly a studio photographer until 1948, when he met Henri Cartier-Brisson in India and was encourageed by him to go out into the streets to do more spontaneous work. Tata worked for magazines such as Life and National Geographic during the 1940’s and 50’s, capturing the life of China, and of India on his visits there, in 1949 documenting the Chinese Communist Revolution. From 1952-6 he made Hong Kong his home but, dissatisfied with his life there, he came to Montreal. The city streets furnished the bulk of his subject matter, alongside his portrait work. Cyclist, Pont Neuf, Paris reflects both interests as it acts as a portrait of the anonymous cyclist resting on the edge of the Pont Neuf, while at the same time capturing a famous area in the city of Paris.

written by Martine Fournier for the “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

 La Pâque nouvelle is an example illustrative of the kind of abstraction Borduas was undertaking during the 1940’s, before the move to New York. It is a study of colour, contrasting purples and yellows, white and black, and an exploration of the role of space on a two-dimensional canvas. While Borduas recognizes the flatness of the picture plane, he also creates layers of space, his daubs of white, pale green, and yellow paint appearing to hover at slightly different distances over the darker background planes. He creates a picture world in which foreground and background reside very close to one another, yet are still separated by the shallow space-layers created by daubing contrasting light colours over a smoother, darker ground.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Toronto artist Michael Snow has had a highly diverse, multidisciplinary career. Beginning in the 1950’s with abstract drawings and paintings, Snow moved in the 1960’s to his famous series on the Walking Woman, of which Rolled Woman II forms a part. During the 1970’s he began working with sculpture and photography, also developing a widely acclaimed film career. Throughout the 1980’s he continued working in film, in addition to exploring installation and holographic techniques. 
    The Walking Woman series involves Snow’s exploration of one image to the fullest. Taking a template of a stylized, 1960’s commercial image of a woman walking, Snow repeated it in hundreds of ways, presenting it in whole form and in parts, alone and in groups, in pieces, bent, rolled, cut out, in both two- and three-dimensional forms. While it evolved from a number of sources, including Pop art and the female figures of Willem de Kooning, the Walking Woman more importantly refers to the presence of the female form as subject throughout art history. Snow uses it to explore the relationship between form and context, subject and medium, and the nature of visual perception. In Rolled Woman II, he has painted the template woman onto paper, then cut her out and rolled her around a pole. In this way she has been worked and abstracted as much as possible, in fact, distorted beyond all recognition.

983.19.title: Summer Blues - The Kiss
983.19.credit: Purchased with a Canada Council Special Purchase Assistance Grant/acquis avec l'aide d'une subvention du Conseil des Arts du Canada
983.19.source: Purchase - Special Purchase Assistance Grant, Canada Council for the Arts / achat - Subvention spéciale d'aide aux acquisitions, Conseil des Arts du Canada, 1983
983.19.references:
written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Joyce Wieland studied commercial art for three years at Toronto’s Central Technical School under Doris McCarthy, who became a mentor and role model for Wieland. Working in animation at Graphic film, Wieland met and married artist Michael Snow, and embarked on her own artistic career. Her early work consisted of figurative experiments in Abstract Expressionism, while later on she moved into more non-objective abstract work, playing with collage and mixed media. Even though this exploration was abstract, Wieland has admitted that almost all her work is autobiographical, and more specifically based on female existence and the domestic sphere. For example, her series of “stain paintings”, made with very light applications of watered-down pigment to canvas, involve organic, often sexual, womb like forms that Wieland believed stemmed from a need to work through her own infertility. Summer Blues - The Kiss is part of the Summer Blues series, in which Wieland combines bits of mirror or glass, cardboard, drawing, and crumpled pieces of paper with delicate pastel colouring to create abstract works that seem to refer to and transform everyday experience. The collages demystify the artistic process as the combination of found objects and invented forms lends a sense of the hand-made to the work. At the same time the collage is a simple celebration of sensual colour and texture.
    Following this period of her career, Wieland began to incorporate common symbols such as stylized hearts, lips, and arrows into her 1960’s work, deriving this from the Pop art movement she experienced while living in New York from 1963 71, yet infusing it with her own concerns about sexual and other popular imagery as related to the female experience. By 1967 she had ceased to paint as she considered her experiments with quilting, installation, and film to be better vehicles for her expression.

written by Martine Fournier for “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

 Having studied from 1930-2 under Harry H. Wickey at the Art Students’ League in New York City, Miller Brittain was influenced by the early 1930’s New York art scene, including social realism, the Ashcan School, and the Mexican Mural movement which was being echoed in New York murals at the time. A skilled draftsman, Brittain nonetheless distorted figures in his work, rounding them, emphasizing line and silhouette rather than detail. The sensuousness of his soft rounded forms and jewelled colour was always in marked contrast to his subject matter, which was usually the difficulties of life in the Maritimes during the Great Depression, or more generally the human experience of loneliness and anguish.
    Serving as a bomb-aimer during the Second World War, Brittain was officially appointed a war artist in 1945. Following this he entered what has been described as a religious phase, drawing his subject matter from Biblical sources, and eventually referring to a more generalized sense of spirituality during the 1950’s. In 1957 the death if his wife brought a more emotional, even nightmarish quality to his work. His 1959 Portrait of a Woman does not draw overtly on the theme of suffering, but does reflect on the human condition through the process of aging, as Brittain has paid particular attention to the details of wrinkled skin and hollow eyes in this portrait.

984.20.title: Manipulating the Self
984.20.references: "The trio of artists - A.A. Bronson, Jorge Zontal and Felix Partz - banded together under the name General Idea in 1968. Working as a collective in multimedia work allowed them to better assume the role of "cultural investigators" who mimicked the tactics of the mass media and appropriated a multitude of cultural vehicles. The scope of their activity and their commitment to ambiguity resist classification. At the outset the prevalent framework of these activities was the 1984 Miss General Idea Pavillion, an open-ended, easily manipulated concept within which works were realized. ... Any attempt, however, to correlate precisely image and text is fruitless. Rather, the viewer is exposed to a multiplicity of meanings and their ironical and paradoxical intent." (Art Gallery of Ontario: Selected Works, 1990) "Les artistes dont les pseudonymes AA Bronson, Felix Partz et Jorge Zontal sont reunis sous le vocable de General Idea oeuvrent depuis 1968 autour de preoccupations illusoires comme les concours de beautes, les parades de mode et le kitsch urbain de la culture nord-americaine. Elabore des les debuts des annees 70, leur plus grand projet consiste a planifier et a construire le pavillon de Miss General Idea, une sorte de faux mythe base sur le roman de science-fiction 1984, de George Orwell, veritable critique narrative de la societe. Le trio fait l'eloge de tout ce qui est precieux et glamour autour de l'election repetitive de Miss General Idea. La parodie a pris des proportions telles qu'elle est devenue le propos de leur recherches, et ils la vivent jusqu'a l'absurde en s'y jetant corps et ame. ... La structure de leur oeuvre comporte un double jeu : celui de creer une idole a l'image de leur propre mythologie et d'y decouvrir le paradoxe qui decoule de ce langage difficilement penetrable, une forme d'appropriation a partir de strategies manipulent divers aspects du domaine de la culture." (Pierre Granche, La collection : Tableau inaugurale, Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal, 1992)

So Certain Was I, I Was a Horse (1984)”...a startling title taken from French playwright Antonin Artaud. Also in mixed media and made in 1984, the riveting image shows one woman in an angularized posture leaning over , much as many of the women in the Swimmer series. Beside her is another woman whose one leg forms lightly the hind leg of a horse, attached to the woman in the foreground.” (Lawrence Sabbath, “Goodwin’s creations extraordinary but eerie.” Gazette Sat. Feb. 15, 1986 p.C.8) 
“The whiteness of the blank support is the paradigmatic silence of her style: in So Certain Was I, I Was a Horse (1984) -the title is from Artaud-whiteness permeates the bodies so that we are uncertain as to whether they are coming into being or fading away...If there is any life in those bodies of crumbly charcoal, it is given by the touches of pastel; not just by the pastel’s colours but by the inherent fleshiness of its substance.” (Georges Bogardi, Betty Goodwin: Passages Concordia Art Gallery, 1986, p.14) 

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Betty Goodwin has devoted her career to the study of the figure as the best way to capture the human condition. Working for many years with no formal education, she enrolled to study printmaking under Yves Gaucher at Concordia University in the late 1960’s, and began experimenting with collage, prints, and assemblage as well as painting, drawing and sculpture. Highly emotive, her images of human suffering have been influenced by Egon Schiele and Joseph Beuys, sometimes merely suggesting the body through bones, wiring, or tangled roots that suggest networks of veins or the nervous system.   
    In So Certain Was I, I Was a Horse (the title having been taken from the French playwright Antonin Artaud), Goodwin shows one woman bending over another, the leg of a horse protruding from her hip, while a third ghostly form stands behind. While the idea of imagining oneself as a horse, conveyed by the title of the work, is whimsical, the image of these bent bodies suggests a disconcerting brokenness. Their posture would be ideal for a horse about to break into a run, yet on the human body it becomes crippling, even painful.

Catalogue to an exhibition held at McMichael Canadian Art Collection from June 28 - September 13, 1992. "In addition to her work as an artist/photographer, Angela Grauerholz is also a graphic designer, a teacher at UQAM, and a founding member of Artexte (a non-profit documentation centre for contemporary visual arts) in Montreal. Her photography is characterized by its dark, gentle tones, skewed perspectives, and the use of long exposures to create a soft-focus image. Through her techniques, Grauerholz makes the presence of the artist a visible, conscious part of the work and denies the purely mimetic aspect of photography. Her subject matter, usually presented as a series of works, includes public and private spaces, portaits and clouds." (p 17)

985.09.title: Seated Figure II
985.09.color: black, white, red, yellow, blue, green, brown, purple, grey
985.09.credit: Purchased with a Canada Council Special Purchase Assistance Grant/acquis avec l'aide d'une subvention du Conseil des Arts du Canada
985.09.source: Purchase- Special Purchase Assistance Grant, Canada Council for the Arts / achat- Subvention spéciale d'aide aux acquisitions, Conseil des Arts du Canada, 1985
985.09.references:
written by Martine Fournier:

After immigrating to Canada from the Netherlands in 1952, Harold Klunder settled just outside Hamilton, Ontario in 1954, and studied at the Central Technical School of Toronto. After graduating in 1964, he worked successfully as a graphic designer during the 1960’s, but by the following decade had decided to return to painting.  His energetic, exuberant images could be seen as attempts to bridge the gap between Modernism and Abstraction. While interested in the theoretical basis of movements like Automatism and that of Les Plasticiens, Klunder preferred the kind of abstract symbolism generated by the Painters 11, and was influenced by David Bolduc. Creating images of energy and motion, loading his canvas with colour, Klunder employed a grid-like, architecturla structure in his early work which softened during the late 1970’s as his forms became more fluid and romantic. During this time he sought to explore the spirituality of painting, a medium whose appeal he believed lay within itself, within the act of pushing paint around on canvas. This trend continued during the 1980’s when Klunder switched to oils and began to work figuratively, influenced by Graham Coughtry and Willem de Kooning. Colour rather than line became his means of expression during this period. In the Seated Figure series, his images are almost “built” out of an accumulation of paint, and he places emphasis on diagonals, creating movement throughout the work, disrupting the sense of a central focus through highly energetic brushwork.

985.14.references:
written by Martine Fournier:

Edmond Dyonnet arrived in Montreal in 1875, and after studying at the School of Arts and Crafts, he went to Italy for four years to gain further instruction under professor Gastaldi. He worked chiefly as a portrait artist in an academic style, although he also painted landscapes of Île d’Orléans, and was instrumental in founding Montreal’s École des Beaux Arts. Ste-Anne de Beaupré is an example of his landscape work, showing rolling green land dotted with cows, a road leading into scattered houses and a glowing sunset sky. A vision of countryside serenity, it invites the viewer into its folds even while its population remains unrevealed.

985.17.references:
written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Primarily a self-taught artist, Horatio Walker was drawn to Quebec when he visited here with his father in 1870. Impressed by the landscape and the people, he would eventually make a career of depicting them in paint. In 1873 he joined the Notman photographic firm, working under John A. Fraser and Robert F. Gagnon as a photo colourist. During the 1870’s he also visited Europe, where he came under the influence of Millet and the Barbizon shool of painting. By 1878 he had set up a studio in New York City, but spent his summers on Île d’Orléans in Quebec, where he eventually bought a farmhouse and settled permanently. Celebrating in his work the life of the habitant, his piety, zest for life, and days of labour, Walker nonetheless managed to avoid conveying a heavy moral message. While his early works use a dark palette resembling that of the Barbizon school, his later images are lighter and fresher in tone, as in the little study of Alice, a small portrait head whose jewel like tones and softened outlines reflect the gentleness and brightness of youth.

written by Martine Fournier:

Arthur Lismer received his academic training at Sheffield School of Art (1898 1905) and at the Académie des Beaux Arts in Antwerp. Upon arriving in Canada in 1911, Lismer worked as a grpahic artist in Toronto, where he met A. Y. Jackson, awren Harris, Tom Thomson, and J. E. H. MacDonald, those who would form the Group of Seven with Lismer and other artists in 1920. Most well-known for his landscapes and his membership in the Group, Lismer was also a pioneer in the field of art education, setting up programs, particularly for children, across the country.
    Lismer’s early work consisted of watercolours in the style of John Constable. By 1914 he had begun to paint landscapes in oil, and was moving into a period of “Neo-Impressionism” in which emphasis was placed on form, space, and volume.  This focus would evolve into the stylized, simplified forms that were the signature of the Group of Seven artists. During the 1940’s he would become interested in the graphic role of line, and by the 1950’s was experimenting with abstraction and lyrical drawing. Peggy’s Cove was probably done during the 1940’s, w period when Lismer frequently spent his summers in Nova Scotia. A dynamic landscape done in sombre colours and simplified style, it reveals a basic tension in the relationship between the forces of water and shore, as Lismer’s brushstrokes physically push them up againt each other.

986.01.title: Hyde Park, London
986.01.subject: figures in a park, 2 seated figures foreground, several strolling figures middlground, expanse of sky background, Greek Temple, left side
986.01.credit: Gift of/don du Dr. Max Stern
986.01.source: Gift of Max Stern / don de Max Stern, 1986
986.01.references:
written by Martine Fournier for the “Concordia Collects” exhibition: 

Considered one of Canada’s great watercolour painters, Frederick Marlett Bell Smith Studied at South Kensington Art Schools, London, and Académie Colarossi, Paris, before immigrating from England in 1866. He became a member of the Society of Canadian artists in 1867, and was a founding member of the Ontario Society of Artists in 1872. While he painted both in Canada and England, including landscape, marine subjects, street scenes, and portraits, he is most well-known for his fascination with atmospheric effects, particularly those of the mountainous Canadian West. Hyde Park, London is an oil study of the park and its patrons. While atmosphere is not Bell-Smith’s chief concern in this work, he does attempt to capture the effects of light in the scene, a common preoccupation in late nineteenth-century European painting.

986.02.title: Sur l'eau (?) Two figures in a boat (?)
986.02.subject: -two figures in a canoe on a lake. -bckgrd: shoreline with trees, sky, birds.
986.02.credit: Gift of/don du Dr. Max Stern
986.02.source: Gift of Dr. Max Stern / don de Dr Max Stern, 1986

986.03.title: Spring Time
986.03.keywords: Group of Seven-Associated, Canadian Group of Painters-Original member, Landscape-Canadian Group of Painters, Woodland Scenes
986.03.subject: landscape broken tree trunk foreground; forest of trees middle and background
986.03.credit: Gift of/don du Dr. Max Stern
986.03.source: Gift of Max Stern / don de Max Stern, 1986
986.03.references:
Born in Victoria in 1871, Emily Carr worked almost exclusively in B.C. and is best known for her images of the communities and carvings of the First Nations peoples, and her expressive landscapes and forest interiors.
-Included in the exhibition “Robert Ayre: The Critic and the Collection,” Concordia Art Gallery, Concordia University, 1992


Emily Carr est née à Victoria (Colombie-Britannique) en 1871. Après des études au San Francisco School of Art (1889-1894), elle part pour l’Angleterre et poursuit sa formation de peintre au Westminster School of Art. De retour au pays en 1905, elle passera les cinq années suivantes à faire des excursions dans des villages indiens de la côte ouest. Consciente de la disparition imminente de ces cultures, Carr s’efforce d’en faire un “relevé artistique”, transposant sur ses toiles et ses dessins leurs habitations et leurs scultpures totémiques, notamment. Après un séjour à Paris en 1911, où elle expose deux oeuvres au Salon d’Automne, elle doit mettre de côté sa production pour gagner sa vie. Elle ne reprendra ses pinceaux que quinze années plus tard, après une rencontre marquante avec le Groupe des Sept en Ontario. Elle passera ses dernières années à peindre, dessiner et écrire, au gré de ses excursions à travers la région de Vancouver. Elle meurt à Victoria en 1945.

Emily Carr est l’une des artistes canadiennes les plus importantes de notre siècle. Si on ne l’a reconnue que tardivement, il n’en reste pas moins qu’elle aura développé un style personnel au gré de ses recherches formelles constantes. Malgré un cheminement artistique difficile et son isolement - en tant que femme indépendante et en tant que peintre moderne - elle ne s’est jamais pliée aux exigences de son milieu. Emily Carr a ouvert les portes de l’art à l’ouest canadien.

A peine sortie des écoles, les premières oeuvres d’Emily Carr sont des aquarelles à sujets indiens. Exécutées avec un souci de réalisme, elles se veulent plus “documentaires” qu’artistiques. Sa rencontre avec les peintres du Groupe des Sept, en 1928, sera une véritable révélation. Jusqu’alors isolée dans son coin de pays, voilà qu’elle fait la connaissance d’artistes intéressés par les techniques modernes et des sujets canadiens, comme elle. Sous leurs conseils, elle abandonne les sujets indiens pour ne se consacrer qu’au paysage, les forêts de l’ouest en particulier. Avec sa vision symboliste et romantique de la nature, Carr cherchera dorénavant à traduire la vitalité et la force qu’elle lui inspire, ceci étant ce qu’elle considère la manifestation divine.

Elle abandonne l’aquarelle pour l’huile sur papier, qui lui permet la même mobilité, mais une plus grande variété d’exécution.

De fait, les oeuvres des années trente sont à mi-chemin entre le fauvisme et l’abstraction géométrique: elle travaille la composition, les relations des formes dans l’espace et la touche rythmique.

Le dessin au charbon sera aussi une part importante de sa production: il servira souvent de base pour des oeuvres produites en studio. Là aussi, on retrouve les mêmes préoccupations pour le rythme et l’espace.

Etude d’un tronc d’arbre (c.1932) démontre bien cette qualité expressive des oeuvres de l’artiste. Travaillant les jeux d’ombre et de lumière, la forme du tronc se réduit à une masse lisse dont elle ne retient  que les contours. D’un geste rapide, elle transforme les branches en des lignes sinueuses qui donnent à l’ensemble un équilibre et une fluidité dans les mouvements ainsi crées. On sent ici toute la force de l’arbre: solide, massif et plein; habité de cette “présence divine”.

Ses oeuvres des années trente annoncent en fait celles de sa période de maturité, de la fin de cette décennie. Alors complètement détachée de tout mouvement artistique - ou toute influence extérieure - Emily Carr a enfin trouvé sa voix et atteint une liberté d’expression sans précédent. Spring Time (1938-1939) en est un bon exemple. Schématisant les formes jusqu’aux limites de l’abstraction, sa palette claire  et sa touche vibrante ne sont pas sans rappeler Van Gogh, qu’elle admirait d’entre tous. L’oeuvre est habitée d’un flux d’énergie continuel, où le regard circule sans cesse. Carr équilibre la surface au moyen de la touche, qui détermine seule la forme des arbres.

written by Martine Fournier for “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Known for her paintings and drawings of First Nations communities, totems, and landscapes in her native British Columbia, Emily Carr first studied at the San Francisco School of Art (1889-1894), and then at the Westminster School of Art in England, returning to Canada in 1905. Believing that the First Nations cultures were doomed to extinction, she sought to capture their way of life, as well as the landscape and forest interior around her, in watercolour and oil paintings. During the 1920’s she became involved with the Group of Seven, and was encouraged by Lawren Harris to focus only on the landscape itself, exploring what she perceived as the underlying unity and spirituality of nature. As she did this, she changed her method from working up watercolours done in the field as oil paintings in the studio, to painting with oil directly on paper with her subjects right in front of her. This resulted in a freshness of colour and fluid stroke that marks the period of her maturity, which occurred during the 1930’s. Spring Time shows fully the results of this new process, exemplifying the lightness and freshness of her later work, as well as the influence of Vincent Van Gogh evidenced by her use of brush stroke to create movement throughout the entire landscape.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

 Chiefly a painter of landscape, seascape, still life and portraits, Stanley Cosgrove studied at the Montreal École des Beaux Arts, and under Edwin Holgate at the Art Association of Montreal. From 1940 to 1943 he traveled to Mexico, where he studied fresco under Jose Clemente Orozco. Preferring not to belong to any particular artistic group or movement, Cosgrove worked independently, concerning himself with formal aspects rather than the subject matter of painting. Reclining Nude was painted during the height of his career, and reveals the influence of artists such as Henri Matisse and George Bracque. Through its depth of colour and sense of transparency, it also demonstrates the importance of his fresco studies in determining his painting style.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Lawren Harris is most famous for his membership in the Group of Seven, a school of painters based in Toronto during the 1920’s. Harris and the Group sought to redirect the focus of Modern art in Canada toward a vision of rugged landscape as representative of the Canadian identity. Influenced by the work of Scandinavian landscape painters, they adopted a stylized, simplified style, and focused their attention on the landscape around Lake Superior and Northern Ontario. Harris’s Lake Superior canvases, from about 1921 on, are different from his earlier work in that he evolved in them a more sculptural sense of land, simplifying colour and paring down details, as is evident in Lake North of Lake Superior. Inspired by the writings of Emerson and Thoreau, harris sought to explore Theosophy in his painting, or the idea of humanity becoming one with nature, and he looked to the wilderness for a sense of spirituality and order, developed in his serene, highly- organized paintings.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects”  exhibition:

Educated at McGill University from 1905-7, John Lyman also studied at the Royal College of Art, South Kensington, and with Marcel Beronneau, at the Académie Julien, and at the Académie Henri Matisse in Paris. Living in France until 1930, Lyman brought a sense of internationalism to the Canadian art scene when he arrived here. His French-inspired Post-Impressionist style involved a strong interest in form, and he rejected the nationalistic approaches to art prevailing in Canada during the 1920’s and 30’s, saying, “I live by my eyes.”
    Lyman’s early works reflect the influence of Matisse, but by the 1920’s he had reached maturity, focusing on composition, enclosing forms with dark outlines, and experimenting with deep contrast between light and shadow. While critics accused his work of lacking passion, many of his scenes of every day life reveal a sense of isolation and somber mood, heightened by his use of dramatic lighting. The Blue Lagoon, St. Vincent is a late work, done during a period of renewed freedom when Lyman traveled to Cape Cod and the Caribbean, capturing here a peaceful, unpopulated landscape.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Although Jean-Paul Riopelle is most famous for his association with Borduas and les Automatistes, his work as an abstract painter evolved through several styles. During the late 1940’s his painting could be classisied as “tachiste”, composed of wild energetic brushstrokes of colour. During the early fifties he also experimented with a kind of controlled drip with which he also drizzled colour onto his paintings. By the middle of the decade he had begun painting with his palette knife, which resulted in vibrant compositions of rectangular strokes resembling shards of broken colour, signature images for which he is now well-known. Though Riopelle was closely aligned with Paul-Émile Borduas, Riopelle had always gone to nature for artistic inspiration, and as his work in the late fifties leaned more and more toward figuration based on marine plant life, he and Borduas, whose work was becoming more formal and reductive, parted ways. Ici, La Bas of 1957 is a “classic” Riopelle painting, from the period of the palette knife works in which his canvases shimmered with his attempts to capture effects of light and colour.

written by Maritne Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

 Having studied in Montreal the the École des Beaux Arts from 1937 to 1939, Jacques de Tonnancour worked in Rio de Janeiro from 1945-6 on a scholarship from the Brazilian Government. He began his career as a figurative painter, depicting people and the Laurentian landscape, but moved into abstraction as he began use subjects like insects and magnified views of tree branches to create shapes on canvas, eventually co-authoring an anti-Automatiste manifesto with Alfred Pellan. Jeune femme assise is an early work, a study of a seated woman whose form is reduced to simple geometric shapes and planes, revealing the influence of artists such as Henri Matisse and Pablo Picasso.

Catalogue to an exhibition held at McMichael Canadian Art Collection from June 28 - September 13, 1992. "In addition to her work as an artist/photographer, Angela Grauerholz is also a graphic designer, a teacher at UQAM, and a founding member of Artexte (a non-profit documentation centre for contemporary visual arts) in Montreal. Her photography is characterized by its dark, gentle tones, skewed perspectives, and use of long exposures to create a soft-focus image. Through her techniques, Grauerholz makes the presence of the artist a visible, conscious part of the work and denies the purely mimetic aspect of photography. Her subject matter, usually presented as a series of works, includes public and private spaces, portraits and clouds." (p 17)

986.19.title: Moon
986.19.subject: landscape with moon
986.19.references:
written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Angela Grauerholz uses photography and installation to explore the ways in which presentation and understanding affect the significance of the cultural object. To this end she has presented archival photographs, photographs hanging in a rack system used for storing and displaying large photos in plexiglass, and has used text samples of “dead” languages of lost civilizations in her work to show that once deprived of meaning by the viewer’s inability to understand them, they become mere decorative material for an artist’s use. Often she will present the mundane photographically using long exposures to create a soft focus and a haziness, so that an everyday scene becomes a vehicle for examining the processes of image, memory, history, collection, and sight itself. In Moon a similar effect is achieved through shadow and darkness, which create an almost impenetrable atmosphere of mystery. Here, the moon is the single point of brightness in a dark scene, and reveals only hints of a brick wall and a tree branch with its light. Focusing on this unyielding darkness, Grauerholz can question the very capabilities of sight and the reliability of photographic veracity.

986.21.title: No Excuses - No Apologies
986.21.subject: figurative elements: hands, heads, filing cabinet, glasses; central area occupied by large head, hands at bottom, female head at left, filing cabinet at right
986.21.references:
written by Martine Fournier:

David Craven’s paintings, collages, and drawings have long been recognized as intensely personal, difficult works that simultaneously explore both the surface of painting, and its deepest emotional content. While his interest in the procedure of painting itself, evidenced by the gestural nature of his work, has always been obvious, his early production centred on an abstract expressionism in which no particular subject came forward. Only later on did he begin to work more figuratively, using the human face as a kind of gargoyle or mask-like image of the grotesque, and incorporating images of technology and male, power-oriented objects as symbols of the ills of modern society. 
    No Excuses - No Apologies is a work in which Craven addresses these issues using anguished faces, a pair of hands, and a pair of thick-rimmed men’s glasses, suggesting the theme of power versus helplessness that recurs so often in his work. The stark, black and white, line-oriented collage, with its cruciform shape, comments on a generalized societal anguish while also targeting a specifically modern, office-oriented, urbanized lifestyle.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Though she was an artist herself, and studied with Joseph Saint-Charles at Monument National in Montreal (1916-17) and later with André Lhote in France, Agnès Lefort was most famous for her gallery on Sherbrooke Street, which she ran from 1950-61. Lefort’s own artwork, influenced by post-cubism, was not well received in Montreal during the 1930’s and 40’s, as the city was then reluctant to embrace Modern art trends. Lefort opened her gallery in order to support young artist working in new styles, regardless of what medium they used or to what group they belonged, and was responsible for nurturing not only these avant-garde artists, but the growth of Modern art itself within the city. Lefort focused on displaying Canadian and chiefly Québécois work, particularly the work of female artists, as well as bringing the latest European trends in to be seen by Montrealers. Nature Morte au Poisson Rouge is a playful still life reflecting Lefort’s interest in post-cubism and the work of Les Plasticiens. In an energetic juxtpaposition of colours, shapes, and patterns, it recalls most vividly the collage technique of early cubism.

written by Martine Fournier:

Philip Surrey was apprenticed at Bridgen’s engraving as a young man, then studied at Winnipeg School of Art and under Fred Varley in 1929 at the Vancouver School of Art.  During the 1930’s he traveled to New York City where he studied at the Art Students’ League, and in 1937 moved to Montreal. This city would become his favoured subject as he used its streets, taverns, and cafés as images of the Modern city. While maintaining traditional painting concerns in his work, the influence of abstraction is evident in his simplified, geometric forms. A lover of dramatic lighting, he preferred depicting early morning and nighttime scenes, as in Decarie Boulevard. Painted in dark, sombre colours, this work depicts a bleak, nocturnal industrial scene, in which a lone person walkign toward the viewer seems to represent urban loneliness and anonymity. At the same time, it is a highly complicated study in composition as the lines created by street lamps, cranes, tire tracks, and fencing function also on an abstract level.

written by Martine Fournier:

After studying under Anne Savage at Baron Byng High School in Montreal, and Alexandre Bercovitch at the Montreal Museum School of Fine Arts and Design from 1935-42, Moe Reinblatt joined the RCAF and was appointed a War Artist in 1944. Using both thickly and thinly applied paint and a variety of mark-making techniques, Reinblatt sought in his landscapes and portraits to convey strong emotional content and mood, preferring stark winter landscapes scenes which he painted around the Laurentians and on Mont Royal. Also an explorer of high-key, Impressionistic colour, Reinblatt could be said to have combined European Expressionism with British landscape techniques. Although he is associated with a group of Montreal Jewish painters active from the 1930’s to the 1950’s, he developed a personal style and avoided becoming a part of any particular school of painting. Profile of Joey is a close-up portrait revealing part of the neck and head of the sitter, and exemplifies Reinblatt’s ability to create mood through colour, in this case with sombre tones of brown and beige.

987.25.references:
written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

The young painter Pierre Gauvreau grew up in Montreal, associated with Borduas and Les Automatistes, and was one of those who signed the famous Refus global. Barred from finishing high school because he owned works such as Beaudelaire’s Les fleurs du mal and poetry by Rimbaud that had been censored by the Church, Gauvreau was a prime candidate for Borduas’ style of rebellion. Influenced early on by the work of Matisse, Picasso, and Braque that he had seen in Life Magazine, Gauvreau later saw works by these and other European artists in person when he joined the army and went to Europe from 1943-6. Gauvreau consistently contrasts calligraphic drawing with broad strokes of colour, depicting mysterious, suggestive shapes that float against a shifting background space. Early works such as Untitled of 1948 tended to be muddy, perhaps because of Gauvreau’s difficulty in keeping his colours clear with the tendency of oil paints to bleed into one another, and small, due to financial constraints. Painting until the early 1960’s, Gauvreau then switched to a television career, only coming back to his artwork during the late seventies. By this time, the availability of acrylic paint seems to have influenced his ability to keep clear boundaries between fresh, bright colours, while maintaining his earlier interest in playing with ambiguous biomorphic forms.

987.26.title: Untitled/sans titre
987.26.subject: "brushy" multi-coloured organic motifs applied in repetitive manner over entire surface
987.26.references:
written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Fernand Toupin studied under Jean-Paul Jérôme and Stanley Cosgrove at the Montreal École des Beaux Arts. His painting has evolved through a series of abstract techniques, yet has always been nased on nature, such that one senses the presence of earth, crevices, ocean, or lava in most of his work. By the late 1970’s Toupin was painting vague forms that emerged from the centre of his canvases, often built up with so much paint that they took on a sculptural quality.  This relatively early untitled work conveys nature as well, resembling clouds or blossoming trees in its white puffs painted over a coloured ground. The same sense of layered space is created as well, except that here a feeling of colour covered over by white dominates, as opposed to an emergence of colour from a white ground as it occurs in later works.

987.30.references:
Born in Moncton, New Brunswick in 1953, Raymonde April studied fine art at the Cegep de Riviere-du-Loup (Quebec), then at Universite Laval (Quebec). She is a co-founder of the gallery La Chambre Blanche, an artist-run centre dedicated to the expression of new voices and current art practices. Since 1983 she has taught photography in the Visual Arts Department at Ottawa University, as well as in the Studio Department, Faculty of Fine Arts at Concordia University. As realist sets for fictional events, Raymonde April's photography broadens the perameters of the aesthetics of seduction: her subjects are not what they at first glance appear to be. While the artist or her friends and family may take the place of photographic subject, the images as discrete objects divulges no biographical information that can be used as their documents. Instead, these individuals are transformed into formal elements who function much like light, objects and text. With the exception of widely known people and places, the main components play fictional parts. As actors, her friends and family alike usher the viewer into the theatricality of the mundane, bringing us into private spaces made public via her photographic eye. Through this paradoxical synthesis of differently invested emotional sites, the strategic ambiguity which functions as the subtext to Raymond April's work emerges.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

987.37.title: Shadow Form and Kouros
987.37.subject: human figure, schematized, standing, on horizontal "base" - footprints project from base to face figure.
987.37.credit: Purchased with a Canada Council Special Purchase Assistance Grant/acquis avec l'aide d'une subvention du Conseil des Arts du Canada
987.37.source: Purchase- Special Purchase Assistance Grant, Canada Council for the Arts / achat- Subvention spéciale d'aide aux acquisitions, Conseil des Arts du Canada, 1987
987.37.references:
written by Martine Fournier:

David Moore received his BA in 1964 from the University of Dublin, following which he came to Montreal to study at the École des Beaux Arts, where he earned a BA in Fine Arts with a major in printmaking in 1970. In 1972 he received his diploma in art education from l’Université de Québec à Montréal, and in 1978 his MFA from Concordia University. His sculpture and installation work has evolved from the combined use of found and constructed objects in a personal exploration of notions of identity, history, and time, to a particular interest in ancient ruins and the combination of human and animal form. Moore’s work of the late 1980’s is based on his stay in Crete from 1983-5, during which time he also visited Egypt and Turkey. Facsinated by ancient technology and architecture, he began to work with forms such as the pyramid, taken by their overwhelming simplicity. Basing his sculptures on these architectural forms, he at first reworked them on a small scale until they were virtually deviod of reference, but then went back to larger works and using anthropomorphic forms to examine the relationship between self and other.
    Shadow Form and Kouros is such an examination. The simplified form of the man is based on sixth century BC sculptures of the youthful athletic male, and the shadow form is implied by a set of footprints facing the Kouros. Working with wood because it demands consideration of its own warps and markings, its own history, Moore looks at a larger historical context while continuing his investigations into the self/other dichotomy.

987.39.title: Decoy Homes (The Moon)
987.39.subject: abstracted urban landscape
987.39.credit: Purchased in 1987 with The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment; Presented in Honour of the Members of the Rector's Circle, 2004 / Acquis en 1987 grâce au Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'acquisition d'œuvres d'art; présenté en hommage aux membres du Cercle du Recteur, 2004
987.39.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowement, in honour of Members of the Rector's Circle / achat grâce au Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l’achat d’œuvres d’art; présenté en hommage aux membres du Cercle de Recteur, 2004
987.39.references: "Kim Adams was born in Edmonton in 1951. Since 1981 he has had solo exhibitions in Toronto and in Montreal in 1987. He recently participated in the San Paolo Biennale and several group shows in western Canada including Locations/National (Victoria, 1983), Dislocation (Banff 1985) and in Ontario, The Interpretation of Architecture (Toronto 1986) and Passage (Burlington, 1987)." From "Contemporary Canadian Works on Paper", Concordia Art Gallery, 1988. Since 1988 Kim Adams has had a major exhibition at the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal. The gallery owns a study (drawing) for a series of sculptural works titled Decoy Homes. From the Winnipeg Art Gallery catalogue accompanying their Kim Adams show, Andy Patton has the following to say about the "Decoy Homes" and "The Moon" : "Decoy Homes is a housing project. More exactly, it proposes to use pre-fabricated metal garden sheds as housing. When the entire project is finished, other assembled stacks of sheds will accompany this current one. Adams' original idea was that each unit would be complete with floors, lighting, plumbing, hot water, etc.: all the amenities necessary to make these into workable housing. But somewhere along the line, the work changed course from that original concept, and now what is presented is simply the shell of what could become housing. As it stands now the project is not housing; but it does not simply represent it - since, with work, the sheds could be used as a minimal form of shelter. So the work does not function in the way of a series of drawings "about" housing might. It is more than representational. But it is less than actual. It's worth looking into the title. To call this work a "decoy" suggests a falseness to what the work seems to offer. If a carved and painted wooden decoy of a duck is designed to deliver wild ducks to the hunter, then perhaps Decoy Homes lures us into the gallery with the promise of being actually useful. It lures us into the institution we know as "art". ... within which acts and objects come to be seen as autonomous, as existing for themselves, outside of any practical effects. In that light, we can see for a moment what an ambiguous position Decoy Homes occupies. On the one hand it both represents and begins to construct inexpensive and minimal housing, in response to the concrete situation of the city where the artist lives. ... On the other hand the work acknowledges through the title that even if it could function as housing, as art it is necessarily seen as being outside concrete usefulness. It cannot be used as housing and seen as an artwork at the same time, because of the historical and social position which artworks have come to occupy for us. But what Decoy Homes does allow is a glimpse of the positioning of artworks and at its own position in the complicity of things, by emphasizing both concrete usefulness, and at the same time, its own existence as a decoy. All of which radically alters the idea of the work really being a decoy - since a decoy can only work by convincing us of its truth. In suggesting that, in part, a decoy, as housing which is false, it is plausible to see this work as an attempt to go beyond the social and historical position of art as object without effect - but not abstractly, as though artworks were not socially restrained by a history; and without surrendering that distance between art and life which allows artworks the possibility to seeing and comment on the larger social world. ... [The Moon] : Inside the bucket-shaped lamp, flourescent tubes shine through sheets of plexiglass, casting a cool white glow over the pressed-metal fake-woodgrain garden sheds, replacing the moon. The moon and its ambient light are gone; now they are not simply represented within the work, but replaced by a working technical system. Even then, this is done by means not just of light, but of light which is already a sign - the lamp mimics the "bucket of chicken" sign which advertises Kentucky Fried Chicken, that simulated regional cooking. Captured lighting bearing the promise of fulfilment through appetite." (Pages 19, 21, from the article "Trousers on Head", by Andy Patton) The drawing in the gallery's collection is a study for the previously discussed series.

987.41.title: Mount Royal #32
987.41.subject: view of atmospheric landscape seen through row of thin tree trunks in sharp focus at foreground
987.41.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1987
987.41.references:
"As a landscape photographer, I have come to think of the land as being an enormous historical archive. I am interested in revealing the narratives contained within the landscape, especially those places where the land reveals itself as being both an agent of change and the field of human endeavour." (artist's statement in the American Artist, vol. 10, Spring 1996, p 36-7) 1987/10/28-12/5 "Mark Ruwedel; Photographs," Gallery II. From a text written for the exhibition at Gallery II: "The photographs of the American photographer Mark Ruwedel (b. 1954), now living in Montreal reflect the unusual relationship of nature and the city that marks Montreal. Images of Mount Royal and its cemetary reinforce the psychological presence of the mountain (and nature) in the daily life of Montreal. The mountain's mythical presence and the cold reality of its physical condition meld as a symbol of the city's collective past and its ambiguous future." Also available in the artist's file, "Artist Pages: The Land as Historical Archive" from American Art, Volume 10, Spring 1996. p 36-41; Mark Ruwedel, COLUMBIA RIVER: THE HARTFORD STRETCH (1993), a collaborative project with the US Department of Energy.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

987.46.references: "The trio of artists - A.A. Bronson, Jorge Zontal and Felix Partz - banded together under the name General Idea in 1968. Working as a collective in multimedia work allowed them to better assume the role of "cultural investigators" who mimicked the tactics of the mass media and appropriated a multitude of cultural vehicles. The scope of their activity and their commmitment to ambiguity resist classification. At the outset the prevelant framework of these activities was the 1984 Miss General Idea Pavillion, an open-ended, easily manipulated concept within which works were realized. ... Any attempt, however, to correlate precisely image and text is fruitless. Rather, the viewer is exposed to a multiplicity of meanings and their ironical and paradoxical intent." (Art Gallery of Ontario: Selected Works, 1990) "Les artistes dont le pseudonymes AA Bronson, Felix Partz et Jorge Zontal sont reunis sous le vocable de General Idea oeuvrent ensemble depuis 1968 autour de preoccupations illusoires comme les concours de beaute, les parades de mode et le kitsch urbain de la culture nord-americaine. Elabore des le debut des annees 70, lw\eur plus grand projet consiste a planifier et a construirele pavillon de Miss General Idea, une sorte de faux mythe base sur le roman de science fiction 1984, de George Orwell, veritable critique narrative de la societe. Le triofait l'eloge de tout qui est precieux et glamour autourde l'election repetitive de Miss General Idea. La parodie a pris des proportions telles qu'elle est devenue le propos de leur recherches, et ils la vivent jusqu'a l'absurde en s'y jetant corps et ame. ... exploite le theme du caniche, mascotte qui apparait dans plusieurs murales du pavillon de Miss General Idea 1984. L'image du chien, animal sociale, ... ironise a la fois ... l'univers de l'art et ... la vision collective du monde. ... Le groupe trafique le reel par la metaphore et se joue ainsi de l'ambiguite. Sous le couvert de l'humour et du sarcasme, cette recherchefarfelue est parfois seduisant. Elle amene le spectateur, a travers l'exploration du theme canin, a voir la proposition utopique d'une forme derisoire du systeme de l'art. La structure de leur oeuvre comporte un double jeu : celui de creer une idole a l'image de leur propre mythologie et d'y decouvrir le paradoxe qui decoule de ce langage difficilement penetrable, une forme d'appropriation a partir de strategies manipulant divers aspects du domaine de la culture." (Pierre Granche. La collection : tableau inaugurale, Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal, 1992)

988.05.references:
"The Quebec artist Alain Paiement, whose first exhibition was held in Montreal in the early 1980s, takes up a ... complicated position with regard to ... the binary opposition upon which the "break" ... from Modernism to Postmodernism is drawn. Concerned with various systems of mapping, including those employed by scientific disciplines such as meteorology and geography, his work is more closely alignd with conceptual art, the "undertow" of the Modern/Postmodern debate. His work shares with conceptual art an interest in systems of signification - the way in which meanings are (re)produced rather than naturally given, including those of art itself. Yet, while sharing conceptual art's self-referential interests, Paiement's work distances itself from conceptualism's more recent emphasis on the semiotic critique of representation by means of photo-montage and textual components. Rather, it seeks to address, in specifically visual terms, systems of visual transcription, including topography. Utilizing a wide variety of media (drawing, painting, photography, sculpture, installation, and even architecture), his work cannot be reduced to either a Modernist or a Postmodernist position. Instead, it takes an analytic stance toward the "break" between the two by examining systems of "topographic" mapping. (Topography, derived from the Greek terms topos - place - andgraphien - writing - refers to the transcription of a surface or three-dimensional reality - place or site - onto a two-dimensional plane.)" (p 3-4, from the catalogue/exhibition Alain Paiement: Amphitheatres, at Power Plant, 10 March - 23 April, 1989. Essay by Barbara Fischer) The complete catalogue essay can be found in the artist's file.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

After studying at the Conseil des Arts et Manufactures, and under William Brymner at the Art Association of Montreal from 1905-1912, Emily Coonan undertook a career as a painter of landscape and figurative works, and was associated with the Beaver Hall group of Montreal. Her choice of subject matter reveals an interest in intimate, everyday moments, and she worked chiefly with portraiture, populated interiors, and children, though without the sentimentality typically expected of female painters of the time. Although she was the first woman ever to exhibit with the Group of Seven, she stayed away from the tendency toward stylization and heavy line that defined their view of the Canadian landscape, preferring softer outlines and more subtle tones of colour. She traveled to Europe with Henrietta Mabel May in 1912, and again to France and Italy from 1920 21on a traveling scholarship from the National Gallery. It was during this 1920 trip to Italy that she painted Untitled (Santa Maria Formosa), a work that reveals her preference for unobvious subjects and quiet, reflective mood.
