988.08.references:
From the 1992 permanent collection catalogue of the Musee d'art contemporain, Pierre Granche describes Rita Letendre as follows: "En interrogeant sans cesse la sensation pure et la matiere coloree, l'oeuvre de Rita Letendre se trouve a la croisee des chemins entre une peintre abstraite montrealaise et une acceptation geometruque, a la recherche d'un mode personnel d'expression. Il est peu d'examples durant les annees 50 d'une volonte aussi determinee chez une femme artiste dont le discours questionne une approche plus structuree et rationnelle de la peinture, ce qui la distingue de la premiere generation des automatistes." From the 1988 application for certification of cultural property, Sandra Paikowsky described this work as follows: "Abstract painting on paper in black, blue, ochre and white pigment. Gestural application of gouache with centralized rising forms. ... This work represents the period when Letendre moved from an automatiste vocabulary towards a geometric handiling of form. The looser rendering of form suggests the influence of abstract expressionism which effected Montreal art at the beginning of the 1960s. It also represents a movement away from the "tachiste: application of paint found in Montreal art of the 1950s. ... Because the work reflects a seminal point in the development of her painting the work has both major art historical and aesthetic significance."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.71-74
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, p.342
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, p.291

988.09.title: Siamese Twins
988.09.subject: large industrial structure
988.09.credit: Purchased with a Canada Council Special Purchase Assistance Grant/acquis avec l'aide d'une subvention du Conseil des Arts du Canada
988.09.source: Purchase- Special Purchase Assistance Grant, Canada Council for the Arts / achat- Subvention spéciale d'aide aux acquisitions, Conseil des Arts du Canada, 1988
988.09.references:
written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Medrie MacPhee received her BFA from the Nova Scotia School of Art and Design in Halifax in 1976, and then attended the Cooper Union School of Art in New York. In her surreal depictions of the industrial and mechanical world one can trace the influence of artists such as de Chirico and Hopper. Exploring the relationship between biological and mechanical, interior and exterior, MacPhee’s buildings seem to take on faces, her pipes to grow out of control like concrete jungle vines. During the 1980’s she sought to separate herself from the Precisionists as her work became more personal, and her structures began to take on personalities of their own. By the end of the decade she had also devised a method of stitching extra pieces of canvas onto her works wherever she needed them in order to expand her ideas and extend her space, adopting a process of building images that echoes the architecture within them. Siamese Twins was done during this period, employing a sense of contrast between colour and deep shadow reminiscent of comic book illustration. The relationship of society to industry, body to body, is explored in this image of pipes against a building, doubled by their shadows.

989.02.title: Of a Place, Solitary
989.02.keywords: Figuration-body as site, Photography-montage, Diptych-single frame
989.02.subject: figurative photographic dyptich, Reference to concentration camp victims (etched numerals);/crucifixion (outstretched arm), right photograph: outstretched female arm against black background, left photograph: series of number etched in glass layering closeup of the arm and producing second ghost image of numerals view-cast shadow
989.02.credit: Purchased with a Canada Council Special Purchase Assistance Grant/acquis avec l'aide d'une subvention du Conseil des Arts du Canada
989.02.source: Purchase - Special Purchase Assistance Program, Canada Council Art Bank / achat- Subvention spéciale d'aide à l'acquisition, La Banque d'oeuvres d'art du Conseil des Arts du Canada - 1989
989.02.references:
Barbara Steinman is a Montreal-based artist whose work has been exhibited widely, including the National Gallery of Canada and the Museum of Modern Art in New York City. Her work is installation-based, and brings together photography, video and sculpture. As monuments to the anonymous, disenfranchised individual, it stakes a claim to the nuance, and implicitly denounces the continued existence of at least two versions of historical events: the official version, which purports to represent the collective, and the individual, or the personal - in other words, the authorized and unauthorized versions. By questioning these mechanisms of history, she assumes a political position. In order to achieve her political objective, Steinman privileges the study of language, mediated by image, word and sign. Once recuperated by the present, historical information can be brought to the light of day, where its hidden manipulations and power investments are revealed. The work "Of a Place, Solitary" (1989), is representative of her concerns with fixing the personalized, historical moment. Often exhibited in conjunction with sound/sculpture installation, "Of a Sound, Mute." A dyptich, the two panels consist of an engraved glass plate and a black and white photograph of an arm outstretched in a crucifixion pose, mounted on masonite. (the model for this work was Reesa Greenberg) The work presents the audience with a series of relationships between the unprotected photograph on the wall and the glass cover mounted beside it, and between the sculptural dimension presented by the numbers etched into the glass and their attendant cast shadow on the supporting wall, and the two-dimensional image of the outstretched arm. The raw photograph, uncovered by the glass, seems vulnerable in the gallery context. But if the transposition of the glass necessary to protect the work occurred, a new set of tension would be created. The etched numbers on the glass would be read as part of the arm, a clear reference to one of the most common symbols of the Nazi holocaust. The austere beauty and subtlety of Barbara Steinman's technique attenuates the forcefullness of these symbols, thus allowing the audience to sidestep proscribed interpretations, and come away with individual, personal readings of collective historical events. (SOURCES: Richmond, Cindy and Barbara London. Barbara Steinman: Uncertain Monuments. An exhibition organized by the Mackenzie Art Gallery, and held from April 24 to August 2, 1992. Touring to the Windsor Art Gallery from November 27, 1993 to January 24, 1994; Manon Blanchette from La collection: Tableau inaugural, a catalogue of the permanent collection of the Musee d'art contemporain, published on the occasion of an exhibition held from May 28, 1992; Greenberg, Reesa. Barbara Steinman: A Lapse in Logic. Catalogue for an exhibition held by the Art Gallery of Windsor, November 20, 1993 - January 9, 1994. Curated by Vincent J. Varga
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See Jessica Bradley and Lesley Johnstone, eds., “Sightlines,” 1994, p.71

written by Martine Fournier:

After studying from 1938 to 1943 at the Montreal École des Beaux Arts, Fernand Leduc began a career in which he experimented many different forms of abstract painting, alwats concerned with the exploration of light. While drawing inspiration from the Montreal art scene, he also spent long periods in France, obviously absorbing the work of the Impressionists, whose influence is revealed in his use of layered colours to create various effects of light. During the 1940’s he became involved with Borduas, contributing an essay to the Refus global of the Automatistes, and painting in the automatic style of attempting to allow the inconscious ming control the brush. During the 1950’s he aligned himself more closely with Les Plasticiens, and became concerned with a more conscioulsy ordered kind of abstraction, which in turn ewvolved into softer shapes and colours. Eventually he was working in a monochromatic style and examining the effects of ery faint variations in colour. Île de Ré is a fairly early work, a juxtaposition of horizintals and verticals, including tiny diagonal strokes, typical of the Automatiste style. Leduc’s interest in light is evident in his layering of primary colours, contrasted with the use of black and white, allowing glimmers of light to appear within the canvas.

989.05.title: Des bleus
989.05.subject: non-objective, geometric abstraction
989.05.source: Gift of Guy Robert, 1989 / Don de Guy Robert, 1989
989.05.references:
written by Martine Fournier:

After studying under Alfred Pellan at the Montreal École des Beaux Arts from 1943-49, Denis Juneau traveled to Italy to study with Nino di Salvatore at the Centro Studi Arte Industria di Novara from 1954-56. Here he studies design, and became familiar with the many possibilities in combining simple geometric shapes. Upon returnig to Montreal he joined with the abstract group Les Plasticiens, and was also a well-known member of the Association of Non-Figurative Artists of Montreal. Working with geometric forms such as semi-circles and small lines, using tape and stencils to create hard-edged forms, Juneau created works that sought to project a sense of fun and a dynamic space to the viewer. Through paintings inspired by the work of abstractionists such as Mondrian, Molinari, Tousignant, and Klee, Juneau once said he was attemptng to capture the movement of the world, movement through space, even at the atomic level, the vibration of sounds, even the movement of the human heartbeat. Des Bleus is one of Juneau’s earlier explorations into the world of colour, and demonstrates his sense of fun since the work is predominantly red, yet titled in such a way as to call attention to the role of blue.

989.07.keywords: Eastern Group of Painters, Group-Contemporary Arts Society, Canadian Group of Painters, Autobiography, Figuration-portrait

989.07.references:
From the 1989 application for certification of cultural property, Sandra Paikowsky writes: [Self-Portrait (1953) is an] "Image of the artist seated in his studio in front of his easel; painted in neutral tones of green, grey, beige ... This work represents Roberts' sophisticated approach to form and content during the "middle" phase of his career. It is an exemplary reflection of Roberts' life long concern for the figure but it is also an unusual subject. The few self-portraits were produced by Roberts c. 1953-54, this "full length" being an extremely important and rare example. The heightened monumentality, new intensity of colour and greater tactility of the surface significantly describes Roberts' assurance and .. experience ..."

989.09.00.description:
Front and back covers: tan-coloured stiff cardstock, rounded lower left and right corners
29 pages
Circular metal binding along 14.7cm dimension (top)

Imprinting on front cover reads: 
The Middlesex Sketchbook
Wire-O-Bound
Fine White Drawing Paper for Pencil-Ink-Crayon-Water Color
(Graphic Design Element): Circle decorated with two-tone star shapes - seven small and one 
large - inside of which reads: Bien-fait dependable papers
Below graphic design element reads:
     501-WB
6x9            30 Sheets
  Student Grade

Front cover carries one applied label and one piece of masking tape with hand-written inventory or 
cataloguing information
989.09.00.source: Gift of the Anne Savage Estate / don de la Succession de Anne Savage, 1989

989.10.09 a-b.keywords: landscape; hills; animals; birds; architecture; village; Manitoba; Portage la Prairie; Coldwell
989.10.09 a-b.description:
43.5cm (h) x 60.6cm (w) window-matted, cream-colored board
2cm x 1cm piece of masking tape at the upper-left corner
5.5cm x .5cm masking tape at the left-hand side
Paper is peeled away at all four sides

Pencil inscription in upper-left corner on reverse of board reads:
8912-E 8912
3/4 silver alum.

3 vertical bevel-cut windows grouped in center of board. All openings 20.4cm (h); width varies – left and right = 14cm (w), and middle = 13.3cm

Each window presents 22.7cm (h) x 15.2cm (w) pages with drawings on both sides done in colored pencil, all removed from a metal ring sketchbook (#3)

All pages are attached to board with masking tape. Each has 1 piece at the top and bottom, 4 to 7cm (l) x 1.3cm (w). Left-hand page has 1 piece on its left side, and right-hand page has 1 piece on its right-hand side. Two pieces of masking tape attached conjoined sides of all three pages to each other and to board.

989.10.09a (front):
Left-hand page of three
Page carries three drawings
Upper: body of water in foreground, low hills in the background, and two birds in upper-left corner, 5cm (h) x 10cm (w)
Middle: single fir tree against a blank background, 6.5cm (h) x 3.8cm (w)
Lower: Elevated view of a group of buildings at the lower-left of a bay, pencil inscription at the lower-right reads “Coldwell”, 8cm (h) x 13cm (w)

989.10.09b (reverse):
Left-hand page of three
Page carries three drawings
Upper: Foreground shows a single building in front of a group of trees, background is a tilled field, pencil inscription at the lower-right reads “Portage La Prairie”, 7cm (h) x 12cm (w)
Middle: 4 haystacks(?) in a field, 3.3cm (h) x 7.3cm (w)
Lower: 2 telephone poles in foreground of a view of farmland, 4cm (h) x 8.5cm (w)

989.191.title: Fragment de individuelle Mythologien
989.191.credit: Purchased with a Canada Council Special Purchase Assistance Grant/acquis avec l'aide d'une subvention du Conseil des Arts du Canada
989.191.source: Purchase - Special Purchase Assistance Program, Canada Council Art Bank / achat - Subvention spéciale d'aide aux acquisitions, La Banque d'oeuvres d'art du Conseil des Arts du Canada, 1989
989.191.references:
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.188-191
-See Jessica Bradley and Lesley Johnstone, eds., “Sightlines,” 1994, p.122-123, 230, 233-237, 244
“Thirty-plus years of formal , metaphysical and even anthropological exploration are rooted in the expressive power of the gesture and trace a certain archeology of knowledge and mythology...Whittome was initially trained in drawing and printmaking in her native Vancouver, and then in Paris. Using found objects, handmade paper, string, encaustic, pigments, and so forth, she recreates a highly personal collection of enigmatic assemblages, placed under glass or display cases , hieratic, totemic sculptures arranged in friezes or on the floor, solemn, austere, minimal paintings, gestural graphic series, presentations mimicking collections of curiosities or drawings- altogether, an extraordinary creative inventory steadfastly dedicated to re-contextualizing the artifact and gesture...If Whittome’s aesthetic and critical project literally encompasses the notion of museum, it is not because it evaluates and reproduces the museum’s ways of listing , arranging, preserving and presenting , but also, and above all, because it is defined and takes shape within the very idea of collection and collecting activities. Whittome’s found, and sought-for, objects are handled classified and transformed so as to attain the characteristics of “work” and, ultimately, acquire its status. Equally important is the artist’s appropriation of the site, of the space or device relating to the object that has been discovered, chosen, shaped and subsequently offered to our gaze.” (Josee Belisle, Irene F. Whittome   du 3 mai au 19 octobre 1997, Musee d’art contemporain de Montreal, p.33)

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

 While Ulysse Comtois began his career as a painter during the 1940’s, he is best known for his sculpture, in particular his mobile cantilevered aluminum columns of the 1960’s. After studying at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts in 1949, Comtois visited New York City, where he was inspired by the works of Alexander Calder and began to experiment with welded sculptures during the 1950’s. Known for a sense of fun and an amusement park feel, Comtois’s sculpture seeks to look beyond technical design aspects to what he called a “visual sensuality,” and his spiraling, rotating aluminum columns are famous for liberating sculpture from its traditionally static nature. An eclectic artist, Comtois fluxuated between many different styles of modernism without assigning himself to one particular group. His 1961 Untitled reflects his formalist concerns with colour as a non-objective abstract painter, yet also presents a cheerful aspect typical of Comtois’ work with its bright horizontal stripes.

989.52.description:
Object is a hanging calender comprising a large sheet with image in the upper cetner, and a small block of calender pages attached in the lower center area.
Main sheet has two holes punched at the top, with paper eyelets attached on the reverse side on 4.5cm centers.
Green cloth ribbon is passed through each of the holes as a hanger.
Colored linocut in upper center of sheet shows Madonna(?) in a field with a rabbit on the left side and a cat on the right side. Below the image is a block, 2.5cm (h) x 5.5cm (w), of calender pages stitched at the top and held inside a paper cover. Calender is commercially printed, and first page is January 1948

989.53.description:

sketches of winter or Christmas themes, such as: Mary and Child, Christmas trees, and children with Christmas trees
Pencil inscription in upper-right reads: "427 ^illegible^ Institute"

"Mrs Price  Mrs McKenzie ^illegible^"

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Rita Letendre moved to Montreal in 1941, and studied at the École des Beaux-Arts from 1948-9. Unhappy with the rigidity of the school’s instruction, she left after one year, becoming involved with Paul-Émile Borduas and Les Automatistes. While she was associated with them during the early 1950’s, she developed a truly independent style, one that centred on themes of light and energy. She is most well-known for her hard-edge abstract works depicting bright beams of light streaming out from dark backgrounds and seemingly beyond the edges of her canvas.
    While her early work reflected Borduas’s influence in its sombre tonality and thickly applied paint, she moved during the mid-1950’s to a more tightly organized picture plane, using the overlap and juxtaposition of various shapes to create movement, instead of brushstroke. Attempting even at this early stage to liberate light from her canvases, she used sparkles in her paint, then began painting bursts of colour which she eventually contrasted against black during the early sixties. From this stage evolved the wedge-like forms and bands of bright colour for which she is now known. L’Aube is an early work, revealing the influence of the Automatiste movement in Letendre’s use of rectangular daubs of thick colour, resembling Riopelle’s palette knife paintings.

From "Legal Perspectives: Selected Works from the Collection of Osler, Hoskin and Harcourt". Catalogue to an exhibition held at McMichael Canadian Art Collection from June 28 - September 13, 1992. "Will Gorlitz received his art training in the 1970s at the University of Manitoba, followed by studies at the Nova Scotia College of Art and Design. Although he is a painter, he has been influenced by other media such as conceptual art, video art, and performance art. This has led him to adopt a deconstructivist approach that allows for many possibilities of interpretation. Working in thematic series that question the visual language of representation, Gorlitz does not intend his imagery to be viewed as an isolated entity but as imagery layered within a system of relations. Meaning is completed by the spectator's interpretation. The artist lives in Wellington, Ontario." (p 17)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

992.05.title: Boat House Map Two
992.05.references:
Ed Zelenak   Boat House Map 2 (1991)
Mapping, in all its various manifestations, deals with the processes by which a perceived, remembered, and thought-about world is visually brought into being. As a concept it has been used here as an analogy with which to understand Zelenak’s production. All maps concern themselves with the idea of locating a place, and Zelenak, too, is in continual search for the “where” and “here”.  
“Ed Zelenak’s practice is one which has stemmed from the stark impersonality of Minimalism and evolved into a personal exploration of location, self and the energies that inform them. A concern for understanding qualities of consciousness has derived from his disciplined approach and consistent probing into how a work of art communicates- how it locates him.Zelenak’s is an analytic sensibility, but one which requires active viewer invoapper is one who conceives of the representation of things in space; representation             and space  are the two critical terms here. In addition, in the process of mark-making, one can further a means by which place is remembered and thereby record a memory.
	Zelenak’s drawings and sculptures can be understood as variations on mapping, a concern for finding a place. Like maps, the artworks perform a number of significant functions. they serve as necessary tools in the comprehension of spatial phenomena; they are efficient devices for the storage of information, and permit an understanding of relationships not otherwise known.
	Taken as a who;e, the installation of this exhibition also alludes to geographic mapping, with the art objects seen as “markers” or “sites” within a whole room. The way Zelenak has positioned them forces the viewer to orchestrate body movements through rhythmic cadences of scale and material, latitudinal and longitudinal forms, surface texture and suggestive image. By this strategy Zelenak takes further the analogy between body and place, self and location, in an extended context that is physically real and conceptually broader in its implications.” ((Marnie Fleming, Ed Zelenak: Finding a Place, Selected Work 1976-1988 (London: London Regional Art and Historical Museums, p.5) 
	“Zelenak’s iconic configurations characterize the wall works. The shapes a re typically made of metal, and then are set within a field of white paper. Graphite notations appear like planning marks- a combination of calculated and intuitive gestures that search to find the exact point at which the shape is to be embedded. The starkness of the surrounding white paper becomes as important as silence is to language...
	The gestural marks of the graphite cross and re-cross between the desire for presence and representational readings; between being and meaning. They are the notations that tell of Zelenak's’ methodical making of the piece. Sometimes the graphic energies flow too quickly to take definite shape. Other times the image is interrupted by the use of a small (red-coloured or inlaid metal) marker. Zelenak describes their use as “signifying and recording incident.” Like map markers (which also indicate incident, direction or position), the coloured marker expresses a mental concept.” (   ((Marnie Fleming, Ed Zelenak: Finding a Place, Selected Work 1976-1988 (London: London Regional Art and Historical Museums, p.16)
	“His need to fix the world and locate his place in it define his art more than any other element.” (Christopher Hume, “Sculptor bends steel to suit symbolic designs”Toronto Star Friday Jan. 31, 1992)
	“...The differences in these map-making practices, however, are as plain as the similarities. For while Champlain drew maps of a hitherto utterly unknown land , artists today survey a terrain that once was familiar, but now has been made strange and menacing by the technology that pervades it....the map-making of installation art and large-scale drawing is today urged by a longing to name humankind’s place in the perishing world.” (John Bentley Mays, “The new map making: artworks that chart a spiritual course,” The Globe and Mail Saturday July 22, 1989, p.C4)

992.06.title: Parachute Jump
992.06.references: "Susanna Heller's ... paintings and works on paper describe a careful observation of a world we all share. Essentially landscape paintings, the work suggests three themes - the "pure", or uninhabited landscape; the pastoral landscape which occupies the elusive space between rural and urban space; and the urban landscape. ... Regardless of the overt subject, Heller unfolds the story of the image in various directions, through constant shifts of emphasis. However, each painting and drawing retains its own narrative, specific to the sensations of time and place that first prompted the image. Her pictorial approach reminds us of the traditions of expressionism, but she goes beyond just its visual vocabulary in her recognition of its theoretical dualism of pessimism and optimism, fear and wonderment." (from the Artefact communique for Susanna Heller: Recent Paintings and Works on Paper, October 24 - December 7, 1991, by Sandra Paikowsky) "One of the most salient features of Ms. Heller's painting is an almost obsessive avoidance of closure. No form is fully realized and no space is ever constructed without numerous twists, contradictions or interruptions. Her view of nature is dynamic and interdependent, consequently her representations reflect that. She considers space to be an "event" and her forms forever threaten to congeal without ever doing so. Also contributing to her attitude towards closure is Ms. Heller's belief that authenticity of expression resides at the cusp of discovery. ... In Ms. Heller's drawings one finds the essence of vision. It is here that she first expands her expressive vocabulary. It is also here that one sees most clearly how she transforms prosaic detail into a highly charged amalgam of reportage and pure feeling." (David Hornung, September 19, 1988, essay for an exhibition held at the Tomoko Liguori Gallery, New York City)

992.09.references:
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
SUSAN SCOTT
Susan Scott’s works “are characterized by a narrative coherence and an incisive sense of social drama and sundry emotional states that stakes a (p.14) concrete claim of the observer’s own imaginative life.” Each work “ tells its own story, and the narrative form of each drawing is perfectly in keeping with the moods this artist seeks to convey; moods which, in their strange authenticity and in the virtuosity of the draughtsmanship that communicates them, can be captivating and disturbing and challenging at once...fictitious narratives according to which spiritual of moral relations are proffered, in figural form to the spectator.And they are parables which are touchstones for the way we live and the way we feel; the emotive topography of our most private lives. Scott apprehends what Roland Barthes called the ‘scenography of waiting.’...These representational tableaux have a felt ambiguity that only draws us back to them, and while they may be parables, they are also moralistic fables, fables fraught with paradigms of moral truth, abjection and longing from the life-world.” (James D. Campbell, Montreal on Paper Saidye Bronfman Centre, June 27-August 3, 1989 p.15) “Scott has been working with figurative narrative issues for over fifteen years. In committing her subject matter to images of children for the past eight years the artist is attempting to re-address the contemporary taboo of women painting children. Her intention is to address the child’s inner world through the use of parable and allegory, while leaving enough subjective space so as to invite the viewer to retell these stories in their own words.” (Press Release, Galerie de Bellefeuille, Susan G. Scott “Whispers” (1998)) “The characters in the paintings are children, adolescents or young women and men caught up in dramas or traumatic relationships that imply anger, fear, aggression,vulnerability and power struggles...it’s our subjective responses that colour our vision , Scott seems to say. Vision itself is questioned....Echoes of Massaccio, Titian, Goya , Poussin, Fragonard and Balthus give a strong edge to these works forging links to painting’s past.” (“Paintings leave you wondering” Calgary Herald, Wed. May 17, 1989.)

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Tony Scherman received his MA in 1974 from the Royal College of Art in London. Throughout his career he has searched for the epic moments in history and mythology that define human existence, yet reduces those moments to extreme close ups of faces and body parts. He revisits history through the intimate act, such as shaving or bathing, rather than portraying the grander scenes of glorious victory or death typical of academic history painting. Working with encaustic, a mixture of pigment and wax, Scherman also chooses a method of painting that goes back to ancient times, a laborious and time-consuming process that requires him to live intensely in these moments he has chosen for representation. With this careful vision focused on the unexpected moment, Scherman has explored the French Revolution, Shakespeare’s Macbeth, and classical subjects drawn from Ovid’s Metamorphoses. In Untitled from 1989, Scherman develops an enigmatic death bed scene, where what appears to be a vignette of a dying man and his grieving wife is juxtaposed against the same man sitting up on the edge of the bed, a pair of female hands reaching into the frame to adjust his tie. This might be a memory or a moment as it occured earlier that day, or even a vision of his entrance into an afterlife. In contrast to his usual choice of pulling seemingly arbitrary moments out of monumental events for closer scrutiny, Scherman here explores the singular event that every living thing universally awaits.

992.11.title: Composition
992.11.subject: abstract
992.11.source: Purchase- Max and Iris Stern Art Acquisition Fund / achat - Fonds Max et Iris Stern pour l’acquisition d’oeuvres d’art, 1992
992.11.references:
Youngest member of "les Automatistes", extensively referenced in Dennis Reid's Concise History of Canadian Painting (Toronto: Oxford University Press, 1988) 2nd edition. Pages 226-7, 228, 232, 237, 291, 291n, 292, 332. In the permanent collection catalogue of the Musee d'art contemporain, La collection: tableau inaugural "Jean-Paul Mousseau fut l'un des principaux acteurs de la <<revolution automatiste>>. Tout au long de sa carriere artistique, il en a conserve le desir d'authenticite, la volonte de liberte et le gout d'innover. Definnisant l'artiste comme un chercheur visuel, il elabore un vocabulaire plastique qui particularise sa production dessinee, peinte et sculpturale, mais aussi ses travaux scenographique, muraux et appliques. Delaissant l'expressionisme typique de son oeuvre anterieure, il structure davantage, au cours des annees 50, les elements de la composition et investit bientot la surface picturale d'un reseau de bandes colorees, obliques et texturees."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.21, 26-27
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, pp.337-338, 343
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.226-228, 232, 237, 291, 292, 332

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

The youngest artist associated with the Automatiste movement in Montreal, Jean Paul Mousseau eventually branched out into many areas of public art. Strongly opposed to the way in which capitalist society commodifies art and often creates an art world that is reserved for the rich and highly educated, Mousseau took his art making into many public venues, creating murals, designing theatre sets, lighting, and costumes, and even making jewelry. In these endeavours he sought to create a more attractive and stimulating exterior world for people to live in, and was always interested in new technology available to artists. His bright paintings and colourful painted sculpture combine a playful sense of fun with a serious study of geometrical form and colour. Composition is an early work, revealing the influence of the abstract movement in Montreal. Here Mousseau creates a study of colour and form using interlocking horizontal bands of black, red, violet, and blue.

992.12.title: Le Port de Montréal
992.12.keywords: Beaver Hall Group, Canadian Group of Painters, Industry, Montréal scenes
992.12.subject: boats & harbour, Montreal
992.12.references:
From the permanent collection catalogue of the Art Gallery of Ontario: "As the son of the renowned French Canadian sculptor Louis-Phillippe Hebert and the younger brother of sculptor Henri, the young Adrien was absorbed by art. Although born in Paris, he divided his time between that city and Montreal, where he set up his studio. While in Paris he was fascinated by the Seine, and he was often a passenger in the popular bateaux mouches. Following his permanent return to Canada in 1924, Hebert turned his attention to Montreal's harbour, as he believed he could not find the true life and spirit of contemporary art in "wild forests" or "drowsy villages." A leading exponent of Modernism in Quebec painting, he departed from the rigid academic appraches of his immediate predecessors and modelled his compositions on those of the French Post-impressionist Paul Cezanne. Like many younger painters of the day, and increasingly during the 1930s, he wished to record the social and environmental conditions by which he was surrounded and of which he was a part. Hence his interest in complementing views of his own studio and residence with depiction of his immediate environs, and of the industrial activity that took plce alongside, and analogous to, his assiduous labours at the easel. Typical of his harbour paintings, this canvas features ..." In the Concise History of Canadian Painting Dennis Reid writes "ADRIEN HEBERT (1890-1967), son of the distinguished Montreal sculptor Louis-Philippe Hebert, studied under both Brymner and in Paris, and the stolid, classicising modernism he presented in Montreal through exhibitions and in his teaching was entirely consistent with the taste exemplified by the work of Edwin Holgate and of other leading lights in the anglophone community." (207)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, p.306
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, p.207

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Son of the sculptor Louis-Philippe Hébert, and brother of the sculptor Henri, Adrien Hébert came to Montreal in 1894. He studied at the Monument National under Edmond Dyonnet and Joseph Saint-Charles from 1904-6, at the Art Association of Montreal under William Brymner from 1907-11, and at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris, under Fernand Cormon and Émile Pager, from 1912-14. He went back and forth between Paris and Montreal until 1924, when he came back to Montreal permanently, and turned to the city for his artistic inspiration. Considered a leader of the Modernist movement in Quebec, Hébert’s painting was concerned with a Post Impressionist sense of colour and solidity of form. He painted interiors, and landscapes capturing the Autumn and Spring around Ste-Rose, but in Montreal he was most drawn to the harbour, as he had been drawn to the Seine in Paris. As a scene of industry, the harbour was highly compatible with Hébert’s interest in industry and labour. Le Port de Montréal demonstrates this with its emphasis on the looming prow of the giant ship, the constriction of the narrow space between boat and dock, and the smoke and steam emanating from the boats.

992.13.title: Blackout
992.13.subject: abstraction
992.13.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
992.13.source: Purchase- Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat- Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1992
992.13.references:
Please see Dennis Reid, "A Concise History of Canadian Painting" (Toronto: Oxford University Press, 1988), second edition. Pages 291, 328, 331-6. Photocopy of 331-6 available in artist's file. In Matthew Teitelbaum's "Paterson Ewen: The Montreal Years", the following is written about Ewen's "Blackout" paintings: "Ewen followed the Lifestream series with paintings which expressed a similar interest in controlled gesture. In two concurrent bodies of work, retrospectively called Blackout and Alert, he used contrasting geometric shapes to create points of tension and evocations of space. Playfullness was inherent. Deep eruptive textures were created by dragging sawblades across the surface; paint was pulled into ridges, and smudged into crevices. Each body of work had its genesis in Ewen's increasing interest in the formal constituents of Russian Constructivism. In this, he shared an interest with a number of Montreal artists who saw in the work of Mikhail Larianov, Natalia Goncharova and, most particularly, Kasimir Malevich, a purity of formal means, and a resistence to the conventions of popular taste. The emphatic geometry of the Constructivists reflected a new urban order of space and structural clarity and encouraged those who, like the Plasticiens, took the implications of Constructivism into even more simplified compositions. For Ewen, the example of Constructivism moved him away from a centralized, linear composition to his first truly all-over paintings, filled with dramatic, yet ordered visual incidents across the surface of the canvas. The Blackout works (cats. 31 through 34), particularly, are filled with the anxiety of articulating form and structure from minimal colour. Realized in the summer of 1961, which Ewen spent in the country near Montreal, the Blackout paintings were suggested by the phenomenon of the night sky. A number were realized out-of-doors in the evening; others, including the Alert series, were painted indoors. Each is near monochrome, yet clearly punctuated with colour highlights, like blinking stars, which flicker near floating Constructivist-inspired squares. The squares here ease into each other, there clash; they move and twist and break the defining edge of the canvas support. The image, wrested from the natural world, is brought forward and spilled upon the canvas." (27)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.71, 74-76, 81, 149
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, pp.343, 347
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.291, 328, 331-336

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

    Patterson Ewen studied at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts under Arthur Lismer and Goodridge Roberts from 1948-50, and was also influenced by John Constable and Philip Guston. During the 1950’s and 60’s he was involved with the Montreal abstractionists Les Automatistes, and with Guido Molinari and Claude Tousignant through Galerie l’Actuelle. He was using a masking tape technique to create straight edge abstract works, but he began to see the lines in his paintings as the movement of objects through space. This prompted him to experiment with painting rain, which would lead to a lifelong interest in exploring meteoroligical and astronomical workings through his art. By the late 1960’s he had tired of painting on canvas, and moved to what he is now most famous for, large works painted onto gauged plywood that balance large areas of colour with the texture of relief. Blackout is an early work, done before Ewen discovered the plywood technique, yet strangely like a precursor to his later facination with sky in its thick black surface glimmering with traces of red and purple squares.

992.15.title: La Chanteuse, Théâtre Loews
992.15.keywords: Group-Contemporary Arts Society, Figuration-social scenes, Montréal scenes, Social Realism
992.15.subject: performer/audience - Female performer is on stage at Loew's Theatre (Ste-Catherine Street). The head of the audience are seen from behind.
992.15.credit: Gift of/don du Dr. Samuel H. Schecter
992.15.source: Gift of Samuel H. Schecter / don de Samuel H. Schecter, 1992
992.15.references:
From a text written by Louis Muhlstock and found in the artists's file (provenence unknown), "Born in Opatow, Poland, in 1940, Jack Beder came to Canada in 1926. He studied at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Montreal from 1929 to 1934, winning numerous awards for landscape and annual work, including the first prize bronze medal in 1931, the year he first exhibited at the Art Association of Montreal, now the Museum of Fine Arts. Since that time he has been a frequent exhibitor, in solo shows and in groups not only in Montreal, but in Toronto, in Western Canada and in the United States. His work has been represented in the travelling exhibitions of the Canadian Society of Painters in Water Colour throughout Canada and in New York, in National Gallery Shows, in the exhibitions of the Royal Canadian Academy and the Canadian Society of Graphic Art, and he appeared in the water colour section of the Canadian exhibition at the New York World's Fair in 1939 ... At the beginning of his career, Jack Beder stayed close to Montreal, attracted by the streets anf the harbour, and for several years - between 1931 and 1935 - did a great deal of drawing in cafes, later using the sketches for large compositions in oil and gouache." Exhibition history of La chanteuse, theatre Leows: 1934 - Montreal, Y.M.H.A. (one man show); 1973 - Ottawa, Wallach Galleries (one man show); 1987 - Saidye Bronfman Centre (Group Show) Jewish Painters and Modernity, Montreal 1930-45. From Esther Trepanier's essay, "A new Canadian painting?": "... Jack Beder and Louis Muhlstock ... became the "masters" of urban painting sonce both painters were extremely partial to the city. THey both approached it as a place of visual experimentation in which one could attempt to capture the infinite highlights created by atmospheric conditions through forms and colour. The spirit behind this undertaking is reminiscent of the 19th-century European tradition, which reached its climax with the Impressionists. Yet neither Beder nor Muhlstock uaw the systematic fragmentation of strokes which caused the Impressionists to somewhat neglect three-dimensional perspective. ... Muhlstock's street scenes are remarkably deserted. Beder, on the other hand, rarely did portraits, preferring instead to reintroduce the human figure in typical urban scenes. It was in Montreal's cafes, night-clubs and restaurants that he would sketch the city's nocturnal "fauna", using them as raw material for paintings which, by their total lack of flattery toward the models, remind one of Toulouse-Lautrec." For comprehensive articles on Beder and his histo-social context, please see artist's file. From the Beder artist file, September 1992 memo from Kristina Huneault "The Leows Theatre was built in 1917 and originally was used both for films and live vaudeville productions. It was renovated and the interior divided into smaller theatres in 1976." La chanteuse, theatre Leows is a small, orange brown and green pastel drawing on paper, whose subject is a female performer on stage at Leows Theatre (Saint Catherine Street, Montreal). The vantage point is from the rear of the theatre, and the heads of the audience are seen from behind. The work was presented at the opening of the Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery by Dr. Samuel Schecter, in recognition of Dr. Patrick Kenniff's contribution to Montreal's 350th anniversary.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

written by Martine Fournier for the “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

After immigrating to Canada from Poland in 1926, Montreal artist Jack Beder studied at the École des Beaux-Arts from 1929 to 1934. During his early career he painted many scenes of urban life in the streets and cafés of Montreal, later traveling to the laurentian hills and Lac St. Jean to capture the landscape. In 1946 he visited the Maritimes, a painting trip he would continue to repeat for many years to come.
    Considered a master of urban painting, Beder tended to focus on the city itself during the thirties, striving to capture an urban quality of light, and painting the people of Montreal in its cafés and theatres. La chanteuse, Théâtre Loews is typical of Beder’s urban scenes as it depicts a crowd watching a singer in the Leows Theatre on Ste. Catherine St. Beder uses his canvas here to bring forward a moment of brightness during a difficult era, highlighting the glowing form of the singer as she is contrasted against the shadowed heads of her audience.

992.16.title: Nude
992.16.subject: nude female - standing woman with arms raise from the back
992.16.credit: Gift of/don du Dr. and/et Mrs./Mme Harvey Evans
992.16.source: Gift of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey A. Evans / don de Dr et Mme Harvey A. Evans, 1992
992.16.references:
Exhibition history: Canadian National Exhibition, August 24 - September 8, 1951 (#35); Royal Canadian Academy, 72nd annual exhibition, Art Gallery of Toronto, November 23, 1951 - January 6, 1952 (#21). "Nude (1950) is an outstanding example of Cosgrove's commitment to painting and to figure painting in particular. His unigue aesthetic sensibility, his ongoing concern with formal dynamics, medium and process are in evidence here. The treatment of the surface and technical approach demonstrate the influence of Orozco, with whom he worked in Mexico, and of fresco paintings in the 40s and later, and this work represents a pivotal point in the development of his oeuvre." Stanley Cosgrove's far-reaching influence as an educator at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Montreal and his contribution to the larger art community places him in an important position in the history of Canadian art. (Karen Antaki, 1992 application for certification of cultural property)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.215-216, 218, 290

992.17.title: Shaker Suite
992.17.subject: male figure playing piano in leopard-skin room; images of chairs
992.17.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
992.17.references:
"Throughout the 1980's Joanne Tod has created critical images that address issues of power, identity and representation. Appropriating the highly illustrative style of advertising, she depicts situations with a conventional clarity and fluidity that endow her work deceptively with the authority of a final utterance." (AGO permanent collection catalogue, 1990) "Situated within a fin-de-siecle time frame, Joanne Tod's oeuvre represents a restorative process reflective of a generation's concern with the recuperation of meaning in art. In response to a media run, post-industrial society and its fostering of a false sense of homogeneity and order, contemporary artists have sought out interventionist methods to address crucial issues attached to identity and representation. The culling and recontextualization of media imagery, and the conscious critique of historicism and of traditional forms of representation such as painting, exemplify a reaction to the far-reaching influence of the detached third eye of mass media and the social mechanisms that control our very mechanisms of "knowing"." (Karen Antaki, catalogue essay for the exhibition Joanne Tod: The [dis]Order of Things, Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery, April 22 - June 5, 1993. "La peinture de Joanne Tod se distingue d'emblee par sa nature resolumment figurative. La matiere picturale y est subordonnee a la chose representee, scenes et personnes etant rendus avec un apparent souci de clarte. Mais l'illusion n'est que partielle et s'accompagne d'autre part d'un certain trouble." (Pierre Landry, Musee d'art contemporain permanent collection catalogue, 1992) "Joanne Tod's paintings are critical images: they are about social mores, about racism, sexism, about "the good life". Overall, they are images which are topical to today's right wing moral climate, current with this period of conservatization. Tod produces her imagery in the visual language of the dominant culture. They are abviously appropriated, in style, from the imagery of TV and magazines, derived from advertisements, all expertly painted in a realist and illustrative manner. Yet in spite of its source the meaning is always somehow inverted, interrupted with a jarring sensation. In what might otherwise be an ordinary image, perfectly banal and ready for easy consumption, there is something wrong, some incongrious element introduced." (page 7-8 from Late Capitalism: Will Gorlitz, Andy Patton, Joanne Tod, Shirley Wiitasalo. Curated by Tim Guest, at The Art Gallery At Harbourfront, January 11 - February 17, 1985) Shaker Suite (1986) is a silkscreen print of a male figure seated at a piano, in a room hung with images of chairs on leopard-print walls. Title play on words "suite" references both a set of matched furniture for a room, and a form of musical composition, and "shaker" a millenarium sect originating in England in 1747 and practicing celibacy and an ascetic communal life, currently best known for their architecture and design. One of the distinguishing characteristics of their architectural organization was the practice of hanging their chairs on the walls of their communal dwellings when they were not in use.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.280-281, 290
-See Jessica Bradley and Lesley Johnstone, eds., “Sightlines,” 1994, p.359

993.01.title: Compass
993.01.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
993.01.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1993
993.01.references:
Barbara Steinman is a Montreal-based artist who has exhibited widely, including the National Gallery of Canada in Ottawa and the Museum of Modern Art in New York City. Her installation-based work brings together photography, video and sculpture. As monuments to the anonymous, disenfranchised individual, her work stakes a claim for the nuance and implicitly denounces the continued existence of at least two versions of historical events: the official version, which purports to represent the collective, and the individual, or the personal - in other words, the authorized and unauthorized versions. By questioning these mechanisms of history, she assumes a political position. In order to achieve her political objective, Steinman privileges the study of language, mediated through image, word and sign. Once recuperated by the present, historical information is brought to the light of day, wherein hidden manipulations and power investments stand revealed. Her 1991 sculpture `Compass', consists of a large magnifying lens mounted on a brass tripod, with the words "THE CENTRE OF THE WORLD/IS EXACTLY/WHERE YOU STAND" inscribed into the glass. Exhibited as part of larger installations titled "Ballroom" in the Pump House in Charleston, South Carolina, commissioned for city-wide exhibition titled "Places With a Past"; "L'imperceptible trajet", 1992: Chapelle de l'Hotel-Dieu, Cadran Solaires, Troyes, France (SOURCES: Richmond, Cindy and Barbara London: Uncertain Monuments. An exhibition organized by the Mackenzie Art Gallery and held from April 24 - August 2, 1992. Manon Blanchette in La collection: tableau inaugurale, a catalogue of the permanent collection of the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal, published on the occasion of an exhibition which started May 28, 1992.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See Jessica Bradley and Lesley Johnstone, eds., “Sightlines,” 1994, p.71

993.02.subject: Latin American investment/colonialism by U.S.A. as reflected in newspaper excerpts, graph & photograph

993.02.references:
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See Jessica Bradley and Lesley Johnstone, eds., “Sightlines,” 1994, p.93n
DOMINIQUE BLAIN
Karen Antaki writes “Dominique Blain’s oeuvre also addresses questions of marginalization, focusing on the cultural and social divisions between one   and the other ,  and metaphorically engaging issues of enframement and exclusion. While photographic images drawn form archival sources provide the artist’s documentary content, their recontextualization relocates meaning within a discursive critique of hierarchical orders such as religion, patriarchy and colonization....the location of the soil also directs the spectator’s viewing activity, furthering the equation made between the claiming and controlling of land. ( Karen Antaki, Temporal Borders: Image and Site Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery, 1993 p.6) ...it is acknowledging the relationships between land, labour , ownership and profit within the context of place and its possession, that one gains an understanding of the transient and contingent nature of human existence.” (Antaki, Temporal Borders p.7) “Real dirt, albeit of the clean and insect-free variety purchased at a garden centre, is also part of Dominique Blain’s multi-media installation entitled “No Man’s Land”. The dirt is heaped in a line just in front of the gallery wall. And hung low on this wall is a strip of black and white photos that show stopping Asian rice farmers. The dirt both forms a barrier and brings us into physical contact with tangible reality. Also, the lowness of the images forces us to bend down in mild imitation of the farmers themselves...” (Henry Lehmann, HOUR, October 14, 1993) “For the past three years Montreal artist Dominique Blain has been producing a body of work which deals with the politics of inequality and its legacy in what is, perhaps in name only, a post-colonial world. The artist uses historical photographs from period ethnographic magazines to explore the early role of photography in representing both the exotic imagery and the ideology of ‘empire’..... The objects in her imaginary museum... through reversals and substitutions, conspire to deconstruct the inherent distortions of domination, exploitation and appropriation.” (Owens Art Gallery Calendar, Fall 1994) “The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery’s Temporal Borders: Image and Site show included Dominique Blain’s explicit photographic exposes of Third World workers laboring in the fields. ...stereotypes notions of ownership, exploitation and profit with a consciousness that is as didactic as it is media perfect...” (John K. Grande Sculpture January-February 1994)
Blain’s images are “derived from public affairs magazines and newspapers”...the artist makes use of a variety of found objects and used primary materials...
techniques employed: montage and photographic blow-up
..”The carefully sculpted shapes of the figures , as well as the carefully chosen objects in the assemblages and the timeworn frames that enclose some of her pieces, evoke a slow passage of time, almost a retro ambience. This emphasizes the process of fabrication and the presence of the maker’s identity. The intimacy inherent in this aspect of Blain’s works contrasts with the public nature of her source material and the anonymity of its broad accessibility. Blain manipulates the viewer so that he or she is effectively drawn to these aspects in her work and encompassed by their very seductiveness...” (Michele Theriault, Perspective 89: Roy Arden and Dominique Blain (September 16-November 12, 1989, Art Gallery of Ontario, 1989, p.19)...”Blain’s practice ...is predicated on a view or reality as representation, which is in turn manipulated so as to undermine and subvert its   particular hegemonic and homogenizing voice (the master voice).
	Blain is a manipulator of signs, and her work is also a critique of the traffic of images and of culture as a producer of signs. She produces new signs and a new set of codes in which the relationship of the signifier and the signified is made ambivalent...” (Michele Theriault p.21)...
...”they conspire to erect a presence of “other” that forces the viewer to reposition his cultural presence. The images ... stress the white man’s paternalistic control over the culture of the other (e.g. colonialism) and confront the viewer with constructs that contribute to a redefinition of his or her cultural identity...Her assemblages...propose a restructured view of reality that ‘uncovers conditions’ and subtly and sparingly reveals the mechanics of cultural hegemony and differences.” (Michele Theriault p.23)

993.03.title: Floral Ruin
993.03.subject: studio set-up of landscape with Greco-Roman ruin
993.03.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
993.03.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1993
993.03.references:
From a 1993 Musee d'art de Joliette press release: "A la fin des annees soixante-dix, Holly King travaille la performance en explorant les notions de mise en scene et de theatralite. Des le debut des annees quatre-vingts, elle s'oriente vers la photographie, mais ses preoccupations demeurent les memes : jouer avec l'illusion et la notion du vrai et du faux. ... Peut-on la qualifier d'artiste multidisciplinaire puisque les paysages qu'elle photographie sont le resultat de maquettes qu'elle compose, peint et eclaire? Ainsi, elle met en scene des paysages fictifs composes d'elements reels et d'elements construits. Elle laisse le spectateur jouer le jeu de departager le vrai du faux ou tout simplement de se laisser charmer par ces paysages venus de nulle part."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

“Prior to photography, her work in performance led Holly King to experiment with theatricality and mise-en scène. From the theatre tradition she has drawn certain elements such as frontal perspective and artifice, and transposed them in her photographic work where she explores in an indirect manner the tension between excessive visibility and illusion...Holly King’s subject matter and her manner of representation plays upon a paradox, and this paradox contributes to the eerie aspect of the works. By juxtaposing the ephemeral aspect of an event with its inscription in time, by associating the sublime with the banal, a shift of focus occurs which recalls the distance between the natural and the theatrical. (Diagonales Montreal)

“Clearly, the theatricalized settings of staging’s potential worlds go against the canonical definition of photography . They are what-have-not -been...Or better yet, they are what-could-not-have been-there...as ‘there’ is of considerable importance, since the spaces created by these photographs are reflexive. The photographs themselves are topics of fictitious, potential and ( Peter Krausz, Staging Saidye Bronfman Centre for the Arts, 1995 p.8) conceivable places constructed for s specific purpose. Henceforth, , the accepted definition of photography, further enriched...by such theorists such as Roland Barthes, Rosalind Krauss...- the result of an effective interaction between the photographer and the perceived world, the imprint of this contact- becomes disabled or at least seriously enfeebled...The signification of photographs cannot be reduced to the defining particularities of each image, but is the ‘act by which an ideological subject is cognizant of the world.’ Photography’s existing definitions are not, for that matter, false but are reducible to what we have chosen to think of them and to how we have disposed of them for over a century...”
Holly King chooses “to modify the world’s already-there from the outset, shaping it....(Her) construction of a simulated and fictitious space, generally ephemeral and destined for demolition, places further value on the treatment of space.

By choosing to work with assemblage and collage, the artists of staging, each in his or her own way, are constructing a marked, scenic space, bearing traces artificially produced or simply altered...light is shed upon a constructed state of world for a specific purpose.  A purpose that, thereafter, can rely solely on this construction, resting upon a predetermined basis...(Krausz, Stagings p.9)
.... “this uncertainty arises in perceiving the confrontation between the real and the fictional, and in the ambiguity linking reality and artifice...That image, as a fusion of visual idioms, is articulated with a vocabulary wherein the real , formally or iconographically, provides the terms with which to consider the imaginary...” (Cyril Reade, Holly King: Realms of Night Stride Gallery, Feb 5-28, 1987, Southern Alberta Art Gallery, March 7-30, 1987)   
 
written by Martine Fournier:

After obtaining her BFA from Laval University, Quebec in 1979, and her MFA from York University, Toronto in 1981, Holly King began a career as a performance artist. Switching to photography in the early 1980’s, her work was still informed by her theatrical experience as she chose to create miniature landscapes on tabletops, like miniature theatre sets, and photograph them. The result, as in Floral Ruin, is a dramatically-lit dreamworld that seems to lie somewhere between fairytale and nightmare. Unlike many other constructed photography artists, King does not use the medium for ironic or satirical observations on society, but rather to explore the world of illusion. Creating an artificial world , King is interested in how it becomes believable and therefore illusion, and how the spectator, once recognizing the illusion involved, becomes distanced from the landscape King has created. In this way she sets up a scenario symbolic of the unattainability of Paradise.

993.04.title: Le Chasseur d'images (trophée #229)
993.04.subject: leaf in 4 sections, with push-pins
993.04.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
993.04.source: Purchase- Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat- Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat des oeuvres d'art, 1993
993.04.references:
written by Martine Fournier:

Photographer Roberto Pellegrinuzzi frequently uses installation to explore not only human faces, and simple domestic and natural objets, but the photographic process itself. As he plays with detail and enlargement, dissecting the effects of lenses and chemicals, he also maintains a sense of the magic of capturing life on film. During the 1990’s series called Le chasseur d’images, Pellegrinuzzi works mainly with leaves, sometimes repeating the leaf image again and again, constructing architectural forms from these images as though with tiles, or constructing one monumental leaf out of many detail shots blown up to gigantic proportions. Pellegrinuzzi thus examines the world on both micro and macroscopic levels, constructing images that overwhelm not only with size but with incredible detail. In Le chasseur d’images (trophée #229), Pellegrinuzzi blows up the image of a single leaf (though not to the architectural scale of some of his other works), and breaks it into sections that are seen in separate squares, as though through a window.

993.06.title: Volcano IV
993.06.subject: abstracted volcano with smoke
993.06.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
993.06.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1993
993.06.references: In a pamphlet (published 1987) accompanying an exhibition of recent works by David Moore at the Concordia Art Gallery, Moore had the following to say about the work and his process: "The more recent and larger works switch from object to subject; in my idea, psychological projections of the viewer, anthropomorphic forms with connotations of the self, and, by coincidence, other cultures that search for characterization through a pantheistic diversity of aspects of being. It starts from an image, a sign, a shape, a thought ... My method is to draw and redraw a multitude of thumbnail sketches in miniscule sketchpads. I keep in mind the material, usually but not always wood, a material that obliges me to be pragmatic in working with its own warps and shapes, in other words, history. only when the sketches themselves become so metamorphosed as to be almost unrecognizble, do the concepts take form. But in spite of the changes, a relationship is maintained with the original concept. The moment of change remains fixed. I am less concerned with the perfection of the development of form than the semi-magical transformations that art and science have always taken for granted. Contemporary art, in this sense, is doing what alchemy has been doing for hundreds of years in its laboratories." This document was written around the time that the volcano series, including Volcano IV, were being produced.

993.07.title: Désirs Mouvements
993.07.subject: abstract
993.07.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l'artiste
993.07.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1993
993.07.references:
One of the original seven automatistes, the others being Roger Fauteux, Jean-Paul Riopelle, Pierre Gauvreau, Paul-Emile Borduas, Fernand Leduc. Indexed in Dennis Reid's "A Concise History of Canadian Painting" (2nd edition) pages 226-7, 228, 232, 239, 240. These References available in artist's file. "Desirs mouvement" was created at the Nouvel Aire Dance Studio (Montreal) in interaction with Paul-Andre Fortier and the other dancers of that company in preparation for a performance at the Art Gallery of Ontario on May 1, 1978. It "is a unique example of Marcel Barbeau's ongoing commitment to the investigation of gestural abstraction and automatisme generally. In addition, as one of the few existing records of the artist's performance works it holds an important place in the history of Canadian art and that of Quebec in particular. Of the large drawings created during the performances of 1972 through 1978, a number already form part of significant Canadian public collections such as the Owens Art Gallery, the Agnes Etherington Art Centre, the Art Gallery of Greater Victoria and the London Regional Art and Historical Museums." (Karen Antaki, from the 1993 application for certification of cultural property) "This monumental performance drawing (180"x180") is the last of a group of 20 monumental paintings and drawings made by Barbeau at performances between 1972 and 1978 that he has kept in his personal collection. It was the very first work done during a performance with choreographer Paul-Andre Fortier, prior to an AGO performance, and it was also the very first choreographic experience with the dancer. It was exhibited at the Maison de la culture de Plateau Mont-Royal within an exhibition of Barbeau's large-scale drawings and was widely reproduced and analysed by the media on the occasion of this exhibition. Two other drawings from that series which were made on kraft paper during a performance at Quebec-Ete-Danse in 1978 have been lost, so only 18 paintings and drawings of this size from this period remain. All others were sold many years ago. To ensure the conservation of this last drawing, Marcel Barbeau had it glued on canvas." (Ninon Gauthier, from the 1993 application for certification of cultural property)

993.12.title: Théâtre d'Ombres, à l'Encre
993.12.subject: abstract - 2 enframed rectangular images of broad sweeps of colour wash and geometric form
993.12.credit: Gift of/don de Alison and/et Alan Schwartz
993.12.source: Gift of Alison and Alan Schwartz / don d'Alison et Alan Schwartz, 1993
993.12.references:
-Since the 1970's, drawing has occupied the centre of Jocelyne Alloucherie's artistic practice. Her work, "Theatre d'Ombres, a l'Encre" is typical, through its simultanous reference to the potentiality of both image and site. This reflection on the architectural space as theatre underscores the metaphoric contents evoking both monument and myth, in accordance to the contrasting registers of critical distance and personal apprehension. (Margot Bouman) Theatre d'Ombres, a l'encre forms part of a series of six and consists of "Two enframed ink-based drawings in a dominant chromatism of black and grey. A reference to both architectural and natural space is made through the broad sweeps of colour wash and the geometric articulation of form. ... This drawing constitutes an important example of Jocelyne Alloucherie's continued exploration of the interrelationship between space and site, architecture and nature. Whereas the artist's slightly earlier production is superimposed "painting" on monumental object/subjects, here the activity of painting is framed and presented as subject itself. This reversal nevertheless remains consistent with Alloucherie's preoccupation with pictorial interventions. This work demonstrates both a continuation and an evolution of the artist's work and is of signifiance in terms of her overall production." (Karen Antaki, from the 1993 application for certification of Cultural Property)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

993.13.title: Untitled - Rouge
993.13.subject: abstract, hard edge - subtle variation of red fields on four vertical panels
993.13.credit: Gift of/don de Alison and/et Alan Schwartz
993.13.source: Gift of Alison and Alan Schwartz / don d'Alison et Alan Schwartz, 1993
993.13.references:
From "Legal Perspective: Selected Works from the Permanent Collection of Osler, Hoskin and Harcourt". Catalogue to an exhibition held at McMichael Canadian Art Collection from June 28 to September 13, 1992. "Colour was the central concern of Louis Comtois from the beginning of his career until his recent death. The artist's early training in Montreal when the tradition of formal, abstract colour-painting was dominant, remained an important element in his art throughout his career, most of which was spent in New York. Like the work of the minimalists, Comtois' paintings demand participation from the spectator as his seemingly monochrome paintings embody subtle layerings and modulations of colour, light and finish which are apparent only with contemplation. This minimalist approach almost denies the presence of the artist's hand." (p 14) Untitled - Rouge (1980) is a "monochromatic red painting constructed in four vertical panels. Subtle tonal changes produce faintly discerned colour bands and, in conjunction with the actual physical division of the panels, creates an undulating surace tension. This painting is an excellent example of Louis Comtois' oeuvre, a native born Quebecois artist who lived in New York until his death in 1990. In its post-minimalist reductive emphasis, the work reveals Comtois' formal influences: Montreal abstraction and the legacy of les Plasticiens. The reference to an important period in the development of Quebec art combines with the artist's ongoing pictorial concerns, such as the layered articulation of space and colour, to engage the spectator in a critical and contemporary discourse." (Karen Antaki, from the 1993 application for certification of cultural property)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.250, 253

993.15.title: Oasis I
993.15.subject: abstract - centralized geometric abstraction of various sized rectangular and adjacent shapes
993.15.credit: Gift of/don de Alison and/et Alan Schwartz
993.15.source: Gift of Alison and Alan Schwartz / don d'Alison et Alan Schwartz, 1993
993.15.references:
From "Legal Perspective: Selected Works from the Collection of Osler, Hoskin and Harcourt". Catalogue to an exhibition held at McMichael Canadian Art Collection from June 28 - September 13, 1992. "Colour was the central concern of Louis Comtois from the beginning of his career until his recent death. The artist's early training in Montreal when the tradition of formal, abstract colour-painting was dominant, remained an important elementin his art throughout his career, most of which was spent in New York. Like the work of the minimalists, Comtois' paintings demand participation from the spectator as his seemingly monochrome paintings embody subtle layerings and modulations o colour, light and finish which are apparent only with contemplation. This minimalist approach almost denies the presence of the artist's hand. In 1981, Comtois began experimenting with collage on paper." (p 15) "...et Aubergine and Oasis I ... are centralized geometric arrangements of various sized rectangular and adjacent shapes. The layered applications of pigment and gauze creates a vertical surface tension and dynamic. ... [which] provide an important complement to Untitled - Rouge, an oil painting by Louis Comtois which forms part of the ... [permanent collection. These] two works on paper provide a larger context within which to examine the artist's oeuvre. Both are excellent examples of Comtois' more intimate, iconic paperworks. They contrast the larger, more `constructed' paintings and expand upon the artist's continued interest in probing the limits of abstraction and reflect his ongoing concern with the investigation of colour effects and the articulation of a layered surface dynamic." (Karen Antaki, from the 1993 application for certification of cultural property.)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.250, 253

993.16.title: Les Jardins d'Aube #15
993.16.subject: abstract - gestural mass of colour suspended over suggested ground
993.16.credit: Gift of/don de Alison and/et Alan Schwartz
993.16.object_rights: © Succession de Jean Albert McEwen / SODRAC 2009
993.16.source: Gift of Alison and Alan Schwartz / don d'Alison et Alan Schwartz, 1993
993.16.references:
"Les Jardins d'Aube #15 is an important example of Jean McEwen's production of the mid-seventies. ... Stylistically the work not only refers to the monochromatic emphasis of the 1950's, but also anticipates the later chromatic and structural developments. This oil on canvas produced in tones of white, gold and green is one of a series created in 1975-76. It is composed of a gestural mass of colour suspended above a suggested ground. The layering of oil pigment and the passages of varnish produce an atmospheric spatial organization that reveals its `background' through interspersed vertical bands." (Karen Antaki, 1993 application for certification of cultural property.)
See record #1 for biographical information.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.53, 73-74, 79
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, pp.343, 347
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.291, 296-297, 372

written by Martine Fournier:

While strongly influenced by Borduas, Riopelle, and other Automatistes, Jean McEwen developed his own style of abstraction, using the relationship between fields of colour to create a sense of life, often painting with his fingers. During the early 1950’d McEwen met Mark Rothko and Clifford Still in Paris, and the early influence of of Borduas’s group gave way to theirs. He began to paint with luminosity and sensuousness, using oil and watercolour to explore light, colour, and fluidity of surface. He went from the Cellule series on cells of colour built up through layers of paint, to his Windows series of the early sixties, in which he superimposed colours on one another to show hw they affected each other. From this he went on to cruciform shapes, playing with the importance of the four corners of canvas, and then to a series of flags. By the late 1960’s he was using acrylic to experiment with hard-edge abstraction, and in the 1970’s returned to oil and varnish because of his strong desire to work with colour rather than line. His series on Les jardins d’aube involved covering colour with layers of white, changing the colour dynamic to a more subtel one in whcih ti works from within the painting instead of on its surface. Les jardins d’aube investigates the nature of opacity versus transparency, and creates an opalescence through the combination of colour and layers of white, which he continued to work with in later series.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Originally from Hungary, Herman Heimlich studied at the Budapest Royal Academy of Fine Arts from 1922 to 1926, leaving Hungary for the United States in 1928. In 1930, he moved to Montreal, where he became associated with a group of Montreal figurative Jewish painters active between the 1930’s and 50’s, and befriended Ernst Neumann and Goodridge Roberts. Working in pastels, charcoal, watercolour and oil, Heimlich pursued the human figure as subject, not to bring out its environment or daily existence but rather its physicality and psychology, creating intimate, thoughtful portraits. In the Portrait of Brodie Shearer Heimlich depicts one of his students, also an artist, with his usual personal approach, his focus on capturing the intensity of the young man’s gaze.
