994.03.title: Hanged Man
994.03.subject: giraffe, shoe
994.03.references:
HANGED MAN (1987) ARTIST: TREVOR GOULD

Earl Miller describes Trevor Gould’s work as follows “The relationship between violence, domination, authority and the institutions which produce them is analyzed through a network of narrative in the work of Trevor Gould. Loaded symbols, text and an exotic , expressive iconography present this discourse on power relations. Gould explores the co-relation between expressionism as a manifestation of the self and as a strategy of communicating socio-political ideology.....Gould’s works utilizes symbology open to a myriad of contextual interpretations. Within Gould’s frame of reference, the meanings of his symbology do carry some specificity. Wild animals; gorillas, antelopes and cheetahs are icons of the Other. They are the victims of the status quo; hunted stalked and in one case displayed as a trophy. Phallocentric male figures maintain hierarchical authority over both animals and humans. A notation between the biological chain of life and the cultural sources of cultural dominance is developed by cross-referential symbols of animals, the family, the church and patriarchal violence.....Gould’s attempts to co relate the psychological with the ideological, and an interesting dialogue begins between the male hierarchical system, its subsequent victims and the origins of power. Yet the cross-referencing between human violence and animal majesty raises open-ended questions on man’s destruction of the biological chain and the widespread conviction that Social Darwinism justifies the oppression of the weak and underprivileged...” (Earl Miller, “Trevor Gould” C Magazine volume 12, 1987, p.70.) Describing a recent exhibition of Gould’s work, the Edmonton Art Gallery writes that “ Gould uses the standard exhibition strategies of the zoo, the botanical garden and the museum of natural history to look at the relationship of their methodologies to the colonial context in which they were developed. He provides a glimpse into the “geography of exhibiting” thereby offering a new interpretation of the natural world.” (see Edmonton Art Gallery web site: Upcoming Exhibitions, “Trevor Gould: Posing For The Public, April 16-June 13, 1999 http://www.eag.org/upcoming-exhibitions/gould_ 1999.html) Jim Drobnick writes “Travelling from theme park to zoo, from museum to botanical garden, the works of Trevor Gould consistently foreground the exhibitionary means by which the ideology of empire has been manifested, rationalized and celebrated. While the most egregious expression of colonial hubris may have peaked in the nineteenth century’s mania for World’s Fairs and ethnographic expositions, Gould’s interest lies in exposing the persistence if this ideology in contemporary institutions and practices.” (see CIAC website, essay by Jim Drobnick “Trevor Gould, true Confessions of a Leaf Thief.” http;//www.ciac.ca/biennale/angl_artistes.html#capteurs)

994.04.title: Untitled/sans titre
994.04.subject: vase (3 dimensional) with inscription on support, contained with box/frame
994.04.references:
"Inside mural boxes with glassed-in fronts, an object is shown whose form is repeated in a drawing next to it - a sort of model or rigorously traced pattern which reproduces the object in the manner of a template. However, the distance imposed by these objects comes less from the presence of a physical barrier (the glass) than the simultaneous presentation of two moments (two states) of a single thing. ... it is impossible to be certain which of these elements is more 'authentic' and would come first among (its) many possible interpretations." (Landry, 57. Translated by Sandra A. Sinclair) "The perversity of Stevenson's work can be found, for example, in the opposition of highly subjective objects with a deadpan mimicry of the heavily coded and controlled manners of categorization and display used in the naming and framing of her works. (Ritchie 5) "For Stevenson the character of everyday experience has a decidedly sensory bent, tied to the qualities of her chosen forms and materials and their capacity to elicit sense memories, the sort of memories driven by emotional or psychological events. Her quasi-representational references to ... vaguely human organs and body parts are incorporated in objects constructed of ordinary, utilitarian materials ... these familiar, sensual characteristics indicate a quality of experience that is singularly private and intuitive." (Ritchie, 7) (SOURCES: Pierre Landry, "L'origine des choses", catalogue to an exhibition organized by the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal, October 21 1994 - January 8, 1995; Christina Ritchie, "Perspectives 94: Carlo Cesta and Sarah Stevenson", catalogue to an exhibition organized by the Art Gallery of Ontario, October 26, 1994 - January 8, 1995)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

994.05.title: Untitled/sans titre
994.05.subject: human eye
994.05.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
994.05.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1994
994.05.references:
"Depuis 1980, l'oeuvre de Genevieve Cadieux ne cesse de gagner la reconnaisance de public. Aux frontieres de plusieurs disciplines artistiques, il s'approprie toujours l'espace environnement. En ce sens, il est dont sculpture. De plus, comme le spectateur participe etroitement au dispositif de mise en scene, il est egalement installation : une installation qui, tout au cours de son developpement, a represente le corps dans ce qu'il a a la fois de connu et de mysterieux. Comme si le mecanisme de recherche de Cadieux fonctionne surtout par paires d'opposition, les oeuvres traitent soutent une idee de son contraire. Quoi qu'il en soit, elles stimulent avant tout une approche de nature emotive, et nul ne reste indifferent devant leur puissance et leur richesse virtuelles." (Manon Blanchette, from La collection : Tableau inaugural of the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal, 1992) From an interview between James Lingwood and Genevieve Cadieux, published in Le Journal du Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal, vol. 3, numero 4, Mars, Avril, Mai 1993 : (question) "Est-ce que vous photographiez les yeux pour fouiller la <<politique>> de la regard?" (answer) "Oui, quant au regard. Mais dans Parfum, les yeux ressemblent a des blessures." ("Untitled" is a differently framed, or "cut" print of the left-hand image of the dyptich "Parfum".) In the same interview, Cadieux talks about the relationship between "cutting" and image selection : "Le fait de prendre des images equivait a les couper : on choisit les images, on les travaille, mais elle ne se suivent pas. L'idee de coupure est tres importante dans mon oeuvre : il y a la coupure physique, qui est tres technique et se justifie a partir de limites telles que le format du papier offert uniquement en certaines dimensions. Je ne coupe pas mes oeuvres au hasard : au contraire, mon travail se rapproche du surrealisme par le placement des images. Dans les films surrealistes, on est toujours surpris par la scene suivante, par la rupture de la trame narrative." (pages one and two) In a letter from Rene Blouin to Karen Antaki, we find that the fact that this institution owns a small print by Cadieux is atypical of her usual practice of selling large works to institutions and small to private collectors, as this institution's collection specializes in small, intimate works on paper.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.205-206
-See Jessica Bradley and Lesley Johnstone, eds., “Sightlines,” 1994, pp.71-72

994.06.title: Italian Girl
994.06.keywords: Beaver Hall Group, Canadian Impressionism, Canadians Cross Borders-Europe
994.06.subject: portrait
994.06.credit: Collection of the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery, Concordia University, Max and Iris Stern Acquisition Fund / Collection de la Galerie Leonard et Bina Ellen, Université Concordia, Fonds d’acquisition Max et Iris Stern
994.06.references:
Born May 30, 1885 (Montreal, Canada), died 1971. Studied under William Brymner alongside Mabel May, Nora Collyer, Lilias Newton, Sarah Robertson and Prudence Heward. Exhibited with although never fully participated in the Beaver Hall Hill Group. Influences: Maurice Cullen, James Wilson Morrice. "Acclaimed throughout the first half of her lifetime, she was an unusually talented artist of rare sensitivity. An early exponent of Canadian modernism, Coonan's pictures must now claim their rightful place in the art history of this country." K. Antaki, p 33, Emily Coonan (1885 - 1971). In 1916, Coonan won a Special Prize (a travelling scholarship) from the Women's Art Society for Canadian Women Artist's Work. Because of unfavourable conditions created on the Continent by World War I, departure was delayed until 1920. Although her precise itinerary is unknown, judging from her paintings she visited Florence, Venice and possibly Paris and London. The majority of the works that Coonan produced while in Europe were landscapes, although she is known to have painted at least one portrait, "Italian Girl" (c.1930-31). In this work, Coonan carried forward the formal aesthetic investigation that she had initiated with "The Green Door" (c. 1913), which addressed the understanding and resolution of mass, plane and colour. The repetition of line and play of geometric patterns, as well as the blatant "pose" of the of the figure with no attempt at naturalism all contribute to the monumentality of the figure. What is also striking about this work is its decidedly low-key palette, creating an atmosphere of quietude and simplicity, where the subtlety of the image is reinforced by the even harmony of the internal elements and the enveloping low light.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Like Untitled (Santa Maria Formosa), Italian Girl was also painted on Emily Coonan’s trip to Italy from 1920-21. It clearly demonstrates her tendency toward darker colours, softer outlines, and the use of the figure not as a means for socialist expression, but as a study in formal elements. While the Italian girl has a definite expressiveness and likeness in her face, she has also been stiffly posed in order that her arms might form a rectangle to mirror that of the chair beside her, her body used as a compositional element rather than a descriptor of personality.

994.07.title: Pointe d'étoile
994.07.subject: linear abstraction on triangular support with irregular triangular shapes of red, white and blue
994.07.source: Gift of Richard Dalcourt, 1994 / Don de Richard Dalcourt, 1994
994.07.references:
From the 1992 permanent collection catalogue of the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal (La collection: tableau inaugural), Pierre Landry writes "Des ses toutes premieres oeuvres (dessins, peintures, collages et objets peints realises durant la premiere moitie des annees 60), Serge Lemoyne opte pour une pratique qui excede les traditions automatiste et plasticienne, reconnues comme etant les principales voies de developpement de l'art au Quebec. Certes, cette production initiale presente quelques traites associes a l'esthetique automatiste : abstraction des formes, geste rapide, attention pretee aux qualites expressive de la matiere... Mais au-dela des ses caracteristiques, de nature surtout formelle, la demarche de Lemoyne se distingue tout particulierement par cette liberte dans le choix, toujours changeant, de ses formes d'expression." POINTE D'ETOILE (triangle) is a "tricolour three sided canvas with five irregular triangular shapes in red, white and blue subdividing the surface. Coloured paint splashes across the surface and activates the overall area. ... Point d'etoile (triangle) is an important example of a series of tricolour paintings produced by Serge Lemoyne between 1969 and 1980. Beyond Automatiste and Plasticien roots, the "star" series reflected a concern with the reconciliation of figuration and abstraction, a synthesis of modernist painting and more "popular" preoccupations. A known reference to hockey and national sport symbolically alludes to national identity. Lemoyne's red, white and blue triangular constructions not only relate art historically to the "shaped canvas" but may also be situated within a contemporary discourse that has sought to blur the lines between sculpture and painting. The works produced by Lemoyne during this period were important precedents to the deconstructionist developments seen in his oeuvre from 1980 to the present. Serge Lemoyne occupies an important place in the history of Quebec painting and, by extension, Canadian art history." (Karen Antaki, from the 1994 application for certification of cultural property.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

994.08.title: Gryfon
994.08.subject: pyramid structure on office chair base
994.08.credit: don de/gift of Mme/Mrs. Iona Pilat
994.08.source: Gift of Mrs. Iona Pilat / don de Mme Pilat, 1994
994.08.references:
MFA, Concordia University

Gryfon is described as a "freestanding sculpture on a four wheeled base that originally formed part of an office chair. Mounted above the base is a steel cone shape with gouged and textured surface. ... The importance of Gryfon is contained within an analysis of the artist's overall production. As an early example of her oeuvre it demonstrates the sources of information that, despite radical formal changes over the years, have continued to govern the artist's work. The assembling of "found" elements drawn from an urban environment with imaginary forms, reflects an interest in exploring the contradictory nature of experience and perception. The cone and wheel shapes in this work are precedents to an industrially inspired iconography now seen in the artist's large scale sculptures. Liliana Berezowsky's growing reputation as a Canadian sculptor residing in Quebec contributes to the national significance of this work." (Karen Antaki, 1994 application for certification of cultural property)

994.09.title: Bruised Manhattan
994.09.subject: gestural abstraction of city-scape
994.09.color: wide range of tones and colours
994.09.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
994.09.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowement / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1994

994.10.title: Vanishing Point
994.10.subject: landscape, cartography
994.10.source: Gift of Mr. Ronald Noël / don de M. Ronald Noël, 1994
994.10.references:
"Artiste dont le travail a atteint une renommee internationale, Barbara Steinman realise des oeuvres qui appartiennent au monde de l'installation. Associant photographie, video et sculpture, elles sont souvent des monuments qui mettent en scene non pas des personnes illustres mais des laisses-pour-compte, des inconnues, des anonymes. Steinman revendique le droit a la nuance, denoncant le fait qu'il existe toujours au moin deux versions d'un meme evenement historique: l'officiel, liee au collectif, et l'individuelle ou la particuliere - autrement dit, la version autorisee et celle qui ne l'est pas. En se questionnant sur le mecanisme historique qui rend possible pareille selection, elle prend position politiquement. Afin d'atteindre son objectif politique, Steinman privilegie l'etude du language, mediatise par l'image et le mot. Une fois restituee au present, l'information historique se revele au grand jour, avec tous les types de manipulations et de pouvoir qu'elle implique." MANON BLANCHETTE, in La collection: tableau inaugurale, a permanent collection catalogue of the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal "In "Vanishing Point" (1991), Steinman again questions how technology has affected our view of the natural world. Four large panels are based on a glowing, abstracted map. Printed on top of this abstract field are different permutations of the same material: William Ruttlesby's mid-19th century, stereoscopic photograph of the Scottish coast, and the fragment of a radar map. The work resembles a series of charts depicting pairs of eyes. The combined elements seem to refer both to vision as well as the soul, which in Ruttlesby's time was thought to be perceived in a person's eyes." (24-25) (Barbara London: "Visionary Transformations". essay written for the catalogue Uncertain Monuments, an exhibition organized by the Mackenzie Art Gallery, and held from April 24 - August 2, 1992. Touring to the Windsor Art Gallery from November 27, 1993 - January 24, 1994. In the 1994 application for certification of cultural property, Karen Antaki describes Vanishing Point as follows "Vanishing Point consists of four framed cibachrome photographs mounted on masonite. These four panels are paired one above the other, frame against frame. Each panel consists of two centrified spheres superimposed upon a blue ground created by the use of aerial views. The images within the spheres depict varied details of a mountain landscape, creating a complex visual interplay between both positive and negative photographic elements in the work. ... In Vanishing Point, Barbara Steinman's focus is on the description of landscape as a vehicle for the investigation of issues related to optical vision versus social perspective. This concern has been an integral component within Steinman's overall production. It demonstrates her ongoing interest in the use of photography as technological determinant in the social production of visual meaning. Here, through the photographic manipulation of the pictured landscape, its representational significance is relocated within the context of culturally constructed yet personally experienced vision." It is a superb example by a leading contemporary Canadian artist
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See Jessica Bradley and Lesley Johnstone, eds., “Sightlines,” 1994, p.71

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Barbara Steinman’s work in photography, sculpture, and installation has explored a variety of social issues and historical times, but remains constant in its probing of the reality of individual versus collective consciousness, history, and perception. Creating intersections between art, science, and technology, she often refers to the human body while situating it within a wider historical or spiritual realm that ties it to the collective of society. In Vanishing Point, perception becomes the key issue, in particular how technology affects our vision of the world. Superimposing mid nineteenth century photographs of the Scottish coast by William Ruttlesby and fragments of radar maps onto bluish glowing aerial views, she contrasts ways of seeing in terms of proximity, detail, and even motivation. At the same time her circular forms refer to time and space, sun and moon, set against the blue of the aerial maps like four pairs of eyes steadily reflecting the viewer’s gaze.

994.11.title: Portrait of a Young Boy
994.11.keywords: Eastern Group of Painters, Group-Contemporary Arts Society, Canadian Group of Painters, Figuration-portrait
994.11.subject: interior, seated semi-dressed boy, figure study - flattened backgound, prominance of sitter
994.11.color: tones of green, ochre, brown, etc.
994.11.source: Gift of Mr. Bram Garber / don de M. Bram Garber, 1993
994.11.references:
Portrait of a Young Boy is described as a "portrait of a seated young male adolescent painted in tones of green, ochre, brown, etc." ... "Portrait of a Young Boy (c. 1942-43) is an outstanding example of Roberts' series of adolescent portraits begun in the early 1940s. It is characterised by a formal resemblance, clarity of line and forthrightness typical of Roberts' approach to the portraits of his cousin's children, Ian, Archie and Flora. This depiction of Ian demonstrates the flattened background and slight prominence of the sitter that is both compatible with the artist's relationship to his young models, and that also distinguishes the children's portraits from the larger body of figure works." (Karen Antaki, 1994 application for certification of cultural property)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.14-15, 23, 30, 74
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, pp.309, 310, 312, 332, 344
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.208-212, 214, 331

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Portrait of a Young Boy is a study of Roberts’ nephew, Ian, part of a series of adolescent figure studies made by the artist during the 1940’s. Here Roberts portrays the figure of the young boy without social symbolism or the sentimentality frequently found in images of adolescents by other artists of the same period. Stylistically, the painting reflects his interest in achieving a resemblance to the figure, and highlighting it by silhouetting it against a flat background, a feature distinguishing it from his larger body of figurative work.

994.12.title: Seated Young Girl
994.12.keywords: Eastern Group of Painters, Group-Contemporary Arts Society, Canadian Group of Painters, Figuration-individual
994.12.subject: interior, seated dressed girl with dark braids, figure study - tactile, fluid application of paint tending towards abstraction
994.12.color: predominant tones of blue and beige
994.12.source: Gift of Bram Garber / don de Bram Garber, 1994
994.12.references:
In the Ellen Art Gallery's 1994 cultural property application Karen Antaki describes "Seated Young Girl" as an "image of a female adolescent with pigtails seated against a bare backdrop. Painted in predominant tones of blue and beige. ... This work is an important example of the portraits painted by Goodridge Roberts during the middle phase of his career. Painted on masonite, which Roberts employed almost exclusively from the fifties onwards, it demonstrates a heightened tactility and surface dynamics characteristic of this period. A fluidity in the application of paint contributes to an overall less structured effect and a tendency towards greater abstraction. The painting is in excellent condition, and represents an outstanding contribution by a major Canadian artist and has considerable national significance."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.14-15, 23, 30, 74
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, pp.309, 310, 312, 332, 344
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.208-212, 214, 331

994.13.title: Angry Rabbit
994.13.subject: stylized rabbit's head
994.13.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
994.13.source: Purchase - Acquisition Fund / achat- Fonds de dotation, 1994
994.13.references: Drawings of rabbits act as an iconographic constant throughout John Scott's body of work, in counterpoint to more apocalyptic vehicles of destruction and industry. Following is an exerpt from Joan Murray's EDGE CITY (1994, The Robert McLaughlin Gallery, Oshawa, Ontario): "9) The bunny-people grew out of thousands of drawings Scott had made over the years (mostly during the early 70s) of what he called "the little hearts" or the heart people: small stick-like creatures with hearts for heads. A funny and ingenious compression of the idea of vulnerability, of the sweet passivity and tragic powerlessness of passion over reason, the little hearts came to seem like a sort of proletariat of the emotions, a collective of caring, polymorphous mass agents (like fleshy and ineffectual Eloi of H.G. Well's The Time Machine) of feeling alone - and therefore utter victims of the dark unknowable vehicles and weapons of reason's high (that is, unfathomable) technology. Over the years of Scott's compulsive drawing of these poignant little heart people, the twin roundedness of their valentine heart-shapes somehow became elongated and grew into ears - and the bunnies. 10) What purpose did these bunnies serve? The bunny people were a graphic language of social protest. They were homeless masses yearning to understand what was happening to them. They were an epic unscrolling of an entire milieu for Scott, an accumulated question, an objective correlation for victimization. ... Iconographically, the bunnies were diametrically opposed, within the body of Scott's work, to the space vehicles and murderous jet bombers which precede them (but which continue to turn up from time to time). 11) How were the bunnies read? Sometimes, as an unattractive hopelessness, whereby Scott was seen as the mere poser of questions about social injustices and global truths, a questioner without answers, without proposals, mired in passivity. To see them in this way is to forget that the bunnies are the gentle half of an unfinished dialogue between victims and victimizer (ie the vehicles and the weapons). In no sense does Scott imagine the artist's project to be the production of detached objects of work. For Scott, the Bunnies and the bombers were locked in an ideological embrace about the axis of cause and effect. The great vehicles and techno-destroyers, as Scott saw them, dictated the shape of the world. The bunnies were the frenetic symptoms of this threatening shaping force. ... they flowed from Scott's brush more like the evidence of a performance than as discrete and commodity value drawings. The bunny-epic was often produced under circumstances whereby whatever statement Scott was making should be of necessity temporary, transitory. In effect, the bunnies were always more utterence than artifact. 12) In the course of directing his epic flow of graphic bunnies, Scott found that just as the hearts had modulated into bunnies, so the bunnies were losing their normal anthropomorphically orthodox outlines and growing more and more distorted. Late bunnies are, in fact, very frequently about bodily distortion (a head grows directly out of a midriff, an upraised arm turns into a serpent, eyes stare out of an abdomen and so on). ... 15) Is there any end to this? Something of the sort, a direction at least. Scott always seems to be slung between two poles of experience, poles that differ in character and mode but are steadfast in their fertile generative oppositeness. The bunny-people that occupied him for so long now seem, he told me recently, "delerious." The product of a fever of caring?" (Gary Michael Dault, "Prolegomena to a Study to the Drawings of John Scott" (Preparation for a catalogue for a 1984 exhibition in Lethbridge, Alberta, revised in 1986).

994.15.references: Fritz Brandtner was born in Danzig, in 1896. In 1928, after serving in World War I, studying art, art history and architecture, teaching life classes and working as a freelance commercial designer for advertising and display, he emigrated to Canada. After spending some time in an immigrant camp, he chose to settle in Winnipeg, at 707 Sherbrooke St. N. He first found work as a house painter, then as a commercial artist with Brigden's of Winnipeg Limited, working on the design and layout of Eaton's mail order catalogue until 1934. During that period, he came into contact with the Canadian artists Caven Atkins, Eric Bergman, Bertram Brooker, Lionel Lemoine FitzGerald, Walter Phillips and Phillip Surrey. Experimented in abstraction. Fritz Brandtner and his wife moved to Montreal in March 1934, at which time they met and became friends with Dr. Norman Bethune, .

994.26.title: Untitled/sans titre (tree study)
994.26.subject: tree
994.26.color: black, mustard, green, red and brown
994.26.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
994.26.references: Information only available up to 1984. From the Sandra Paikovsky catalogue essay to "Michael Jolliffe: Thirteen Paintings/Treize tableaux" (Concordia Art Gallery, 1984) "Born in Darlington, England in 1945, [Michael Jolliffe] came to Ontario in 1963, and moved to Vancouver two years later. ... [H]e studied at the Vancouver School of Art from 1971 to 1975, gravitating toward the printmakers because of their serious and energetic attitudes. ... With Gary Bowden, Renee Van Halm, Robert Evermond and others, he helped found the Malaspina Printmaking Society as a catalyst for Wes Coast printmakers. While he did do some painting at the School, he had earlier been involved in some acting and set decoration for the theatre. Jolliffe has likened painting to work in the theatre as both require "a search to find the essence of the character; to build something out of a predefined role." In 1975 he left Vancouver for Montreal to do graduate study [at Concordia University]. Although he had worked with figuration in Vancouver, in Montreal he exhibited minimalist paintings and drawings as well as the occasional conceptual piece. Like many of his contemporaries, he worked his way through reductivist art, returning to "borderline" figurative painting. But he had little commitment to a persuasive subject matter and "no sense of responsibility about what I painted." The turning point came in 1980. Jolliffe discovered Christianity and had the sense that he had "been touched by something greater than myself." This epiphanic episode provided him with a sense of order, freedom and responsibility: "It allowed me to think about what I wanted to paint and I now had a real relationship with painting." For the past four years Jolliffe has devoted himself to painting Christian parables, a subject matter that has made his critics uncomfortable. But he does not "intend the pictures to be only didactic; if so, they would be of a different composition."

Cette oeuvre a été présentée dans l'exposition collective « This is Montréal! », Galerie Leonard & Bina Ellen, 13 mars - 19 avril 2008.

994.28.title: Om
994.28.subject: geometric abstraction
994.28.credit: Gift of/don de Doris and/et Mulla May
994.28.source: Gift of Doris and Mulla May / don de Doris et Mulla May, 1994
994.28.references:
"En interrogeant sans cesse la sensation pure et la matiere coloree, l'oeuvre de Rita Letendre se trouve a la croisee des chemins entre une peinture abstrait montrealaise et acception geometrique. Il est peu d'examples durant les annees 50 d'une volonte aussi determinee chez une femme artiste dont le discours questionne une approche plus structuree et rationnelle de la peinture, ce qui la distingue de la premiere generation des automatistes. ..." (Pierre Granche, in La Collection: Tableau inaugurale of the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal, 1992) "The route of this painter through lyric abstraction to hard edge technique, issues in her recent paintings in a luminosity no longer directly dependent on a Cartesian order of forms. The chromatic prisms, perceived in these paintings as the energizers of the surface, create the tensions of light that are the essential matter of her recent work." (Gilles Toupin, Artscanada, January 1973) "In the 50's and early 60's this Montreal girl was already considered to be one of the most promising Cnadaian artists. She had found in the "automatiste" movement the craving for self-expression that befitted her undaunted, yet disciplined temperament. ... Her evolution has followed the path of inner logic. The chaos of her early paintings was only apparent at first sight. A second look would reveal a search for light and form. This she tried and succeeded in achieving through a series of black and white canvases where the triangular masses of black inherent in her previous paintings took on a geometric shape. These masses, however, had a weight, and often acted as wedges that tended to bend a line in the lower part of the canvas. They met at a focal point and exploded the light. The impasto was disappearing and the black as well as the white were becoming pure light. Now she was ready for her new adventure with colour. As is often the case, a change of medium liberates the new, incoming surging mutation in style. Rita Letendre began to master silk-screen techique and to modulate the light by adding colour to it, so to speak. In fact, as evidenced by her latest works, she was still concerned with speed, not of the gesture this time, but of light/colour itself. She felt free to use her trademark colours of black, deep red, yellows and whites to create, with the same power of meditation, in serigraphs or paintings that would vibrate and explode in a very concerted way." (Gilles Huneault, reprinted from Artscanada, vol 138/39 in a catalogue which accompanied an exhibition held in the Palm Springs Desert Museum, California in 1974) The artist's file has extensive material on the period in which this work was made.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.71-74
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, p.342
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, p.291

994.29.title: Le Rêve des vignerons
994.29.subject: gestural abstraction
994.29.source: Gift of Yves Deydier / don d'Yves Deydier, 1994
994.29.references:
From the Ellen Art Gallery application for Certification of Cultural Property, Karen Antaki describes "Le reve des vignerons" as: "A lyrical, abstracted landscape executed in a naturalistic palette of ochre, green and yellow. Strands of woven brushmarks are superimposed upon an atmospheric field of colour to create a surface that is both dynamic and elegiacal. ... This painting is an excellant example of the artist's continuing interest in the depiction of sites of human passage, both natural and constructed. It demonstrates his concerns with expanding our understanding of the traditional `paysage' genre, and his ongoing interest in probing its symbolic possibilities. Produced in 1988, it anticipates his slightly later frescoes on found objects, where the inclusion of `real' materials amplifies the significance attached to the works as markers of human experience."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

994.30.title: Wall-Mounted Flying Stereotype
994.30.subject: ceramic figure (illuminated by a green fluorescent light) whose face is magnified by a lens
994.30.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l'artiste
994.30.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1994
994.30.references:
Wall-Mounted Flying Stereotype is a "small ceramic figure suspended horizontally from the wall surface. It is illuminated by a green flourescent light. The face of the figure is magnified by a lens placed directly before it. ... Produced in 1991, this piece belongs to a body of work that marked a radical change in formal approach and execution from the artist's large, technologically sophisticated sculptures while at the same time continuing his concerns with issues surrounding the nature and mechanisms of perception, and the concept of the `debased' figure and the grotesque. Roland Brener's contribution to contemporary Canadian art and the discourse that surrounds it, in addition to the unique character of this work, renders "Wall-Mounted Flying Stereotype" of major significance." (Karen Antaki, from the 1994 application for certification of Cultural Property)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, p.230
-See Jessica Bradley and Lesley Johnstone, eds., “Sightlines,” 1994, p.71

written by Martine Fournier:

Working in Victoria, British Columbia since 1972, Roland Brener uses large sculptures and installations, usually involving sound and movement, to comment on the relationship between humanity and machinery, the effects of mass communication, and what he calls the “debased figure” in society. Wall-Mounted Flying Stereotype is part of a later series that represents a departure from Brener’s previous large and technologically complex sculptural work. In the series of flying stereotypes, which includes a mobile of over-sized stereotypical heads such as a First Nations man in a feather headdress and a black boy in a straw hat, Brener works on a more intimate scale, yet is still concerned with the themes of debased person, of grotesqueness, and the impact of mass communication. Wall-Mounted Flying Stereotype is a small ceramic figure suspended from the wall, lit luridly with green light, face magnified by a lens placed in front of it. With this, and the rest of the series, Brener questions not only society’s racism but what we consider to be a present-day sense of liberalism.

994.32.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l'artiste
994.32.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1995
994.32.references:
"These black and white photographs form part of a series of twelve produced by the artist in 1993. Unique in focus, medium and approach in terms of the artist's overall oeuvre they are also literal representations of his work, serving to frame the underlying concerns informing his recent production. As distinct views of Brener's installation Capital Z (National Gallery of Canada) they serve to expand the meaning and parameters of this source work while maintaining their own formal integrity." (Karen Antaki, 1994 application for certification of cultural property)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, p.230
-See Jessica Bradley and Lesley Johnstone, eds., “Sightlines,” 1994, p.71
