995.02.title: Fontaine Divona (Cahors) vue de la Rive
995.02.subject: landscape with figure
995.02.source: Purchase- General Acquisition / achat- acquisition général, 1995
995.02.references:
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
Denis Farley
Fontaine Divona (Cahors vue de la rive)
“The seven large-scale, colour photographs selected for this exhibition stem from a recent commission to record, in relationship with the artist’s own works, “landmarks” in the Cahors region of France. The sites were chosen by Farley for their dual appeal as regional reference points of aesthetic interest ...Poetically inspired and historically laden, his topographical paysages engage our senses and arouse our intellectual interest through an orchestrated re-presentation of an observed image field.
As in Denis Farley’s overall recent production, this series entitled Repérages, double mesures demonstrates his ongoing interest in probing the nature and mechanisms of observation and its relationship to our apprehension of the physical world...his interest in exploring the process of photography may be situated within a discourse concerned with issues attached to perceptual authenticity and conventions of sight.” (Karen Antaki, Press Release, Denis Farley: Recent Photographs, Feb 21- Mar 21, 1995) 

“The works selected for this exhibition stem from a recent commission to record, in relationship with the artist’s own work, ‘landmarks’ in the Cahors region of France...In almost all cases, the pictured settings are evocative of the past, depicting structures that are deserted, architecturally eroded, or otherwise distanced from their original purpose...In this series, it is the inclusion of a satellite dish (or at times a broken plaster cast of the same dish shape) as an integral formal component upon which the images appear, that renders the pictured landscape at once more focused and unknown.”
...“He employs the tent  camera obscura with a modified surveyor’s tripod, a mirror and a lens to produce his images. The moveable tent structure within which the subject is situated and recorded allows for a multipositioning of both observer and observed. A beam of light , reflected from the mirror through the lens, floods the satellite dish (or broken cast), as well as the ground upon which it is placed. Once photographed , the representation of the dish appears to merge with the ground and the image field, displacing the subject and, at the same time, creating a sense of visual coherence that appears naturalistic but is not... In fragmenting the dishes....these shards take possession of the ‘real’ world surface, drawing new ground into the overall picture, in much the same way as selective vision encroaches upon corporeal verity....His evocative landscapes compel our imagination and encourage us to consider the constructs attached to contemporary visual thought and the dynamics of visual perception itself.” (Karen Antaki, Denis Farley , Feb 21-Mar 21, 1995, Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery)

“Denis Farley’s present work stems from his research into pre-photographic optics and the use of the camera obscura as an observation tool...Originally the tent camera obscura allowed the tent camera obscura allowed the observer to position the observatory anywhere in the landscape and then sit tracing the image as projected onto a sheet of paper...Farley alludes to the complexities of 20th century society and how we observe, perceive and in fact survey ourselves...”(Peter Sramek, foreword, Denis Farley: Simultaneous Trans/Positions Vu and Gallery 44, Centre for Contemporary Photography, 1993)
...”Maybe it is the way they invert what seemed a rather ordinary reality, reminding us of our transience, our tendency to prereflectiveneness and selective blindness, replete with perceptual preconceptions... (James Campbell, “At the Threshold of The Image, The Dream: Remarks on the Photoworks of Denis Farley,”  Denis Farley: Simultaneous Trans/Positions Vu and Gallery 44, Centre for Contemporary Photography, 1993)
...Farley’s work also broaches issues related to surveillance technology and the laws of opticality, and is full of ironic commentary on ‘straight photography’, which it simultaneously enacts and steps outside of)

995.03.title: Grand Amphithéâtre, According to Horizon
995.03.subject: architectural interior
995.03.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
995.03.source: Purchase- Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat- Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art. 1995
995.03.references:
From the Power Plant catalogue/show "Alain Paiement: Amphitheatres" (10 March - 23 April 1989) : "The Quebec artist Alain Paiement, whose first exhibition was held in Montreal in the early 80s ... [through his concern] with various systems of mapping, including those employed by scientific disciplines such as meteorology and geography, ... is ... closely aligned with conceptualism, the "undertow" of the Modern/Postmodern debate. His work shares with conceptual art an interest in systems of signification - the way in which meanings are (re)produced rather than naturally given, including those of art itself. Yet, while sharing conceptual art's self-referential interests, Paiement's work distances itself from conceptualism's more recent emphasis on the semiotic critique of representation by means of photo-montage and textual components. Rather, it seeks to address, in specifically visual terms, systems of visual transcription, including topography. (p. 3-4) ... Paiement's most recent body of works, which he has mounted under the general title of Amphitheatres, ... are concerned with the specular relation between subject and object as posited by modernist discourse. ... Amphitheatre Bachelard (1988) and Grand Amphitheatre: Horizontal Planisphere (1989), ... at once name and represent two ... amphitheatres ... found at the Sorbonne, Paris. Both works consist of a series of photographs taken in the above-named theatres, from a fixed position in the upper periphery of the theatre space. The camera is set on the course of a voracious consumption: panning the entire hall in several complete and systematic horizontal rotations - beginning in the centre of the ceiling and gradually moving downward in full rotations all the way to the floor - the photographs yield in all-encompassing panoramic, that is, "panoptic" view. ... Paiement's photographic project here appears propelled by the desire towards the horizon of the infinite ... This desire is a belief in the infinite ability of science, technology, and capitalism to realize and to make concrete the infinitude of ideas: "knowing all, being capable of all, and having all." Historically, panoramic mappings such as Paiement's would have been mounted within a sphere or rotunda, so as to restore, if illusionistically, the depth and all-around view of the pictured space for a viewer positioned at its centre. In Grand Amphitheatre: Horizontal Planisphere (1989), however, Paiement utilizes the photographs in an unusual and startling manner, which at once emphasized their peculiar status as a material surface representing at once the empirical perception (registration) of an existing space, and its speculative mapping through the grid of an a priori cartographic system. The pictures yielded by this procedure - reassembled by way of a montage - constitute a full rotational view of the theatre's interior. Yet, in order to accomodate the spherical topography on a flat surface, the montage has been ripped and cut, leaving only the "equator" - the longest circumference - intact. Unlike those maps which seem to compensate for the distortion of the earth's surface when reproduced on a two-dimensional page, Grand Amphitheatre - Horizontal Planisphere cannot cancel the violence and impossibility of such transcription: the surface of the photographic paper still protrudes in heavy waves, rather than settling into its supposedly flat position on the wall. The visual surface (or perceptual skin) yields both puzzling and violent distortions, which are due to as much to the unforgiving materiality of the paper as to the compression or distension incurred by the various distances of the theatre's circumference in relation to the camera lens."(p 9-10) Barbara Fischer N.B., the complete text can be found in the artist's file.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

995.04.title: The 401 Towards London: Monument
995.04.subject: highway landscape
995.04.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
995.04.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1995
995.04.references:
Part of the (Jack Chambers) 401 - Westbound series. In PARACHUTE Greg Beatty wrote "In "The 401 Towards London: Median" (1991), Sheila Ayearst presents a painting based on a 1968 painting by photo-realist Jack Chambers of the highway leading to London, Ontario. As a genre, photo-realism is given more credibility as a representational medium than other forms of painting because photorealists work from photographs of their subject. But whereas Chambers' painting is bright and sunny, Ayearst has made several strategic revisions - a lower vantage point, a cloudy, polluted sky, a tire track on the grassy median - which creates a more ominous atmosphere. The overall effect is to shift our attention from the distant horizon to a specific spot on a highway where four women were murdered in 1991. Thus, Ayearst injects an element of danger in Chambers' optimistic vision of modern urban society. She also leaves a strip of canvas at the top of her painting so that it resembles a snapshot framed by a white border. This emphasizes the contrived nature of her reconstructed narrative." (41) In her introductory essay Ingrid Jenkner wrote: "This privileging of painting in a transaesthetic blend Ayearst achieves in "The 401 Towards London: Verge", 1990, a large oil [same dimensions as "Monument"] which is presented without photographic accessories. Its complex connections to the history of painting and to mass culture emerge through the union of traditional technique with a contemporary gothic landscape setting. The title refers us to Jack Chambers's work of 1968-69; the oil glaze technique, palette and locale to Homer Watson's brittle, dreamlike Doon landscapes of the 1880s ... Yet ... this is Sheila Ayearst's painting, not her copy of someone else's work. As an allegorist who uses already existing images and stories in her own work, Sheila Ayearst relies on combinative procedures (intertextuality) to recuperate old meanings. The effect of this is affirmative, ... since it does not challenge the belief systems that produced the source paintings, so much as it redeems the past for the present. In this sense, Ayearst's references to paintings by Ozias Leduc and his spiritual inheritor Jack Chambers (401 Towards London, 1968-69) are especially interesting for their openness to transcendence as a specific content in painting." SOURCES: Greg Beatty, "Visual Evidence." review of show at the Dunlop Art Gallery, Regina, October 16 - November 28, 1993 in PARACHUTE 74; Ingrid Jenkner, "Verge: Sheila Ayearst"; catalogue for an exhibition at the Macdonald Stewart Art Centre, Guelph, Ontario. 1 December 1990 - 3 February, 1991

written by Martine Fournier:

Having obtained her B.F.A. from York University in 1977, Sheila Ayearst has since been exploring the relationship between self and other, present and past, and what she considers to be the magical space in between. During the early 1980’s, she was making over the frescoes of Giotto, intrigued by his interest in the mediating space between saints and their God. She went on to juxtapose copies of “old Master” paintings with photographic/textual images taken from contemporary magazines and newspapers. In this task Ayearst saw herself as setting up a dialogue between the disorder of the present and the ordered paintings of the past, creating a collision of two different visions of the world.
    In The 401 Towards London: Monument, 1991, Ayearst responds again to the history of art, reinterpreting a painting of the 401made by Jack Chambers some 20 years before. While Chambers saw the view out his rearview mirror on the highway as an epiphanous experience of what he called “perceptual realism,” an overwhelmingly complete and perfect vision, Ayearst explores how, as a woman of the late twentieth century, she is both compelled by and excluded from Chambers’ vision. Her painting reflects on the murder of four women who were abducted near the 401during the early 1990’s, offering a darkened vision of the highway as crime scene, highlighting what she considers to be our “misplaced perceptions of security” in the modern world, and the relative naïvete of Chambers’ interpretation. She continues here to clash the present with the past, contrasting contemporary settings with traditional painting techniques, earlier images with her own fresh interpretations. 

written by Mark A. Cheetham in the London Regional Art and Historical Museums Sheila Ayearst: the 401 Towards London catalogue: “Sheila Ayearst is an artist who thinks very carefully about past art, its motivations and material presence. Since 1989, she has been working with imagery and sites canonized by Jack Chambers’ painting of Highway 401. In part, she is interested in how these works partake of a very old art language, that of the sublime, a category of unpresentable yet awe-inspiring phenomena and experiences.
Ayearst feels noth attracted to and barred from the epiphany encapsulated in this sort of painting. Chambers initially saw the view painted in the 401 paintings in the rearview mirror as he was driving from London to Toronto. He wanted to capture the scene, so he drove onto the Woodstock overpass and took a photograph to work from later. For him, the original perception was a ‘Wow’ experience, a realization that .anything that one sees is in its actual presence also more than we can in any one way understand it to be.’ The completeness and perfection of the experience overwhelms us; Chambers’ artistic response, which he called ‘perceptual realism,’ attempts to record this sublimity, and the painting is therefore inclusive, commanding.
Ayearst believes that her position as a woman in the late 20th century makes ‘this kind of personal “religious” vision of art unavailable.’ But she doesn’t simply reject Chambers’ vision or indeed the medium of painting. Compelled by the promise of this privileged access, yet ultimately ambivalent towards it, she records ‘the other artist’s sublime experience with nature.’ But even though she works in the same size and medium, she changes Chambers’ presentation in ways that alert us to her differences from his enabling attitudes.
Chambers’ 401 has the specificity of an overview: it’s clear where it is - even today, with all the changes in the area - but in a sense the scene is short on details because particulars have been sacrificed to inclusiveness. Ayearst, by contrast, often takes us very close to the road. In The 401 Towards London: Median 1990, for example, the viewpoint is low, near the grass in the median strip. In the distance, we see the bridge from which Chambers composed his view. Up close on the left, we see tire tracks in the gravel. Not only has Ayearst literally and metaphorically reversed Chambers’ image, but in this and others in the series, she marks where her source photo doesn’t fit with his ‘original.’ The 401 Towards London: Verge 1990 is even more explicit about the difference in ‘viewpoint’: we see a car stopped on the verge, a vehicle with which  Ayearst announces the overriding theme of this and much of her other recent work: ‘misplaced perceptions of security.’
In the early 90s, four women were abducted from or near the 401. All were murdered. ‘The failure of the “modern” (superhighay/suburbia) to efficiently deliver security,’ she writes, ‘is paralleled with the disintegration of the painted representation moving out from the centre of the canvas.’ With this perspective in mind, Chambers’ view begins to look naive or at least innocent, and sublime transcendence offends us in its wilful blindness to reality.
Ayearst’s 401 paintings both subvert and exploit the aesthetics of the sublime. She refutes the transcendent view cherished by CHambers by insisting on specifics, both of appearance and history. As Naomi Schor has convincingly argued in Reading in Detail, in art, ‘the detail is gendered...as feminine’ and it can therefore counter the ‘anti-particularist aesthetic’ of the sublime. Ayearst presents the danger in an ‘ordinary’ scene and perhaps even relies - like the crime photos in which she is interested - on a viewer’s morbid pleasure in looking at such disasters from a relatively safe vantage. No doubt we all sometimes wish to avoid or even forget the horrors of contemporary society. Ayearst’s ambivalent sublime doesn’t let us off so easily; where, her images force us to ask, is the line between art and ‘real’ experience?”

Written by Andy Patton in the same catalogue: “Her (Ayearst’s) own paintings after Chambers might be a kind of tarnishing, a rusting away of possibilities during the years that now separate his time from ours. But this doesn’t mean that her paintings are simply a form of mourning, or a nostalgia for the past: at this point in time painting can only enter the present by admitting its diminishment. It is no longer the vehicle for a transcendent light. (...) Like all paintings, Ayearst’s paintings are concerned with appearances - but they are like a thorough-going atheism, no faith in God, light, or painting. Nor do her works share the kind of technological optimism that seems to shine out from Chambers’ painting: that faith in the newly laid ribbon of asphalt running from London to Toronto and beyond.
But Ayearst’s paintings aren’t simply a kind of negation-in-paint of Chambers’ painting. I think they’re far more ambiguous than that, because, in their referring back to his work, they keep it constantly in mind, and thus hold it as a possibility even while denying that such a light, or such a belief in painting could be possible now. Perhaps this is in part the result of painting’s peculiar present tense in which Chamers’ painting, that was done some twenty-odd years before Ayearst’s, and her own, now exist in the same moment. Both, now, can only be seen in this present in which we live, even if one preceded the other in time. That fact of precedence is all that allows Ayearst’s paintings to be built on his - and yet now they are both jumbled together in the only time in which things can be seen: now.
Perhaps Chambers’ painting becomes doubled: it is seen as then and now. And perhaps Ayearst’s paintings subject themselves to something weirdly similar. They are all done in that deliberately dated style which preceded the style in which Chambers worked by more than a century - even though her work followed his. So her works impel themselves backward, not just by referring to Chambers’ painting, but by utilizing this dated style that seems to mire them in history, a then that is not now, a then that precedes Chambers’ painting, even though the mere fact of referring to Chambers at all means that they had to come later.
I don’t think that it is clear at all where in time Ayearst’s paintings exist, only that they are not lost in it. I wonder if it’s nto here - in this confounding of time - that Ayearst’s paintings show the working of a deeply hidden faith, after all, because it is here, in this confounding of presents and pasts, that the pastness of the past is undone. And so all the possibilities that the past recorded, and which have been relegated to the prison of history, can be released in a present tense which only functions by admitting that it too is already past.

995.05.title: Trinita dei Monti
995.05.subject: cityscape (Rome)
995.05.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
995.05.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1995
995.05.references:
"Pierre Dorion is among the most important representatives of contemporary painting in Canada. Over the past fifteen years, he has created an autonomous and complex body of work that has achieved an almost classic maturity in the "Autoportrait" and "Roman Image" paintings of recent years. With great intellectual sharpness, Pierre Dorion reflects the ambiguity of modern existence in the schism between emotional inclinations, openness and empathy, and the simultaneous scepticism and critical distance with regard to what one sees." (Loretta Yarlow, introduction to catalogue "Pierre Dorion") For an extensive, general discussion of Pierre Dorion's "Roman Images" series (to which "Trinita dei Monti" belongs), please see "Insomnia in an Uncertain Place" (p 23-31, Pierre Dorion catalogue) by Jose Lebrero Stals (translated from the Spanish by Kim Bradley) as well as "A Backwards Glance" by Catherine Crowston (p 15 - 21, Pierre Dorion catalogue).
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See Jessica Bradley and Lesley Johnstone, eds., “Sightlines,” 1994, p.302
Pierre Dorion
Trinita Dei Monti (1994)
... “Pierre Dorion’s own particular European tour brought him to Rome , where he stayed several months in 1991...he photographed the places he visited during his stay. They are notes, amateur snapshots, the fruit of the desire to register what he saw: churches , palaces, parks and interiors in the dense historic-architectonic web of the Italian capital. Originally archived, they have been taken out again in his Montreal studio to be converted into the referential images of a body of work that he systematically initiated in the winter of 1993-94. Dorion’s previous , extensive series of self portraits allowed him to structure a “personalized” system of representation within a conceptually objective and formal vocabulary characterized by transverseness, a quality which continues manifesting itself...
In this recent series of urban landscapes and interiors painted in 1994, however Dorion carries out a decisive adjustment that, if it does not in any way signify a betrayal of the synthetic pictorial language proposed in his prior work, it does constitute a fertile advance in the investigation that he is carrying out with and about modes of representation. He opts for smaller formats and for flatness to reinforce the optical association with the traditional (Jose Lebrero Stals, “Insomnia in an Uncertain Place” Pierre Dorion Art Gallery of York University, 1995 p.23) illusionistic window. The selected motifs are habitable places although they are deserted  . The illusionism of the proposed images, however is truncated with formal games: transitional zones approaching abstraction are established within the compositions . The modular partition, the theatricality and monumentality of the Autoportraits have been suppressed , as well as the additive methods of collage thorough which he included real objects in the composition of the image. In this way, his investigations of the perceptual ambiguity of painting are now strictly sustained within the traditional means of representation , augmenting the friction between the flat, literal surface and motifs represented. What makes the result especially peculiar is the artificial and soiled appearance of the waxy-textured , veiled images, as difficult to associate with the natural world of physical objects as with the “plastic reality” of non-figuration...The interior space which dominated the prior work has become exteriorized...These solitary landscapes and interiors give rise to questions about notions of newness and evolution in a type of painting like his, which , like all present day ones, he inherited from a moribund but still operative tradition. Starting from this premise, Dorion’s objective consists of generating art that assumes a role that is supposedly contradictory, simultaneously “modern” and “traditional”. His is synthetic elaboration of paintings where one finds forms originating from both...modernism and...the traditional, in dialectical equilibrium. Dorion considers himself a Northern painter fascinated by the impression historic Rome made upon him...Rome, then becomes the...provisional excuse for an artistic trip in an open process in which the discursive coordinated are at the same time retrovisionary and innovative.
	“Analogically, this work would be rewinding of art history to the point when Corot travelled to Rome, but in the North American present in which I live. During my stay in that city, I studied the tradition of Northern painters who lived there a long time, why they went there and why they painted. I relate it to the questioning of ideas of modern art, which, to my understanding, began with the founding of Impressionism.” (All quotes are taken from an interview with the artist, November 1994, Montreal)(Jose Lebrero Stals, “Insomnia in an Uncertain Place” Pierre Dorion Art Gallery of York University, 1995, p.25)...He tries to approach the motif instinctively, as Corot would have in his Roman studies. He configures inventive devices of representation , divorcing himself interpretively from veduta, from what happened in the first place and in the photograph afterwards, from that which one saw naturally and that which one supposes the artist would have to reproduce. As an alternative, he opts for a sort of capriccio or a topographical bastard and virtual fantasy picture, impossible to locate or recognize in the world of things beyond the painted scene. He outlines, for example, the original architectonic forms, simplifying them. He distorts them diluting the contours and the junctures that make the construction of the image possible...He “de-Europes” them, taking out their brilliance and enveloping what is represented in an ambience of vagueness and languidness easily associated with a markedly North American conception of light, intensifying the extensive spaces and the predominantly cold chromatic range     

Dorion investigates his cultural identity with this new metaphorical glance at the exterior world. In the studio, he dismantles the parts of the selected references and reorders them, configuring unsettling harmonies that want to be metaphors of the process of painting. In this way , he generates a formative rhetoric in which the historical canons and conventions of the medium he uses, paint, appear as much his own as not, as necessary as they are disposable...(Jose Lebrero Stals, “Insomnia in an Uncertain Place” Pierre Dorion Art Gallery of York University, 1995, p.26)...Symbolically, Rome possesses the sediment of many layers of Occidental painting’s history. It is a cultural space , then, that can be understood in the whole of his work as a discursive bridge between the Autoportraits and future projects inspired by the most recent photographic images...What one sees “found” in the Italian capital is indefinite, and in the end, not very relevant -it could have been made anywhere. His approximation of the landscape is not recreation nor contemplation, but rather apprenticeship: to go into the exterior world and try to make it the direct source of a fictional surrounding, the open manifestation of what is found within, mistrusting the hypothetical possibility of a definitive access to transparency, visibility or perception...   (Jose Lebrero Stals,“Insomnia in an Uncertain Place” Pierre Dorion Art Gallery of York University, 1995, p.27).

	In this series, I am continuing my investigation of light, which now appears to be treated very pictorially. With the reintroduction of figurative light, I simultaneously pose two possibilities: that of the surface and that of illusion. The notion of illusion in painting, which is constant in my (Jose Lebrero Stals,“Insomnia in an Uncertain Place” Pierre Dorion Art Gallery of York University, 1995, p.29) work is created here in a flat manner, almost in a non-space, constructing a sort of framed window, locating the painting within a painting... I believe that painting still serves to project invisible things which have a very refined and subtle physical presence (interview with the artist, November 1994, Montreal)...Dorion’s criticism of heritage is an investigation with prototypical images that are not self-exhausting; they are new formation of hybrid figures arising out of a cultural heritage that has become chaotic...” (Jose Lebrero Stals“Insomnia in an Uncertain Place” Pierre Dorion Art Gallery of York University, 1995, p.30).
 

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

While Pierre Dorion seeks in his paintings to render everyday scenes realistically, working mainly from photographs, he also uses his work to refer to the history of painting itself, particularly Renaissance subjects and portraiture. Early in his career he explored the relationship of painting to sculpture by plastering an interior with photogaphs from magazines, then painting an interior in a manner reminiscent of Renaissance fresco. During the early 1990’s he was painting images that were essentially photo-realistic, yet with a haziness and blurred edges that forced the viewer to contemplate the act of photographing, and the act of viewing itself. Along these lines his series of self-portraits, incorporating blurred edges, nearly monochromatic colour, and sculptural objects such as real frames attached inside the canvas edge, situates the acts of portraiture and self portraiture within a larger art historical context. In Trinita dei Monti, Dorion presents a rooftop view through a window, a peopleless cityscape somewhat reminiscent of de Chirico. While the scene is Italian, and refers specifically to Corot’s travels to Rome, it is also generic enough to have been painted anywhere.

995.06.title: A Eulogy to Earth (Still Life), to Bierstadt
995.06.subject: landscape
995.06.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
995.06.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1995
995.06.references: "Bierk's choice of images to appropriate is clearly not arbitrary. They virtually all involve a sense of high drama - nature ... at a particularly dramatic moment, that is, at the moment of heightened, indeed, maximum tension. It is a mystical moment - the moment of revelation, invariably a moment of high contrast, between colors, and especially between light and dark, emblematic of the precarious emotional balance of the moment. The images by Bierstadt, Ryder, Fantin-Latour, et al that Bierk chooses reveal nature at its most vivid and intense and thus most sacred - a climactic revelation and sacremental celebration of nature, as though in a brilliant flash, in which memory and immediacy seem one. (Kuspit, 10) For an extensive, general discussion of the Eulogy to Earth series, please see Donald Kuspit's article "David Bierk's Lost Paradise of Art and Nature" in the catalogue to the exhibition DAVID BIERK: ANOTHER HISTORY (Associated American Artists: September 14 through October 21, 1995), which is in the Bierk artist file.

995.07.title: Caroline de la Rivière
995.07.subject: portrait of woman, background landscape
995.07.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
995.07.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1995
995.07.references:
"We have been working collaboratively together since 1982, producing site works involving entire buildings as well as projects with and for museums, galleries and publications. The ephemeral site projects we conceive mainly for abandoned buildings are a hybrid of social theory, architectural archeology, scholarly research, popular history, metaphysical investigation and contemporary interdisciplinary arts. The buildings themselves are ideologically, socially and economically charged architectures which we choose with care as integral parts of our work. ... This exhibition at Susan Hobbs Gallery is our first Toronto exhibition. ... [the salon-style installation related to bearded ladies, of which the work Caroline de la Riviere forms a part], Salon de la Femme a Barbe addresses the matter we ourselves produce, looking at the cultural manipulation of bodily excrescences such as hair in the policing of social order. We began thinking about Salon de la femmea Barbe in 1987, when we first read about the hairy girl-child whose portrait (1580) was in the collection of the Tirolean princes. In 1989 we presented the related performance Animal Love at the fifth international AIDS Conference in Montreal. Animals, part-beasts, fur. Knowledge, sagacity, strength, virility, power and their complex undersides of transgression, stigmatisation, renunciation, and weakness are all indicated by the presence or absence of hair, depending on where it appears and on whose body. The prodigious hair of Samson, of the werewolves, and of the anomalous bearded lady may here be cases of the return of the repressed. Even the fact that hair grows again after being cut, and after death, involves it in this scenario. Hair is a veil, with all its connotations of chastity; a mane, with all its implications of animal force. It marks and makes interchangeably significant several bodily orifices. Gender is a central issue here: the girl-child's passage from a hairless to a hairy body during puberty is accompanied by an incrementally acquired denial of bodily knowledge, memory, and desire." Quotes taken from the brochure accompanying the 1994 exhibition at the Susan Hobbs Gallery, written by Martha Fleming and Lyne Lapointe. Their artistic collaboration came to an end in 1996.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Martha Fleming and Lyne Lapointe engaged in an artistic partnership from 1982 to 1996, during which time they collaborated to reuse forgotten or abandoned objects from the past, setting up installations in abandoned buildings, reviving those places that were once vital to the community around them. In one show, for example, called Le Musée des Sciences, they chose a building resembling the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts to create an imaginary feminist museum, or “anti-museum”, collecting together objects such as an old hydro-therapy bath that was used to calm hysterics, and old medical and anthropoligcal drawings of women. Their museum questioned museological authority, processes of selection and collection, in particular criticising the pictorial history of women.  
    Caroline de la Rivière is part of a series on women with hair, entitled Salon de la femme à barbe. By depicting women with hair grown in inappropriate places, such as the moustached Caroline, they examine hair as a site of cultural manipulation, an identifying and defining element of coporeality. Hair becomes the symbol of the girl reaching puberty, a time when she both begins to grow hair in new places throughout her body, and is instructed on how to care for or remove that hair. Connoting the atavistic side of humanity, wildness, strength, and virility, this hair is also symbolic of the maintainance of social order, of strict gender definitions that arise when we consider where hair is grown and on whom.

995.08.title: Yacht Racing
995.08.keywords:
Beaver Hall Group, Canadian Group of Painters-Original member
Canadian Impressionism
995.08.subject: figures in foreground, sailing scene in background
995.08.credit: Collection of the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery, Concordia University, Max and Iris Stern Acquisition Fund / Collection de la Galerie Leonard et Bina Ellen, Université Concordia, Fonds d’acquisition Max et Iris Stern
995.08.source: Purchase - Max and Iris Stern Art Acquisition Fund / achat - Fonds de dotation Max et Iris Stern pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1995
995.08.references:
"[Henrietta Mabel] May was among a small number of Canadian women artists of the early decades of the twentieth century whose non-traditional commitment to their craft transcended academic principles, winning critical respect and contributing to the emergence of Canadian modernism." (Antaki, abstract, iii) "In marked contrast to "Street Scene, Montreal" is "Watching the Regatta", (NGC) the earliest in a series depicting gracious suburban summertimes. Others included "Sails in the Wind, Pointe Claire", "Yacht Racing", 1914 (Fig.9), and "Waiting for the Excursion Boat" (Fig.10) ... Despite the figures' "Daumier-like strength," there is a fluidity to the forms which mimics the easy mood. This series of `urban nature', for lack of a better term, obviously references the Impressionists and especially Renoir whose works were often of figures in the open air - an important theme for British artists as well. Yet these images ultimately convey a late nineteenth century French style both in visual language and the not so subtle suggestion of the genre and mood of `la fete champetre.' (Antaki, 44) For a brief, general discussion of the artist, please see A DICTIONARY OF CANADIAN ARTISTS, Volume Four, compiled by Colin S. MacDonald (Ottawa: Canadian Paperbacks Publishing Ltd., 19??)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, p.297

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

 After studying under William Brymner and Alberta Cleland at the Art Association of Montreal from about 1902 to 1912, Henrietta Mabel May traveled to Europe with Emily Coonan from 1912-13. She was a World War I Canadian War Recrods artist, a member of the Beaver Hall Group, and a founding member of the Canadian Group of Painters in 1933. Her early figurative works reveal the influence of Impressionism and Post-Impressionism, while later on her friendship with A. Y. Jackson and the Group of Seven led her to adopt a more abstract, stylized style. Making sketching trips to the Gatineau Valley and the Laurentians, to Maine, New Hampshire, and Vermont, May sought out the landscape around her as her chief subject matter. Yacht Racing is an early panel in the Impressionist style, part of the contribution made by May’s early work to the development of Impressionism in Canada.

995.09.title: Design No. 4
995.09.keywords: Group-Contemporary Arts Society, Canadian Group of Painters
995.09.subject: abstraction
995.09.references:
written by Martine Fournier for the “Concordia Collects” exhibition:


    Originally from Germany, Fritz Brandtner developed a style of painting that was obviously formed by his experience with German expressionists such as Kandinsky, Marc, and Grosz, with the Bauhaus Constructivists, and with Cubism such as that of Feininger. He came to Winnipeg, Manitoba from Germany in 1928, but finding little reception for his artwork there he moved again to Montreal in 1934. Here he continued to experiment with abstraction but, reluctant to join with art movements, he remained outside the group of Automatists surrounding Borduas and his refus global. Using a kind of expressionistic Cubism, informed by his knowledge of design and decoration, he sought chiefly to capture the moods of Montreal in his work.
    Design No. 4 is unusual in that it is a non-objective painting, a study of flat colour planes and intersecting angles, produced at around the same time that Brandtner was also exploring landscape painting in the Rocky Mountains of British Columbia. Hailed as a pioneer in bringing a sense of the European avant-garde to Canada, he also made an enormous contribution to Montreal by establishing an art school for underprivileged children with Dr. Norman Bethune in 1936.

995.10.title: Redpath Sugar Series (Lachine Canal, Montréal)
995.10.subject: architectural interior
995.10.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
995.10.source: Purchase- Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat- Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1995
995.10.references:
MFA, Concordia University
see Accession No. 995.11 for description of work
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
Clara Gutsche
Redpath Sugar Series (Lachine Canal, Montreal) (1990)
“Clara Gutsche’s Redpath Sugar Series (Lachine Canal, Montreal) (1990) a photographic series of abandoned industrial architectural sites, is imbued with a solemn spirit of place, intimating past stories and illuminated by the sensory traces of human passage. The black and white photographs are sensitive descriptions of the interior of the Redpath Sugar factory situated in one of the earliest industrial areas of the city of Montreal. Former places of employment and, by extension , social and individual stability, these structures have ironically now become sometime shelters to a homeless, transient population. (Karen Antaki, Espaces Inhabitables/ Inhabitable Places p.6) As documents of worksites now fallen into disuse, Gutsche’s photographic images also serve as analogous representations of displacement and abandonment, thus reminding us of the fleeting, fugitive nature of passage and of production. Though silent, these spaces are not anonymous but unknown, their identity and function lost to progress and time. In describing environments that are both suffused with historical associations and devoid of contemporary meaning, these images structures metaphorically illustrate the indefinite nature of place and its possession. (Antaki p.8)

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Working in series format, Clara Gutsche has explored female life by chronicling her relationship with her daughter, photographing her neighbours, and entering female religious communities of Quebec in order to do a series on convent life. She has also been inspired by the Montreal urban area, working during the 1970’s on The Desctruction of Milton Park (a series done with her husband, David Miller, on Victorian houses in their neighbourhood slated for demolition), on a series of shop windows that examined the role of the female in a consumer-based society, and more recently on the Lachine Canal works.
    This last is a series composed mainly of interiors of old office buildings and industrial houses on the Lachine canal. Searching out the signs of previous occupation in these abandoned areas, Gutsche uses light both to reveal the clues to human history here and to connote an unexpected spirituality and hope. Redpath Sugar Series looks at the interior of an old sugar refinery, now a home for transients, with the theme of abandonment as it is present both in the empty building and in the traces left there by those whom society has abandoned.

995.11.title: Redpath Sugar Series (Lachine Canal, Montréal)

MFA, Concordia University

From the catalogue "Inhabitable Places/Espaces inhabitable" for the exhibition of the same title at the Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery, September 22 - November 1, 1994. "Clara Gutsche's Redpath Sugar (Lachine Canal, Montreal), a photographic series of abandoned industrial architectural sites, is imbued with a solemn spirit of place, intimating past stories and illuminated by the sensory traces of human passage. The black and white photographs are sensitive descriptions of the interior of the Redpath Sugar factory situated in one of the earliest industrial areas of Montreal. Former places of employment and, by extension, social and individual stability, these structures have ironically now become sometime shelters to a homeless, transient population. As documents of worksites now fallen into disuse, Gutsche's photographic images also serve as an analogous representation of displacement and abandonment, thus reminding us of the fleeing, fugitive nature of passage and of production. Though silent, these spaces are not anonymous but unknown, their identity and function lost to progress and time. In describing environments that are both suffused with historical associations and devoid of contemporary meaning, these imaged structures metaphorically illustrate the indefinite nature of place and its possession. (p 7-8) ... Clara Gutsche was born in Saint Louis, Missouri in 1949. She currently lives and works in Montreal." Karen Antaki
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

995.12.title: Blue-Orange
995.12.subject: horizontal floor sculpture of hinged, modular elements
995.12.references:
From the 1994 application for certification of cultural property: Blue Orange is a "horizontal floor sculpture constructed of hinged, modular elements. The interlocking aluminum elements are independently painted orange and blue. ... This sculpture is an excellent example of a series of hinged structures produced by Saxe between 1966 and 1971. This phase of the artist's production may be further subcategoried into six distinct periods. Blue Orange derives from the second "Tractors" phase of `chain' constructions consisting of modular elements placed laterally on the ground. As in his sculptural oeuvre following 1967, this work demonstrates the artist's concern with alternatives to the vertical anthropomorphised constructions that form part of the legacy of western sculpture. Blue Orange illustrates the responsive nature of Saxe's sculptures vis-a-vis the spaces that they occupy. By incorporating the spectator's viewpoint into the realization of the sculptural idea, his work partakes of the contemporary emphasis placed on contextual meaning." (Karen Antaki) Jacques Theriault, in his 1995 appraisal of Blue Orange had the following to say about Henry Saxe: "Sculpteur d'importance national; plus de 30 oeuvres au Musee d'art contemporain. Saxe deplace son propos pictural des annees 60' et debut 70' sur des objets dans l'espace, des structures d'elements geometriques modulaires repetitif qui permettent au spectateur d'adoptes l'objet a n'importe quel espace et d'etudier divers systemes de relation possible entre les elements. Des oeuvres en mutation selon un certain ordre dicte par l'angle denominateur qui tend a redefinie le langage formel spatial par un processus de synthese et d'epuration de la forme, element necessaire a l'elaboration d'un concept seriel. En 1978, Saxe represente le Canada a la Biennale de Venise en compagnie de Ron Martin. A l'ete 1994, Le Musee d'art contemporain lui consacre une importante exposition retrospective et il est, dans la meme annee, recipiendaire du Prix Borduas. Les sculptures de Henry Saxe brise avec la notion traditionelle de "haut" et "bas"; puisque modifiable, leur point d'appui au sol ou au mur est indetermine au depart et depend entierement de la disposition des modules juxtaposees. En realite, elles marquent une volonte de faire abstraction de la masse pour ne jouer qu'avec des volumes se deployent dans l'espace. Saxe fait partie de cette generation d'artistes qui marquent l'evolution et le reference certaine de notre heritage artistique dans la plus grands originalite. Responsable d'une contribution historique dans son genre, ensemble avec d'autres grands maitres contemporain canadiens tel que Borduas, Riopelle, Bush, Curnoe, Gaucher, Hurtubise, Molinari, Murray, Snow, C. Tousignant, R. Martin, etc. etc." From the 1992 permanent collection catalogue of the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal, (LA COLLECTION: TABLEAU INAUGURALE), Pierre Landry writes "Apres une courte periode durant laquelle il pratique la peinture et la gravure, Henry Saxe realise, vers le milieu des annees 60, des reliefs faits de contre-plaque recouvert d'acrylique. Au-dela d'un mise en question des normes de la peinture, ses oeuvres temoignent d'un interet pour la troisieme dimension, lequel orientera progressivement sa demarche vers un travail de nature essentiellement sculpturale. Cette prise en consideration de la troisieme dimension l'amene a s'interroger sur les differents modes d'articulation de l'oeuvre et sur les possibilites formelles inherent a chacun - un question qui dominera la production de Saxe durant la seconde moitie des annees 60."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.142, 217-218
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, p.389
-See Jessica Bradley and Lesley Johnstone, eds., “Sightlines,” 1994, p.37

995.13.title: Highland in Mauve No. 5
995.13.subject: gestural abstraction, two dominated areas of mauve with "sponge" marks of other colours throughout surface.
995.13.credit: Gift of the Gershon Iskowitz Foundation/don de la Fondation Gershon Iskowitz
995.13.source: Gift of the Gershon Iskowitz Foundation / don de la Fondation Gershon Iskowitz, 1995
995.13.references:
"Turning to landscape for the subject of his painting in the early 1950's, Iskowitz increasingly downplayed representational imagery in his work in favour of the expressive potential of colour and form. As a result the artist's works began to function on two levels: as personal recollections of his experiences with lanscape and as formal investigations of colour harmonies, surface patterns, and layers of pictorial space. (taken from the entry on Iskowitz in the permanent collection catalogue of the Art Gallery of Ontario (1990), p 339). According to Dennis Reid (CONCISE HISTORY OF CANADIAN PAINTING. Toronto: Oxford University Press, 1988) Iskowitz's paintings in the 1970's can be described as "abstraction based on landscape experiences." For an extensive, general description of Iskowitz's career, artistic progression and process, please see Dennis Reid, p 384-5. Photocopy in artist's file. In David Burnett's 1982 catalogue essay for the solo show held at the Art Gallery of Ontario, he characterizes Iskowitz's production in the late 1970s as follows: "There is an extension of this particular `all-over' form in a number of large dyptichs which Iskowitz made in the mid-1970s. They are some of the most dynamic paintings of his career, ... Their power comes from the artist's ability to maintain the flow and the dynamics of the picture across a width of some eleven feet. ... one must not think in terms of a series of separate directions but of a complexinterweaving; a work emerges out of the one before, but each has a place in a wider spectrum, a tight interlocked network of relationships." (Burnett, 71) For bibliography and resume of solo and group exhibitions, please see artist's file.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.88, 99-101

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Originally from Poland, Gershon Iskowitz studied at the Warsaw Academy of Arts from 1937-8 and the Cracaw Academy of Fine Art in 1939, until his studies were interrupted by the Second World War, during which he lost all his family in Nazi concentration camps, nearly dying himself. Following the end of the war he enrolled in the Munich Academy of Art (1947), producing early works that were generally figurative interpretations of the horrors of the Holocaust. In 1949 Iskowitz immigrated to Canada, where he took a great interest in the landscape around him, and began to use it as his subject matter. He moved into abstraction as he became interested in aerial views, which he encountered while taking helicopter rides over the countryside. For the rest of his career he continued these investigations into light, colour, and the nature of pictorial space as inspired by the bird’s eye landscape view. Highland in Mauve No. 5 is such an investigation, named for the predominance of purple hues in this particular study of colour and pattern.

KING, Holly
