995.16.title: From Hill Top, Hudson Heights
995.16.keywords:
Beaver Hall Group, Canadian Group of Painters-Original member
Canadian Impressionism
995.16.subject: townscape as seen from hill top
995.16.credit: Collection of the Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery, Concordia University, Max and Iris Stern Acquisition Fund / Collection de la Galerie Leonard et Bina Ellen, Université Concordia, Fonds d’acquisition Max et Iris Stern
995.16.source: Purchase - Max and Iris Stern Art Acquisition Fund / achat - Fonds Max et Iris Stern pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1995
995.16.references:
"[Henrietta Mabel] May was among a small number of Canadian women artists of the early decades of the twentieth century whose non-traditional commitment to their craft transcended academic principles, winning critical respect and contributing to the emergence of Canadian modernism. (Antaki, abstract, iii) need photo, no more specific info readily available ...
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, p.297

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Painted ten years after Yacht Racing, From Hill Top, Hudson Heights reveals how much May’s style changed after she had returned to Canada and began associating with the members of the Group of Seven. Her palette here is much darker, almost surprisingly muddy, and the quick, light brush-strokes of the Impressionist style have given way to simplified, flat planes of colour. The landscape with its village is solidified into geometric forms, many of them outlined in black for even greater emphasis on pictorial flatness.

995.17.title: XXX Voto (for the Spirit Miss General Idea)
995.17.references:
"The trio of artists - A.A. Bronson, Jorge Zontal and Felix Partz - banded together under the name General Idea in 1968. Working as a collective in multimedia work allowed them to better assume the role of "cultural investigators" who mimicked the tactics of the mass media and appropriated a multitude of cultural vehicles. The scope of their activity and their commitment to ambiguity resist classification. At the outset the prevalent of these activities was the 1984 Miss General Idea Pavillion, an open-ended, easily manipulated concept within which works were realized ... Any attempt, however, to correlate precisely image and text is fruitless. Rather, the viewer is exposed to a multiplicity of meanings and their ironical and paradoxical intent." (Art Gallery of Ontario: Selected Works, 1990) "Les artistes dont les pseudonymes AA Bronson, Felix Partz et Jorge Zontal sont reunis sous le vocable de General Idea oeuvre ensemble depuis 1968 autour des preoccupations illusoires comme les concours de beaute, les parades de mode et le kitsch urbain de la culture nord-americaine. Elaborer des le debut des annees 70, leur plus grand projet consiste a planifier et a construire le pavillon de Miss General Idea, une sorte de faux mythe base sur le roman de science-fiction 1984, de George Orwell, veritable critique narrative de la societe. Le trio fait l'eloge de tout ce qui est precieux et glamour autour de l'election repetitive de Miss General Idea. La parodie a pris des proportions telles qu'elle est devenue le propos de leur recherches, et ils la vivent jusqu'a l'absurde en s'y jetant corps et ame. ... La structure de leur oeuvre comporte un double jeu : celui de creer une idole a l'image de leur propre mythologie et d'y decouvrir le paradoxe qui decoule de ce langage difficilement penetrable, une forme d'appropriation a partir de strategies manipulant divers aspects du domaine de la culture." (Pierre Granche, from La collection : tableau inaugural, permanent collection catalogue of the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal, 1992)
 
“General Idea, the collective title for Jorge Zontal, A.A. Bronson and Felix Partz is best known to the art world for witty and humorous critiques of modern culture.” (web site)
General Ideas work is described as “slick yet trenchant exposes of the art world’s pieties and commercialization.” (C Magazine Winter 1995, p.34)
Describing their art, General Idea stated “We like contradictions---as many as possible. Everything we do has as many levels of critique and meaning as we can pump into it.” (General Idea (1991))
“Through art, General Idea constructs a certain distanced relationship to AIDS, one that circumvents autobiography and allows us to sense the scale of the medical tragedy as we cannot if we are too close. In its invocation of the sublime, General Idea thinks through the relation of art to real-world cataclysms and sets down new borders between these realms....we can read quite seriously their witty but moving XXX VOTO, the final text in Pharmacopia. this text is a play on the form of religious art known as the ex-voto, an offering to the divine that records gratitude for a miraculous salvation. The three Xs of General Idea thank the Spirit of Miss General Idea, the spirit of their art. (C Magazine, Winter 1995, p.34 **FIND AUTHOR”S NAME**)

995.18.title: Landscape
995.18.subject: mountainous terrain with tree stub
995.18.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1995

995.19.title: Reader
995.19.subject: urban park scene with single figure
995.19.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l’artiste
995.19.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1995
995.19.references:
written by Martine Fournier:

Edmond Dyonnet arrived in Montreal in 1875, and after studying at the School of Arts and Crafts, he went to Italy for four years to gain further instruction under professor Gastaldi. He worked chiefly as a portrait artist in an academic style, although he also painted landscapes of Île d’Orléans, and was instrumental in founding Montreal’s École des Beaux Arts. Ste-Anne de Beaupré is an example of his landscape work, showing rolling green land dotted with cows, a road leading into scattered houses and a glowing sunset sky. A vision of countryside serenity, it invites the viewer into its folds even while its population remains unrevealed.

995.20.title: Woods
995.20.subject: woods scene
995.20.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l’artiste
995.20.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1995

995.21.title: Moon
995.21.subject: urban nightscape with moon and wall
995.21.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l’artiste
995.21.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1995
995.21.references: From "Legal Perspectives: Selected Works from the Collection of Osler, Hoskin and Harcourt". Catalogue to an exhibition held at McMichael Canadian Art Collection from June 28 - September 13, 1992. "In addition to her work as an artist/photographer, Angela Grauerholz is also a graphic designer, a teacher at UQAM, and a founding member of Artexte (a non-profit documentation centre for contemporary visual arts. Her photography is characterized by its dark, gentle tones, skewed perspectives, and the use of long exposures to create a soft-focus image. Through her techniques, Grauerholzmakes the presence of the artist a visible, conscious part of the work and denies the purely mimetic aspects of photography. Her subject matter, usually presented as a series of works, includes public and private spaces, portraits and clouds." (p 17) From the Ellen Art Gallery's 1996 application for certification of cultural property, Section VI: "Angela Grauerholz is an established Canadian artist of international reputation whose photographic practice has spanned nearly two decades. LANDSCAPE, READER, WOODS and MOON are black and white photographs produced in the mid-eighties that are outstanding examples of the artist's ongoing formal and technical concerns. The images each depict an urban or natural landscape. Despite their contextual specificity, the soft-focused photographed sites possess an ephemeral, atemporal quality that inscribes both past and future time upon the imaged space of the present. These works also reflect the artist's continuing interest in nature as subject and motif. Beyond its representation of the romantic and the sublime, landscape and its various manifestations serves also as a pictorial strategy for the artist for the investigation of the relationship between referentiality and self-referentiality, image and archetype, within the parameters of the current photographic discourse. Angela Grauerholz's oeuvre is not only aesthetically powerful, but also engages timely critical issues in contemporary art practice that reflect the larger Canadian cultural context." (Karen Antaki) From the permanent collection catalogue of the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal (LA COLLECTION: TABLEAU INAUGURAL, 1992), Josee Belisle writes: "Depuis le debut des annees 80, Angela Grauerholz propose des travauz photographiques empreints d'un pouvoir d'evocation remarquable, ou elle retrace, d'une maniere immanente et lumineuse, le sens, la qualite historique et la valeur mnemonique de l'image. La contemplation de ces images provoque chez le spactateur un flot d'associations mentales immediates et reveille en lui les impressions tenaces et sournoises du deja vu. Abordant les genres consacres du portrait, du paysage, de la scene d'interieur, Grauerholz capte, le temps d'une exposition prolongee, l'impression durable et evanescente du banal et du sublime. Qu'elles soient prise sur le vif, sans hate et patiemment, ou encore qu'elles proviennent de photographies de peintures ou d'autres photographies, les images soulignent, d'abord dans le passage du flou et plus tard dans la facture sepia du Cibachrome, le caractere autoreferentiel du medium photographique (son histoire, ses sujets, ses modes de reproduction).

995.22.title: Forming 21
995.22.subject: black graphic element in centre of free-hanging canvas
995.22.source: Gift of Gabriel Safdie / don de Gabriel Safdie, 1995

995.23.title: Cones on Fingers
995.23.subject: a human hand with metallic cones on each finger
995.23.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l’artiste
995.23.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1995
995.23.references:
"In the early work the dark force of (Sterbak's) emotions is barely disernible. The "Measuring Tape Cones" (1979) are light, literally empty at the core, a playful exercise in pure form: a two-dimensional conceptual instrument transformed into an object existing for itself alone. It is too soon to see in the repetition of the object the obsessional character of the game. The series of objects - their differences highlighting so many variations on a theme - and the highly visible process of their transformation belong still to the objective aesthetic of Minimalism. Only when worn on the fingertips, like a queer pair of gloves, is their energy mobilized. Like the long curving nails of a Chinese ascete, or a mannequin's exaggerated manicure, they bring to the sensitive fingertip a sexually attractive uselessness that connotates power." (SOURCE: Diana Nemiroff, States of Being) Reproduction in the catalogue of a silver gelatin print made in 1979 - appears to be the same photo as the one in our collection.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

995.24.title: La Famille
995.24.keywords: Group-Contemporary Arts Society, Canadian Group of Painters, Figuration-intimate/familial
995.24.subject: group portrait at funeral with rural background
995.24.color: naturalistic tones of black, white, brown, ochre, red
995.24.rights_holder: Gestion A.S.L. inc. (mandataire désigné par Anne-Sophie Lemieux: André Michaud, CA)
995.24.source: Gift of Bram Garber / don de Bram Garber, 1996
995.24.references:
"Lemieux's early interest in art was developed under the tutelage of Suzor-Cote and through his studies at Montreal's Ecole des beaux-arts. Further instruction in Paris in the 1930s brought him into contact with Clarence Gagnon. Like him, Lemieux was unaffected by the Paris avant-garde, preferring to comment on conditions in his native province. On his return to Canada, he became part of a small group of painters who concentrated on depicitng traditional quebecois ways of life." (Art Gallery of Ontario: Selected Works, 1985) "The stylized portraits of French-Canadian types for which Lemieux is so well known today first began to appear after a trip to Europe in 1954, made possible by a Royal Society grant. Moody, simplified studies of strong sentiment, they confront the solitude the Quebecois has traditionally felt in his struggle with a harsh climate and an isolated social environment. They implicitly celebrate "la survivance" of basic Quebec values." (Dennis Reid, A Concise History of Canadian Painting. Toronto: Oxford University Press, 1988, p 289) "Apres 1970, et jusqu'a sa mort survenue en decembre 1990, Lemieux repousse les limites meme de ce metier symbolique pour redecouvrir en fin de parcours un universel de modernite expressionniste. L'oeuvre de la maturite tardive est ainsi un requistoire passionne, angoisse, semblant sans espoir, sur le present et l'avenir du l'etre dans le monde. Un art de cri qui temoigne d'une vision tourmentee et quasi apocalyptique de l'humanite. Le paintre de silence deveient celui de cauchemar eveille qui ne se dement pas." (Marie Carani, guest curator for the Lemieux retrospective at the Musee du Quebec, June 4 - November 1 1992) "According to art critic Jacques de Roussan, Lemieux stands out from Borduas and Pellan, by the fact that he could be given a figurative label. Like them, he knew the "pangs of the anecdotal", namely he painted scenes for their narrative values more so than for their subjective dimensions. But whereas Borduas and Pellan broke with realism, Lemieux sought to renew it. The stylistic analysis of the painting of Lemieux was his majpr strength. In the fifties, he was interested in simplifying space to focus solely on the geometric functions. In the seventies, he once again began to give greater detail to his landscapes and characters. ... The work of Lemieux would not have veen possible without the experiences and endeavours of the post-impressionists: cubists, naturalists, symbolists. But, according to de Roussan, Lemieux also developed his own vision and gave form to it in the typical Quebec landscapes and characters that he painted." (synopsis of critical essay by art criticJacques de Roussan, from "L'Effet Lemieux", Musee du Quebec publication, p 28) In a letter (June 9, 1995) from the donor, Bram Garber to Karen Antaki, "I am not an authority on Lemieux, however, I was informed that he created this painting [La famille] from an old photograph, and that he is the child on the right in an era when apparently clothes were handed down regardless of sex."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, pp.311, 344
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, p.289

written by Martine Fournier:

During the 1970’s, Lemieux’s work evolved into a more passionate, more personal body of paintings, and he began to invest his landscapes and figures with much greater detail. La Famille is an interesting example of this later production, as it demonstrates both his renewed interest in the figure, and this continuation of his focus on Quebec culture as subject matter. Based on a photograph from the artist’s own collection, it is an intensely personal study, yet at the same time displays an archetype of family that is universally symbolic of the human condition and the cylcle of life.

995.25.title: Le Blé d'inde
995.25.keywords: Beaver Hall Group, Canadian Group of Painters, Urban Scenes, Social Realism
995.25.subject: figurative grouping of street vendors in market
995.25.credit: Gift of/don du Dr. Harvey A. Evans
995.25.source: Gift of Harvey A. Evans, M.D. / don de Harvey A. Evans, M.D., 1995
995.25.references:
In the 1995 application for Cultural Property certification, Karen Antaki described Le ble d'inde (also titled Du Bon Ble d'Inde Bouilli) as follows: "A figurative painting depicting a group of vendors at their work. The sense of grouping is anonymous, the composition articulated in broad planes of colour and form. Visual patterns echo the rhythmic mood of the painting, the pictorial elements extending the lyrical, timeless spirit of the work. ... This work by an important national artist is significant primarily for its value in the study of Canadian art. It is an excellent representation of Andre Bieler's favourite subject: the inhabited environment. It illustrates the emphasis the artist placed upon images of people at labour or in quotidian life. His regard for human interaction translated formally into strong and lyrical compositional relationships. Le Ble d'inde was painted during Andre Bieler's period of residence in Montreal. It represents a corner of the old Bonsecours Market where the corn vendor stood calling "Du bon ble d'inde bouilli, cinq sous les deux epis." The work is of particular interest not only for its local and historical references, but as a unique example of the artist's production during a period of new involvement with the Montreal art community, and his augmented interest in exhibiting his work and in the investigation of new formal and technical concerns. His first works in the medium of casein, of which this painting is an example, date from this period. While the painting demonstrates new concerns, it also extends the formal interests which informed his earlier production, in particular, the body of work produced in the Gaspe area of rural Quebec in the late twenties, a period referred to as his first maturity as a painter. It continues his focus on strong, lyrical compositions which depict quotidian life and involve strong colour, an emphasis on structural relationships and a sense of pattern which became his trademarks. While pictorial details were of importance to Bieler, it was never at the cost of formal relationships and his works demonstrate a vitality and compositional vigour that exceeds their historical relevance. Andre Bieler was involved with a number of principal Canadian associations including the Beaver Hall Hill Group and the Canadian Group of Painters. In 1941 he organized the important conference of Canadian artists at Queen's University which would later become known as "The Kingston Conference" and was named the first president of the Federation of Canadian Artists. His work as an educator furthers his importance within the Canadian art historical context and adds a distinct dimension to his production."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, p.14
-See J. Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, pp.331-332
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.199, 208

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

 Born in Lausanne, Switzerland, André-Charles Biéler was raised in Paris until 1908, when he came to Montreal with his family. He studied under Charles Rosen and George Bellows at the Art Students’ League Summer School in Woodstock, New York, and then from 1921-6 at Atelier de la Grande Chaumière (under Maurice Denis) and the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris. Renowned for his paintings of rural life in Quebec, in particular Île d’Orléans and the St. Lawrence River North Shore communities, Biéler first painted this kind of subject while studying rural life with his uncle in the Valais region of Switzerland.
    While far more interested in painting people than landscapes, Biéler documented his vision of the joy and simplicity of life in rural Quebec, side-stepping the more common depictions of hardship and poverty prevalent in social realist painting of the 1930’s. Influenced by his study of fresco, and woodblock and pouchoir (stencil) printing techniques, Biéler reveals a consistent interest in line, the rhythm of simple shapes, and colour. While Le Blé d’Inde was painted after Biéler returned from the Quebec countryside to Montreal in 1930, it reflects all his previous artistic concerns, not only in terms of style, but in his continued interest in human labour and everyday life as subject matter.

995.26.title: Surface Events #2
995.26.subject: abstract - five vertical panels in horizontal band
995.26.credit: Gift of Alan and Alison Schwartz in loving memory of Tamara Goldman/don de Alan et Alison Schwartz à la douce mémoire de Tamara Goldman
995.26.source: Gift of Alison and Alan Schwartz in loving memory of Tamara Goldman / don d'Alison et Alan Scwartz à la douce mémoire de Tamara Goldman, 1995
995.26.references:
From "Legal Perspective: Selected Works from the Collection of Osler, Hoskin and Harcourt". Catalogue to an exhibition held at McMichael Canadian Art Collection from June 28 - September 13, 1992. "Colour was the central concern of Louis Comtois from the beginning of his career until his recent death. The artist's early training in Montreal when the tradition of formal, abstract colour-painting was dominant, remained an important element in his art throughout his career, most of which was spent in New York. Like the work of the minimalists, Comtois' paintings demand participation from the spectator as his seemingly monochrome paintings embody subtle layerings and modulations of colour, light and finish which are apparent only with contemplation. This minimalist approach almost denies the presence of the artist's hand. In 1981, Comtois began experimenting with collage on paper." (p 15) From the Ellen Art Gallery's 1995 application for certification of Cultural Property Karen Antaki wrote: "[Surface Events #2] is a modular construction articulated in irregularly sized, vertical rectangles of calibrated and contrasting colour. The minimalist, uniform surface of each panel is interrupted by the gouged lines appearing beneath the surface pigmentation. The work reflects the artist's interest and commitment during his lifetime to exploring the parameters of optical balance and colouristic harmony; a harmony which is nevertheless the result of carefully manipulated formal dissonances." (Appendix 3 c.) "This constructed painting is a superb example of Louis Comtois' departure from the pure, minimalist works which characterized his early production. A departure from the monochromatic, pure geometrics of his earlier work, it demonstrates the artist's preoccupation with new surface tensions and leaving evidence of the artist's hand and the creative painting process. Comtois was a Quebec-born, Canadian artist who lived in New York during the eighties and until his death in 1990. This work, articulated as a series of polychromatic, vertically directed panels approaches the sculptural in its textural quality and irregular construction." (Appendix 6 c.)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.250, 253

995.27.title: Untitled #3
995.27.subject: four rectangles attached in horizontal row
995.27.credit: Gift of Alan and Alison Schwartz in loving memory of Tamara Goldman/don de Alan et Alison Schwartz à la douce mémoire de Tamara Goldman
995.27.source: Gift of Alison and Alan Schwartz in loving memory of Tamara Goldman / don de Alison et Alan Scwartz à la douce mémoire de Tamara Goldman, 1995
995.27.references:
From the Ellen Art Gallery's application for Cultural Property certification, Yves Gaucher's "Untitled #3" (1990) is described as "A horizontal, minimalist composition consisting of a sequence of four planes in grey and yellow." (Karen Antaki, Appendix 3 d.) Further on in Appendix 6 d., she has this to say: "This work is a highly important addition to our permanent collection of Canadian art. Yves Gaucher is a senior Canadian painter of significant reputation. As a small, minimalist painting on paper, this work demonstrates the range of the artist's production and serves as an example of his ongoing concerns with structural and chromatic relationships, dynamic asymetrical forms and the attainment of what he has termed a `visual rhythmics'."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.53, 76-79, 81
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.369-371

995.28.title: Boreal Portage
995.28.keywords:
Photography-montage, Rural Scenes-photo, Diptych-single frame, Figuration-body as site,
graduate
995.28.subject: diptych: ballerina and cabin in winter landscape
995.28.credit: Gift of Alan and Alison Schwartz in loving memory of Tamara Goldman/don de Alan et Alison Schwartz à la douce mémoire de Tamara Goldman
995.28.source: Gift of Alan and Alison Schwartz in memory fo Tamara Goldman / don d'Alan et Alison Schwartz à la mémoire de Tamara Goldman, 1995
995.28.references:
MFA, Concordia University
In the Ellen Art Gallery's 1995 application for certification of Cultural Property Karen Antaki described Sorel Cohen's Boreal Portage as follows: "A large photographic dyptich. Two photographs are encased within a large black background. The disparate images, one of a prima ballerina, the other of an icy but idyllic winter scene, make references to the dualities inherent to nature/culture. A faint but discernible text of the title is placed beneath the photographic images." (Appendix 3 b.) "The work forms part of a series of seven diptychs produced in 1988 that address contemporary problems of representation. Utilizing allegorical imagery and technical photographic manipulations, these binary combinations of coloured images investigate issues of representation, reproduction and the photographic image as a cultural conduit for the circulation of meaning. In contrast to her earlier production which focussed on studio photography, this series is constructed using media-based imagery exclusively: documentary photography, art reproductions, nature books, brochures. She pairs iconic, culturally inscribed images, such as the prima ballerina, with romantic pictorial landscapes to investigate polarities such as nature/culture, fiction/truth, within the parameters of her visual terrain. By inserting textual passages that are almost invisible, Cohen fragments meaning, and accentuates the fictive and fabricated nature of photography. Her employment of the colour and images of advertising also acts as a critique of the means by which culturally determined photographic 'styles' influence our perception of the medium. Cohen's work is situated within an important critical discourse questioning the representation of the female body, as well as nature, in artistic production, and the role of photography in the history of art." (Appendix 6 b.)

995.29.title: Die Laughing - Sapling #3
995.29.subject: sapling in landscape
995.29.credit: Gift of Alan and Alison Schwartz in loving memory of Tamara Goldman/don de Alan et Alison Schwartz à la douce mémoire de Tamara Goldman
995.29.source: Gift of Alison and Alan Schwartz in loving memory of Tamara Goldman / don d'Alison et Alan Scwartz à la douce mémoire de Tamara Goldman, 1995
995.29.references:
From "Legal Perspectives: Selected Works from the Collection of Osler, Hoskin and Harcourt". Catalogue to an exhibition at the McMichael Canadian Art Collection from June 28 - September 13, 1992. "Will Gorlitz received his art training in the 1970s at the University of Manitoba, followed by studies at the Nova Scotia College of Art and Design. Although he is a painter, he has been influenced by other media such as conceptual art, videoart, and performance art. This has led him to adopt a deconstructivist approach that allows for many possibilities of interpretation. Working in thematic series that question the visual language of representation, Gorlitz does not intend his imagery to be viewed as an isolated entity but as imagery layered within a system of relations. Meaning is completed by the spectator's interpretation. The artist lives in Wellington, Ontario." (p 17) "Will Gorlitz is an important contemporary Canadian artist. His works have a particular relevance both regionally and nationally. They explore salient concerns within the current art discourse and investigate issues related to the history of painting. Multi-levelled, they address both ideological and formal issues such as those related to traditional and modern pictorial representational systems. "Die Laughing - Sapling #3" is a highly significant work from an aesthetic standpoint as well as for the critical problems it addresses: questions of identity and framing, the rhetoric of the self-portrait and the stereotype of the family. Bringing irony into the practice of painting, Gorlitz ... "Die Laughing - Sapling #3" is a landscape composition depicting a single sapling arching towards the sky and centred in an open field. The vertical direction of the work places an emphasis upon the tree image and brings to attention traditional pictorial landscape representations. The naturalistic palette and modulated application of the paint create a surface that is harmonious and lyrical." (Transcription of texts found in appendices 3 e. and 6 e. of the 1995 application for the certification of Cultural Property.)
-See review(s) in Artist’s FileDie Laughing - Sapling # 3 (1985)Will Gorlitz
...”the installation Die Laughing, the issues of identity and social production of meaning are contextualized with regard to the history of art. In particular the conventional relations of the artist to his production are dealt with through the model of the family. The basic black humour of the term ‘die laughing’ is turned into a pair of sick jokes carved into tombstones, placed beneath two pictures of aged and rotting trees, entitled Mother  and Father  .  Also, there are six paintings of young trees called SAPLINGS, three to each side of a central, two panelled canvas. This is a self-portrait of the artist laughing, well, laughing his head off would be an appropriate description, and is titled I Die Laughing.
	The ensemble alludes to the construct of the family as a semantic unit in any discussion of production. The work of art is analogous to the issue of procreation, and is dealt with under paternal proprietal rights, yet Gorlitz has extended this concept along peculiar lines. He has taken account of his place within the lineage of painters, stressing the conflict inherent in any patrilineal legacy. First the allegorical structure of his ‘family’, wherein the ‘children’ are the SAPLINGS, those nippers on the soil, and the parents are dead, rotten saturnine, details the canny incorporation of past achievement in the work of the present. The types of paintings display conventional connotations- the artist self-represented, the capture of orderly views of nature, the thematic growth and(William Wood Will Gorlitz New York: 49th Parallel, 1987 p.16) decay in an organic cycle. The metaphoric resemblance to the orderly passage of tradition is dimly present. Yet that very naturalism is sickened by the jokes....Even the sentimentality of the Saplings  is tarnished by their setting- bleak urban slopes where they require stakes... to hold them up.”  (William Wood p.18) ...”The substitution of natural elements for the familial figures is tantamount to denying  the possibilities of adequate representation, perpetuating the conflict of the family at the level of practice. ..the equation of landscape with human relationships is available only to the most solipsistic consciousness, and, though the Saplings  sarcastically parallel human growth, their isolation permits their relations to be perpetually estranged...There is violence here, as the son and the father distribute the bile- black humour of patrilineal and, perhaps, patrilineal aggression to his family unit... (William Wood p.19)...”From this vantage , it is evident that a different kind of subject is being addressed by Gorlitz. No longer the spectator of mass culture mesmerized by personification, but a projection of deep-rooted processes in Western patriarchal culture is being put on stage.

995.30.title: Landscapes (Self-Portrait VI)
995.30.subject: abstract expressionist style with emerging mask-like figure
995.30.credit: Gift of Alan and Alison Schwartz in loving memory of Tamara Goldman/don de Alan et Alison Schwartz à la douce mémoire de Tamara Goldman
995.30.source: Gift of Alan and Alison Schwartz in memory of Tamara Goldman / don d'Alan et Alison Schwartz à la mémoire de Tamara Goldman, 1995
995.30.references: From Appendix 3 f. of the Ellen Art Gallery's 1995 application for certification of Cultural Property: [Landcape (Self-Portrait V1)] is a figurative painting articulated in an abstract, expressionistic style. The composition is characterized by a heavy, gestural paint surface and broad areas of brilliant colour intercut by vigorous bands of black lines. Mask-like figures emerge from within the structural organization of the work and contribute to the forceful, dynamic surface." From Appendix 6 f.: "This painting represents an excellent example of the recent production of one of Canada's leading painters. Klunder's concerns lie with form, colour, and the structuralist, pictorial properties of paint. His is a formal and contextual reconciliation of abstraction which stems from the subjective and the unconscious. His recent self-portraits demonstrate his interest in figuration and the expressive potential of paint-making. Landscape (Self-Portrait V1), is an exceedingly strong composition. The dynamic surface, intense colour and painterly quality allude to the influence of traditional painting while at the same time serving to recontextualize a modernist pictorial legacy. It not only adds a broader dimension to the artist's production, but also exemplifies a regional and national direction in artmaking, and painting more specifically, during the last decade." (both texts, Karen Antaki)

995.31.title: Ephemeral Fire
995.31.subject: close-up of industrial machinery with flames in background (furnace)
995.31.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l’artiste
995.31.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1996
995.31.references:
From a 1993 Musee d'art de Joliette press release: "A la fin des annees soixante-dix, Holly King travaille la performance en explorant les notions de mise en scene et de theatralite. Des le debut des annees quatre-vingts, elle s'oriente vers la photographie, mais ses preoccupations demeurent les memes : jouer avec l'illusion et la notion du vrai et du faux. ... Peut-on la qualifier d'artiste multidisciplinaire puisque les paysages qu'elle photographie sont le resultat de maquettes qu'elle compose, peint et eclaire? Ainsi, elle met en scene des paysages fictifs composes d'elements reels et d'elements construits. Elle laisse le spectateur jouer le jeu de departager le vrai du faux ou tout simplement de se laisser charmer par ces paysages venus de nulle part."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

written by Martine Fournier  for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

After obtaining her BFA from Laval University, Quebec in 1979, and her MFA from York University, Toronto in 1981, Holly King began a career as a performance artist. Switching to photography in the early 1980’s, her work was still informed by her theatrical experience as she chose to create small landscapes on tabletops, like miniature theatre sets, then photograph them. The result is a dramatically-lit dreamworld that seems to lie somewhere between fairytale and nightmare. Unlike many other constructed photography artists, King does not use the medium for ironic or satirical observations on society, but rather to explore the world of illusion. Creating an artificial landscape, King is interested in how it becomes believable and how the spectator, once recognizing the illusion involved, is distanced from the landscape King has created. In Ephemeral Fire her earlier ilusionary landscape works, in which the viewer was often presented with a dangerous or precarious situation, are recalled. This vision of what appears to be firey activity in a foundry or other industrial setting is both hauntingly beautiful and intimidating.

996.01.title: V (# 5)
996.01.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l’artiste
996.01.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1996
996.01.references:
Claire Gravel, from the Saidye Bronfman Centre catalogue of the 1992 exhibition "Le dessin rebelle": "Between his neo-plasticien training with the painters Molinari, Gaucher and Goguen at Concordia University and his association with the Insurrection Art Company, a group of conceptual artists (Paul Heyer, Mike Haslam and Bob Walker) who showed unorthodox works at Galerie Media, Francois Morelli assumed a distinct position in the art milieu then torn by aesthetic antagonism. He experienced these in constant dialysis, as evident in his 1974 "action" where he attached two canvases to his feet and walked to Concordia University." From a 1994 brochure accompanying an exhibition held at Galerie Christiane Chassay, Montreal/Horodner Romley Gallery, New York, Stuart Horodner writes: "His objects encode an air of ritual, as if not satisfied with their presentness. They reach back towards the tribal or the medieval and leap ahead to the twenty-first century techno-worlds. This distillation of impulses is what gives each Morelli project its all time-all place humanity. His process is labor-intensive, and like the prize fighter who is fuelled by the blows against his head, Morelli must factor in an overwhelming time investiture and concentration in order for him to feel like he's truly in the game." In a brochure for the 1997 exhibition at the Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery, Karen Antaki writes: "Over the last fifteen years, Montreal-based artist Francois Morelli has developed a distinctive formal vocabulary that weds the gestural intimacy of drawing with the monumentality that attaches to sculpture and installation. Like dreaming, which casts both light and darkness, his production offers up the familiar and the fantastic in a place seemingly previously traversed, where that which is both known and mysterious presents itself and lingers. ... As a multidisicplinary artist whose practice includes drawing, sculpture and performance, Morelli has traditionally concerned himself with the interaction of bodies and memory in space."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

996.02.title: Hinchinbrooke River
996.02.subject: close-up view of surface of lake with three prominent stones
996.02.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
996.02.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1996
996.02.references:
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

 Photographer David Duchow received a BFA from Concordia University. In his work he often plays with the effect of focus, as in Hinchinbrooke River of his Cook’s Lines Series of 1995. This series, a departure from his earlier large format landscape and architectural photographs, nonetheless is a continuation of his interest in landscape themes, focusing on what used to be the hamlet of Cook’s Lines on the Canada/US border in southwestern Quebec. Once the site of many homes, barns, and several small businesses, the hamlet was virtually abandoned by the mid twentieth century, now consisting of two houses, a barn, and Duchow’s studio. In this photograph, Duchow captures the river in a blur using a Diana camera, at a point where the clear reflective water breaks into distorting wavelets, thus calling into question photographic veracity, vision, perception, and perhaps the notion of landscape as site of self-discovery.

-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.214, 248, 253

written by Martine Fournier:

Louis Muhlstock studied under Edmond Dyonnet and Joseph Saint-Charles at Monument National in Montreal, and from 1920-3 under William Brymner at the Art Association of Montreal. From 1928 ro 1930 he was in France, studying under Louis-François Bilouil and frequenting the Académie de la Grande Chaumière. He began paintng landscapes in various areas of France and continued along these lines in Quebec when he returned to Montreal. However, he also became interested in depicting the city and its tenants, in particular those hard-hit by the Depression during the 1930’s. He is famous for his images of slums, the homeless, sick, and unemployed, also capturing the industrial world at the Montreal United Shipyards during World War II. Later in his career he would delve into abstraction, doing a series of what he called “inscapes”, surreal painitngs centred in texture and pattern, intended to portray the inner landscape of the self. De Bullion Landscape is a painterly depiction of De Bullion street in Montreal, that pays particular attention to the textures of wall and pavement.

996.05.title: Death Valley, Ancient Footpath along the Shore of the Departed Lake
996.05.subject: view of desert with footpath
996.05.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
996.05.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1996
996.05.references:
Born in Pennsylvania, lives and works in Montreal. "As a landscape photographer, I have come to think of the land as being an enormous historical archive. I am interested in revealing the narratives contained within the landscape, especially those places where the landscape reveals itself as being both an agent of change and the field of human endeavour. ... I have been producing images that depict sites where the geological record overlaps or collides with historical and contmeporary evidence of human action upon the land." pages 36-7, artist's statement in American Art, vol. 10, Spring 1996. Work exhibited in Landscape & Photography: A Selection of Recent Acquisitions/Paysage photographiques: acquisitions recentes, August 8 - September 8, 1996, Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery, Concordia University.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

I am interested in revealing the narratives contained within the landscape, especially those places where the land reveals itself as being both an agent of change and the field of human endeavour. ... 996.09.title: Suite Romaine #11
996.09.subject: landscape of plowed fields and trees in hilly terrain
996.09.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
996.09.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l’achat d’oeuvres d’art, 1996
996.09.references:
Peter Krausz lives in Montreal and is a professor at the Universite de Montreal. In the pamphlet which accompanies the exhibition, "The Echoic Landscape", Karen Antaki writes "Approaching the poetics of the sublime, the scenery they [Krausz's landscapes] portray is incongruous with the intricacy of their subject and, as such, serves as a metaphor for the illusory nature of remembrance. Peter Krausz's "Landscape and Memory" consists of three fresco paintings, each possessing an intense beauty that surpasses its visual source in the natural world. Each panel depicts a timeless and seemingly pastoral terrain. Yet the intensity of the artist's palette and the drama of his composition recall the frozen moment of an historically charged event. The radiant lyricism of these imaged landscapes masks their identity as places etched by tragedy and loss. The sites allude to displacement, demonstrating Krausz's ongoing interest in "place" as the ground of dark experience." Please see also James Campbell's article "Site/Memory: The Paintings of Peter Krausz" in DEPTH MARKERS: SELECTED ART WRITINGS 1985-1994, Volume 1 (Toronto: ECW Press, 1995), a photocopy of which can be found in the artist's file.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

996.10.title: Portrait of Molly
996.10.keywords: Group-Contemporary Arts Society, Canadian Group of Painters, Figuration-portrait
996.10.subject: head of young woman
996.10.credit: Gift of/don de Louis Muhlstock in honour of/en l'honneur de Leonard and/et Bina Ellen
996.10.source: Gift of the artist in honour of Leonard and Bina Ellen / don de l'artiste en l'honneur de Leonard et Bina Ellen, 1996
996.10.references:
Louis Muhlstock was born in 1904 in Narajow, in the Austro-Hungarian province of Galicia, which became part of Poland after World War 1. With his family he came to Canada in 1911 to join his father, who had settled in Montreal some years earlier. Muhlstock started his formal art training with evening classes, first at the Conseil des arts et manufactures, then the Art Association of Montreal, and finally at the Ecole des Beaux-arts de Montreal, where he studied under William Brymner, Maurice Cullen and Edmond Dyonnet. Between 1928 and 1931 he studied in Paris with Louis-Francois Biloul. His return to Montreal coincided with the Great Depression, and despite serious difficulties due to a non-existent art market, Muhlstock continued to draw and paint. Using wrapping paper for his drawings, and bleached sugar bags for his canvases, he turned to the unemployed, the homeless and the poor for his models. "Portrait of Molly" (1932), a charcoal study subtly accented in white and pink chalk dates from that period. An excellent desription of Muhlstock's portraiture can be found in a 1936 article by Hector de Saint-Denys Garneau: "The complexity of Muhlstock's talent is found in his technique and an extreme sensibility that is at its most adept when he is describing the female face. His is a sensitivity that evokes secrets rather than unveils them. He works with such extreme discretion and tactfulness that there can never be an impressionn of violation, intrusion or insistence, which might force a withdrawal ..." (Chronique des beaux-arts [II]: Louis Muhlstock. Translated from the original text by Monique Nadeau-Saumier) He taught drawing at his studio, located on the rue Saint-Famille, and exhibited his work at the art gallery in Eaton's department store and the Picture Loan Society in Toronto. Muhlstock was a founding member of the Contemporary Arts Society, created by John Lyman in 1939 to promote an internationalist approach in Canadian painting in reaction to the nationalist landscape school of the Group of Seven. He participated in all of the exhibitions of the CAS from the Society's inception to its demise in 1948. The CAS membership was diversified, representing many trends and aspects of Montreal's artistic community, including a number of Jewish artists who, like Muhlstock, chose to depict their immediate environment, that is, the Jewish ghetto of Montreal. Until then, the urban landscape was mostly known through the paintings of Adrien Hebert, whose works demonstrated a modern interpretation of the animated streets and dockside activities of Montreal. A handful of English-speaking artists also treated similar subjects, but in a more picturesque manner, concentrating on the quaint aspects of Old Montreal. Under Muhlstock's brush, the other urban environments - city lanes, backyards, and rooftops - were first recorded. "De Bullion Landscape" is representative of this focus on heretofore unrecorded aspects of the urban landscape. Througout his career, Muhlstock's works were exhibited across Canada, as well as in the United States, Europe, South Africa, Australia and South America.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, p.306
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.214, 248, 253

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Louis Muhlstock studied under Edmond Dyonnet and Joseph Saint-Charles at Monument National in Montreal, and from 1920-3 under William Brymner at the Art Association of Montreal. From 1928 to 1930 he was in France, studying under Louis-François Bilouil and frequenting the Académie de la Grande Chaumière. He began paintng landscapes in various areas of France and continued along these lines in Quebec when he returned to Montreal. However, he also became interested in depicting the city and its tenants, in particular those hard-hit by the Depression during the 1930’s. He is famous for his images of slums, the homeless, sick, and unemployed, also capturing the industrial world at the Montreal United Shipyards during World War II. Later in his career he would delve into abstraction, doing a series of what he called “inscapes”, surreal paintings centred in texture and pattern, intended to portray the inner landscape of the self. His Portrait of Molly is a delicate charcoal study in which he renders the bright intensity of the sitter’s gaze, suggesting her energy, too, with the addition of light wavy lines around her head.

996.12.title: Bi-Polar Landscape
996.12.subject: landscape: two circles, each resting against the two vertical edges of the canvas, in atmospheric sky.
996.12.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1996
996.12.references:
Exhibited in The Echoic Landscape/Le paysage echoique: Peter Krausz, Marion Wagschal, August 8 - September 18, 1996, Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery, Concordia University. In the brochure which accompanied the exhibition, Karen Antaki wrote: "For Marian Wagschal, the natural world is presented as a construction of culture. Initially perceived as sensuous and sublime, her images of nature deflect from a utopian view, alluding symbolically to sites of violation and loss. Wagschal's Nature embodies prevalently held attitudes towards the mundane environment, and her work addresses the disequilibrium effected by social maxims that sanction the annexation of nature to culture. In addition, Wagschal incorporates the concept of nature as female in order to displace and dispel Arcadian associations of passivity and harmony [which] ... recalls the polarized and paradoxical ideas that attach to our view of nature and that persist, through time, in the form of memory." When interviewed by the CANADIAN JEWISH NEWS, Wagschal said about "Bipolar Landscape": "Your eyes are being pulled apart by these two bodies displaced in the cosmos. The tension in it is disturbing ... I like my work to have an edge." (p 34, September 12, 1996) In a review of the exhibition at the Ellen Art Gallery published in The Gazette on Saturday August 17, 1996 Ann Duncan wrote "One of the ways the paintings of Krausz and Wagschal are connected is the telling references each artist makes to the rich history of painting. In Bipolar Landscape, 1996, Wagschal recalls the sensuous, ethereal paintings of Turner ..."
-See review(s) in Artist’s File

996.13.title: Quantificateur bleu-10/96
996.13.keywords: Group-Plasticiens, Group-NFAAM, Canadian Group of Painters
996.13.subject: abstract - two fields of two shades of blue pigment divided vertically
996.13.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l'artiste
996.13.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1996
996.13.references:
Cette oeuvre a été présentée dans l'exposition vitrine (été) « Parade », Galerie Leonard & Bina Ellen, 4 juillet - 12 août 2011.

SOURCES: Grant Marchand, Sandra with the collaboration of Roald Nasgaard and Guido Molinari. "Guido Molinari: Une retrospective" Catalogue published by the Musee d'art contemporain de Montreal for retrospective exhibition held May 19 - September 17, 1995. "Tout au long d'un parcours de plus de quarante ans s'articulent les grands thematiques qui ont jalonne sa production entiere et qui trouvent leur echo dans une syntaxe originale et innovatrice : les essais tachistes de 1953 a 1955, les tableaux noirs et blancs de 1956, les tableaux plasticiens d'<<espace dynamique>> de 1958 a 1962, les tableaux seriels de bandes verticales egales de 1963 a 1969, les damiers et les triangulaires de 1969 a 1975 et enfin, les <<quantificateurs>> de 1975 a aujourd'hui." (Grant-Marchand, 9) Also, see page 18 of the MAC catalogue for a more extensive discussion between Sandra Grant-Marchand and Guido Molinari re. the "Quantificateurs" series. For Roald Nasgaard's examination, see his essay, p 26, paragraphs two and three in the MAC retrospective catalogue; Reid, Dennis. A CONCISE HISTORY OF CANADIAN PAINTING Second edition (Toronto: Oxford University Press, 1988) "During 1978 and the first half of 1979 he painted seventeen massive canvases (the three largest being three by over six-and-a-half metres, the smallest 228 x 198 cm), which he exhibited together at Montreal's Musee d'art contemporain early in the fall of 1979. He calls them the "Quantificateur" series, in order to emphasize his concern for the quantity of the constituent elements. Indeed the wide bands of colour - all dark hues ranging from warm reddish-browns through to something close to black - are incredibly saturated. They are so dense that the materiality of the colour predominates for a while over our sense of it as space and, finally, as dark light. In some cases the tonal values between the two colours are so close that we perceive the difference only with intense concentration - which assures our entry into the dynamic colour/space that is the work's raison d'etre." (Reid, 367-8) Painting exhibited in The Faculty of Fine Arts Exhibition, November 19 - January 11, 1997, Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery, Concordia University.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, (multiple references)
-See J.Russell Harper, “Painting in Canada: A History,” 1977, p.343
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.292-294, 332, 367-368, 369, 371

written by Martine Fournier:

Guido Molinari studied under Marian Scott and Gordon Webber at the Montreal École des Beaux Arts from 1928-51, and embarked on a painting career in which he has explored precise, mathematical relationships between colours and shapes. During the 1950’s the influence of Les Plasticiens is evident in his canvases as he attempted to obliterate the distinction between figure and ground in painting, first through blobs of colour daubed in equal proportions all over the canvas, then in paintings juxtaposing black and white forms. He is best-known for his paintings of the 1960’s, in which he used vertical bands of colour to continue his work of disrupting the figure/ground relationship. In his Quantifier series of the late seventies he began to work with single colours, such as the blue in Quantificateur bleu - 10/96, exploring the viewer’s relationship to colour and seeking to push the boundaries of our knowledge of it. Often, he would create such subtle gradations of tone within one colour that differences can only be perceived in these canvases after much concentrated staring.

996.14.title: Fleance's First Shave
996.14.subject: extreme close-up of boy's face
996.14.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1996
996.14.references:
"The development of Scherman's work proceeds from a period of major transition within the practice of painting. The debates surrounding Formalism in the late sixties and early seventies gave rise to a period in which the very significance of the medium was brought into question, with both artists and theorists casting about for alternatives to both its definition and methodology. ... [Scherman's] early education in London, England, first at the Byam Shaw School of Painting and Drawing, later at the Royal College of Art, provided a grounding for his later investigations into figuration within the contemporary pictorial discourse. ... The challenge [subsequently] was not to find an alternative to the category of painting, but rather to enlarge its range to include those issues most pertinent to the ongoing debate. He therefore set out to to incorporate the very critique of the practice into the work itself, inserting a terminology of dislocation and ambiguity into its praxis. (Karen Antaki, "Tony Scherman: Banquo's Funeral". Catalogue essay, 1996. p 4-5) "Fleance's First Shave", an extreme closeup of Banquo's son, was produced specifically for the exhibition "Tony Scherman: Banquo's Funeral" (September 26 - November 2, 1996) held at the Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery. "It exemplifies both the artist's most recent painting concerns as well as his continuing commitment to investigating pictorial issues within the context and discourse of contemporary Canadian art practice. For over twenty years, Tony Scherman's oeuvre has been informed by the traditional canons of painting and this, as well as the artist's uncommon pursuit of the medium of encaustic, renders his production relatively unique in this country. Scherman's choice of utilizing vested narratives, his carefully authored compositions, and his sensuous handling of image and paint, describe a visual syntax of unusual individuality." (from the application for certification of cultural property, 1996)
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, p.280

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects exhibition:

Jori Smith was educated from 1922-3 at both the Montreal École des Beaux Arts and the Monument National. During the 1930’s she divided her time between Montreal and Charlevoix, painting the inhabitants of the Charelvoix region, particularly children, which she much preferred to landscape work. Though she joined the Contemporary Arts Society in 1939, she did not truly belong to any artistic group, and her style could be said to fall somewhere between Modern and Naïve. Working with simplified masses of colour and effects of light, she often left traces of canvas showing around her figures to increase the luminosity of a work. Having spent a winter with the Tremblays in Charlevoix, she painted Veillée chez Éloi et Louisa Tremblay in order to capture the experience of attending the veillée, which she did two or three times a week for both instruction and entertainment. The painting conveys the warm and intimate setting of family gathered around the table, an intimacy heightened by the small size of the work. Her use of the light canvas showing through paint to create a glow around the figures is obvious here, and a rhythmic hamrony, reflecting familial harmony, is created by the pattern of their rounded forms.

997.03.title: Nickel Tailings, #31 Sudbury, Ontario
997.03.subject: landscape, nickel tailings, Sudbury, Ontario
997.03.credit: The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l’achat d’oeuvres d’art
997.03.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1997
997.03.references:
Edward Burtynsky
Nickel Tailings, #31 Sudbury, Ont., 1996
an example of Burtynsky’s “urban mining photographs”

met  Harry Knight a retired geologist who had worked for Inco. Burtynsky had photographed the mine tailings six months earlier however “a faulty lens had rendered some of the horizons soft in those pictures. Now Ed wanted to find the sites again and reshoot.” (Canadian Art, Fall 1996)

“Though much of Burtynsky’s work has documented the destructive nature of modern industry , his images have never been ugly...Burtynsky talks about the evolving relationship between man and nature, and how, for the past two decades, that relationship has guided his work.

His 1996 photographic essay on mine tailings earned him the year’s top award for photojournalism from the National Magazine Awards...

Burtynsky examines “the relationship between nature and the forces of industry.”...”Burtynsky has manages to find hidden forms patterns, and colours in places where most of us wouldn’t think of pulling over- ...His past studies - of mines and marble quarries, for example- have looked at the initial stages of industry, in which something precious is taken from the ground for man’s use...

Some see Burtynsky’s images as a critique of man’s brutalization of the natural world; others might view it as a sympathetic bow to industry, creating beauty from ugliness...
 “As Burtynsky documents that intrusion” (man’s intrusion on the landscape) , “he realizes he is also part of it: Like the rest of us, he benefits from the products of industry; in fact the high-tech hardware that keeps Toronto Image Works” (his photographic and digital imaging lab) “in business could not exist otherwise...His images including the new urban mining series are a ‘survey of some of the things I see within our society...The difference is, am I trying to estheticize the devastation or depletion? And quite frankly, it’s not an easy question to answer.” (Dan Falk, “Mining Modern Industry For Art Gems,” The Globe and Mail Tuesday May 5, 1998, p.C3)

...”Nickel mining began in the late 19th century. For decades rock was burned in open cribs, releasing sulphur in dark clouds that rained down sulphuric acid, turning the already rocky terrain black. Since the 1970s, scrubbers and tall smokestacks have reduced the concentration of acid rain. Mining companies also now plant tree seedlings and grass on part of the land.

In Tailings # 30 (NOTE: this is not the work in our collection-our work is Nickel Tailings #31)
Burtynsky shows one stage of the nickel mining process, when the ore-breaking rock is broken down in a mill. Huge rotating cylinders grind the stone to a fine silt. Nickel and other metals are separated out; iron, not considered worth removing, remains. The silt is then mixed with water, and poured into great basins, or “tailing” ponds (tailings are the left-over, the waste). The water seeps out, leaving the rock dust that has turned red through oxidation of the iron that remains in the silt.
To take this photograph Burtynsky stood 15 or 20 feet above the tailings on one of the roads that traverse the pond. The red river of rust flows toward the viewer and spreads out in a wide delta...Tailings # 30 represents only a small section of the vast 6000 acre tailing pond. Other photographs in his series show other sections and views. What Burtynsky captures in the tailings series is an ongoing process. For him, it is important that the pond constantly changes as new layers of tailings pour in and bulldozers build ?beams? and roads...

The scene is hauntingly beautiful as the river of tailings twists and turns and thickens in an almost abstract pattern...That recognition of beauty in ugliness is one of the ‘contradictions’ that Burtynsky strives to express, what he also calls ‘the dynamic of attraction/repulsion.’...he seeks out perspective shifts and evocative patterns, and he uses a very wide-angle lens for a feeling of all-encompassing breadth...Ultimately Burtynsky advocates not a nostalgic return to nature but the responsible management of what we still have and an attendant recognition of the cost.” (Martha Hoppin, From the Mount Holyoke College Art Museum Home Page)

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

 Photographer Edward Burtynsky received his BA in Photographic Arts from Ryerson Polytechnical University in Toronto, and is known for his large photogrpahs of Canadian industrial landscapes. Working with images of farms, greenhouses, mines, quarries, gravel pits, tailing ponds, and refineries, Burtynsky comments on the human relationship with nature and technology. He uses a wide-angle lens to create images of mammoth proportions that are at once panoramic, and detailed enough to draw the viewer in for close inspection. Simultaneously beautiful and repugnant, Burtynsky’s photographs are ambiguous enough to have been interpreted both as a critique of the human ability to ravage nature, and as a positive commentary on the introduction of technology into the landscape.
    Nickel Tailings, #31, Sudbury, Ont. is part of a series on the nickel mining industry in Sudbury, Ontario. The “tailings” are liquid waste from the refining of nickel and copper, seen here in bright orange rivulets that have been coloured by the presence of oxidized iron in the water. The Sudbury area, blackened by acid rain caused by previous mining practices, is pictured here as both an industrial wasteland and a hauntingly beautiful landscape.

997.04.title: Scapulae Entablature

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Toronto artist Spring Hurlbut has long been exploring the themes of death and sacrifice, first using sculptural installation to explore the roots of classicism, for example situating classical columns among trees to invite a comparison. She revisited the origins of classical decoration in human sacrificial practices in her Sacrificial Ornament series. More recently she has examined rituals of death and mourning in La Somnolence, an installation of turn-of-the-century iron cribs and beds arranged in rows resembling graveyards. She then combined this installation with Les biberons infanticides, glass baby bottles with long tubing, also used at the turn of the century, which were dubbed “infanticidal bottles” because of the high mortality rate of babies fed with them.
    Scapulae Entablature forms part of the Sacrificial Ornament series, in which Hurlbut addresses the origins of classical decoration as it sprang from body parts and the rituals of sacrifice. Hurlbut replaced ornamental elements once inspired by eyes, teeth, claws, etc, with the real thing, creating an installation composed of plaster moulding and columns in which the decorative elements are real chicken feet, glass eyes, or, as in this case, plaster casts of human scapulae, referring to the most taboo of pagan practices, the human sacrifice.

997.05 a-b.title: The Melancholy of Maleness, Diptych B
997.05 a-b.subject: scène de genre; paysage
997.05 a-b.medium: gelatin silver print; Iris ink-jet computer graphic print
997.05 a-b.description: The diptych is composed of a black & white photograph on the left, and reproductions of 16th to 18th century paintings, on the right, that are cut into two medallions. The photograph, taken from behind a man and small boy, shows them looking out through a window at penguins. The right element of two medallions has, at the left, a detail taken from Martyrdom of St Felipe (1639) by Jos. de Ribera, that shows a glimpse of the crucifix and the saint’s face. The second medallion, on the right, is a detail from Landscape with the Funeral of Phocion (1648) that shows a cloud formation and the upper branches of a tree.
997.05 a-b.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
997.05 a-b.source: Purchase- Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat- Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat des oeuvres d'art, 1997
997.05 a-b.references:
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
Tim Clark
The Melancholy of Maleness (diptych B) (diptych E)

... “Clark has taken art as the vehicle for communicating his inner confusion , inviting the viewer into a discourse on the fragility of the male psyche... ‘Feminism had a big effect on me,’ the Scottish-born artist said, ‘Specifically, it gave me a set of issues that I could deal with. It allowed me to look at male history the way women looked at male and female history. As a thing to rethink, that’s all.’ ....They consist of seven diptychs , combining photography with fragments of Renaissance paintings, cut out into circular medallions. The juxtaposition of black-and-white shots with the colourful prints presents the viewer with the first conceptual hurdle in this multifaceted exhibition.
A shot of an interior shows a group of men immersed in a conversation, while two little boys stand by silently. ‘Its the entrance to the museum of French Army in Paris,’ Clark explained, pointing out the style of clothing typical for the French upper class.’It’s a strange place, not really attended that much. It’s completely run down but basically the heart of Catholic , aristocratic France.’

To Clark , it represented the continuing male fascination with the army , and all its pathetic primping and posturing. ‘I was talking about the double edge,’ he said. Terrible things happen in wars, but for a lot of men, that’s where their self-identity was built. For me, feminism sort of destroyed a certain part of male history, and it had to be destroyed. But where do you go from there?...it’s not easy to figure out how to place yourself in it.

All I wanted to do was to make a very allegorical piece that’s vague in some ways, and its just about a place where you know you can’t go back, you have to go forward ...

There’s a sense of vulnerability permeating these works, particularly evident in the images caught by Clark’s camera.

A shot of a father and child observing penguins in a New York zoo is juxtaposed with a fragment of a painting portraying martyrdom and another with a silver of pale sky...

‘It’s a dialogue with the audience,’ he said, adding that he has never really discussed the topic with other men. ‘Men don’t release their feelings , they are deeply hidden, difficult to reveal.’

The bond of the father and son, the contorted face of the martyr in the painting and the tranquility of the fragment of sky, all add up to a search for that place where a man can find peace and forge a new identity without losing his maleness in the process...

‘It’s melancholy in the classic sense of the Renaissance,’ Clark said.”Melancholy that applies to artists, where it usually means to be solitary, but also to be depressed and to be on the edge of sanity.’

The cutout fragments come from 18th-, 17th- and 16th-century paintings, and were chosen deliberately by Clark as tools for the construction of an allegorical landscape. But also for their beauty...

Closer inspection reveals tiny coloured dots on the fragments of paintings...

‘That just means formalism..I put it in there so that people would ask , what are the dots for?’”

(Dorota Kozinska, “Charting what is to be a man proves a melancholic business,” Gazette January 18, 1997, P.I1)

997.06 a-b.title: The Melancholy of Maleness, Diptych E
997.06 a-b.subject: scène de genre; paysage
997.06 a-b.medium: gelatin silver print; Iris ink-jet computer graphic print
997.06 a-b.description: The diptych is composed of a black & white photograph on the left, and reproductions of 16th to 18th century paintings, on the right, that are cut into two medallions. The photograph shows a museum interior with two men engaged in conversation; two little boys stand next to them. The right element of two medallions has, at the left, a partial view of a man’s (priest?) head in red skullcap and garments, and at the right, a detail taken from Landscape with the Gathering of the Ashes of Phocion by his Widow (1648) by Nicolas Poussin, showing a solitary figure framed by trees and shrubbery in front of a building.

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Sculptor Joe Fafard obtained his BFA from the University of manitoba in Winnipeg in 1966, and his MFA from Pennsylvania State University in 1968. While in graduate school, he began to experiment with kinetic sculptures, playing with the comic potential of forcing things that are usually static to move. Frustrated with the amount of maintenance required to keep these sculptures operational, he moved into static work, but still thinks of his creations as just on the brink of moving, playing with the tension between movement and stasis. At the same time, he explores the tradition of distortion in sculpture, flattening his people and animals, tricking the viewer by creating objects which appear to be shaped according to our preconceptions from one angle, and from other angles are discovered to be completely distorted. In a series on the art critic Clement Greenberg, this flatness doubled as a visual pun about Greenberg’s belief that the flatness of painting was its most important quality because it was specific to that art form. Fafard’s other series of famous artists, lesser-known artists, and his well-known cows, all play with these notions of space/depth perception and the role of sculpture in the history of art. The terrorized depicts a pint-sized, hooded and leather-jacketed terrorist, a disturbing image of a man with an animal-like head holding rocks in his hands, that Fafard nonetheless infuses with his reknowned quirky humour, reducing the image of terror to a small figure easily overpowered by any viewer.

997.46.title: Un jardin pour Tristan
997.46.subject: abstract - series of horizontal stripes, in wash over green background; overlaid with vertical stripes in impasto
997.46.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1997
997.46.references:
Michèle Drouin
Un Jardin Pour Tristan (1991)
“From canvas to canvas, a quadrature releases peripheral streaks of colour and traces a latent structure that would prevail in 1991. Echoing the borders of the frame, these enlarged bands invite comparison with a window. Conferring a new wight to the work, these margins partake in the painting. Their heaviness reverberates in the choices of colours: midnight blue, deep browns. Is this the proximity of death lived through the estrangement and disappearance of loved ones?

The titles reflect a stasis....Fewer bands penetrate one another as a result of economy of execution. Heavy as beams , they support one another. Primal constructions , their presence dominates by the density of their medium and its progressive ascension to the foreground. Concentrating the coloured flares which weaken at the center of the painting, they enclose them inescapably...” (Claire Gravel, Michèle Drouin: Ouverture-Fermeture/Opening Enclosing Galerie Madeleine Lacerte, Quebec, 1996, p.6)

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Geneviève Cadieux earned her BA in Fine Arts from Ottawa University, and is known for photographic works of the human body enlarged to a cinematic scale. While many of her images depict the female form, skin marked upon through suffering and time, or in ambiguous postures that connote a pleasure/pain dichotomy, she also tackles broader issues of human passion and spirituality. Through images of eyes, mouths, and skin, she explores humanity as a sensory process, studying vision, light, and the credibility of touch. Untitled (dos) is an example of Cadieux’s ability to cause the viewer to reflect on his or her own corporeality by focusing on and enlarging one aspect of the body to a monumental, collective scale. The view of the back here is at once intimate and symbolic, a landscape of skin and shadow common to any human being and yet particular to the woman pictured here.
    
From Karen Antaki’s application for cultural property, 1998: “Using a multitude of strategies, including the photographic enlargements that for the basis of her large installations and a wealth of diverse materials such as mirrors, lead plating and light, Cadieux addresses timely issues of representation, fragmentation, distortion, displacement and memory as they relate to the experiential body in time.
This donation belongs to a body of work that pictures magnified imaes of people and focuses on a single part of their anatomy. They reference the cinematographic in their cropped, cut and seamed formating, and by extension suggest the filmic ‘close-up.’ Blown up images of friends, family and strangers, these pictures bear evidence of lived experience  and transmutation (scars, defects), revealing that which goes unnoticed. The pictured bodies expand, boh literally and figuratively, beyond the subject/frame. Cadieux’s works are simultaneously fragile and dangerous. They evoke a multitude of emotions from the viewer as they present a reading of the body in a progression that moves from the physical, to the visual, to the visualized. In an effort to extend the significance of each work, Cadieux incorporates the technology of the photographic medium into her creations, extending their symbolic and representational dimension through her manipulation of the imprint and its chemical composition.
Untitled (dos) is a portrait of the artist’s mother manifested in a postmodern sense. (...) Without question, it is a powerful and challenging photograph whose significance lies in its formal accomplishment and its unique and important relevance within the context of contemporary Canadian art practices.”

997.49.title: T.A.H. (Total Artificial Heart)
997.49.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1997
997.49.references:
MFA, Concordia University
Lorraine Simms

T.A.H. (1990)
“Simms says she paints mechanical prostheses to evoke ‘the vulnerability of the body and the veneration of the mind...The paintings... have been made from black-and-white photographs in medical literature (Nancy Tousley Calgary Herald, Friday November 27, 1992)...”Most of her paintings are of chunks of high-tech medical hardware, vaguely ominous-looking contraptions that can be inserted into our bodies... Simms explained “One year ago (1989) I began painting artificial hearts as metaphors for cold emotionless hearts. These images remind the viewer of the disconnection many people feel between their emotions and their intellectual reasoning.” “That split also relates to issues of gender stereotyping.” Simms examines the notion of “the body as machine.” “She has taken tiny pieces of medical equipment and blown them up.”(Ann Duncan, “Medical Metaphor yields art with heart” Gazette Sat. Feb 9, 1991) 
David Liss explains that Simms focusses “on the relationship and implications (this)” medical “technology has for the human body and nature.” (David Liss, Gazette  Saturday Nov. 5, 1995)

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

While Gabor Szilasi studied medicine at the University of Budapest from 1946-9, he never completed his studies, and following an unsuccessful attempt to flee Hungary in 1949 he spent five months in prison. In 1952 he bought his first camera, and was on hand in 1956 to document the Hungarian uprising in Budapest. That year another attempt to flee the country was successful, and he immigrated to Canada with his father. In 1958 he met amateur photographer François Lafortune in Quebec, and learned from him the rudiments of photographic processes. By 1959 he had moved to Montreal and was working as a photographer for the Office du Film du Québec. The bulk of his work captures urban scenes of both people and architecture, taken in Montreal and in Eastern European cities visited since his move to Canada. He has also produced a large body of work featuring the people of Quebec in the interior of their homes. Corner of Dluga and Pedzichow Sts, Cracow uses two photographs to show the meeting of two streets, the central focus being the corner of a building which projects out toward the viewer. Both roadways fade into a pale and misty background, and a dreamy quality is emphasized by the almost deserted aspect of the streets. Two distant women are visible on the right, and a man half-hidden on the left is given away only by his shadow.
