written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

 Sylvia Safdie came to Canada from Lebanon as a girl in 1953. In 1975 she received her BFA from Concordia University. Her work has centred on the use of natural objects such as stones, leaves, and earth, combined with industrial elements such as glass and aluminum, in an exploration of the intersections between physical and biological processes, the cycle of growth, transformation, and decay found both in nature and in human life. Often using objects found on her own travels, Safdie examines human origins, memory, displacement, and survival, though without ever being present herself in the work in any autobiographical form. Notations pg. 95 is part of a series in which Safdie paints with a mixture of oil and earth on vellum, in a sense sanctifying and transforming the resources of nature. Her images of bodies painted with the earth appear to float in space due to the transparency of the vellum, their ambiguous nature playing on issues of presence versus absence, and the notion of body as earth, created from earth and returned to it. This particular work shows only a single body, extending the exploration to include the notion of human solitude, as we are each physically bound to one body that cannot be shared completely with anyone else.

998.10.title: Rosa Rose
998.10.subject: abstraction
998.10.color: black, pink, red, green, yellow, white
998.10.description: The work is an abstraction done on nine square canvases fixed together into one large, square polyptych. The three component panels of the upper and middle rows carry angular, horizontally oriented, colored forms that are loosely grouped into three jagged bands. The three panels of the bottommost row show vertical drips of color: green, yellow, white, and red. Red and pink, set against a black ground, are the predominant colors of the work.
998.10.source: Gift of Normand Bernier / don de Normand Bernier, 1998
998.10.references:
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.249-250, 253
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.296, 297, 371-372

Rosa Rose (1974)
“While his late sixties work evinced continually evolving serial geometric patterns, 1970 was the year that Hurtubise began using small square canvases bolted together to form an actual grid. This system allowed the artist ( Jacques Hurtubise: Four Decades, Image After Image, Montreal Museum of Fine Arts Feb 26-May 24, 1998 Mayo Graham “ Hurtubise: Four Decades of Painting p.15 ) the freedom to rearrange or redo individual units until he arrived at a final satisfactory result.
Referring to the evolution of the blackout paintings (large patterns of black fluorescent shapes such as Monique Hurtubise said that he 
	did hundreds of paintings like that, and one day I thought it was enough. I didn’t want to repeat that again. We had a summer place; I was there for three days. I sat down and said, ‘What the hell am I going to do now?’ It came to that- I just hid everything, so then it got to the “blackouts”, with the black in front. It you look at these paintings carefully, you see what’s behind...”  Jacques Hurtubise: Four Decades, Image After Image, Montreal Museum of Fine Arts Feb 26-May 24, 1998 Mayo Graham “ Hurtubise: Four Decades of Painting” p.16 )

... “Against flat backgrounds , Hurtubise used the dynamic qualities of neon to create linear patterns of bright light . These experiments led him to adopt fluorescent colours in his painting, which he applied on black backgrounds on canvases tilted to emphasize diagonal movement of bright colours. By the early 1970s, black backgrounds in his paintings had become predominant- creating what he called “blackouts,” where foreground and background were reversed...A more pronounced example of his interest in formal arrangement s is exhibited in his module paintings of the early and mid 1970s, where canvases were divided into smaller squares, each approached individually but collectively forming a collage that shows through from spatial depths. Each square, in fact, could be considered an individual painting, though the overall   composition retains a sense of harmony through layers of colour and an emphasis on diagonal movement...” (Contemporary Canadian Artists, 1997, p.272)

... “ I build then from many small, rectangular canvases, I throw on some paint, I shift around the modules- if one doesn’t fit I just get rid of it or borrow from another painting.” “For Hurtubise the grids of canvases have become a practical measure. ‘Before I had to decide right away - yes or no’. Now he explores his intended accidents’ “I know every dot by heart...”(Henry Lehmann, “Technique: is it deadly?” Montreal Star October 26, 1974, p.D7)

... “They each consist of an overall grid obliquely traversed by jagged peninsulas of colour emanating from different locations in different paintings...In a superficial way the projections energetically crossing these canvasses resemble the splatterings of paint that we associate with Abstract Expressionism. Hurtubise, however, with the help of paper templates, exercises complete control over his medium. Each colour is carefully applied, one after another as in serigraphy...” (Yolande Racine, “Jacques Hurtubise” Artscanada vol XXXI nos. 3&4 December 1974, p.123)

written by Martine Fournier:

Educated at the Montreal École des Beaux Arts from 1959-60, Jacques Hurtubise also went to New York City in 1960, where he was ispired by abstractionists such as Rothko, de Kooning, and Pollock. Sometimes linked with Les Plasticiens, Hurtubise experimented with many forms of abstract expression. During the 1960’s he created a new methos of painting, cutting out shapes, painting them, and then applying them to flat vertical planes of colour. The layering of thick colours that resulted caused him to introduce neon into the work in an attempt to bring light back into it. Working with neon against a dark ground led Hurtubise to the use of fluorescent paint, which he applied to a black ground. By the 1970’s this black ground was dominant in the work, and he began to work with the process of combining smaller “modules” to create larger paintings, which allowed him to contimually rearrange the work, like pieces of a puzzle, until he was satisfied. 
    Rosa Rose demonstrates this technique, as it is made with a combination of black and fluorescent panels. While these are painted one colour at a time, allowing Hurtubise greater control, the emphasis on diagonals and the slanted dripping of the paint gives the work a sense of movement that travels throughout the panels.

998.11 a-c.references:
Exhibited in above exhibition
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.53, 76-79, 81
-See Dennis Reid, “A Concise History of Canadian Painting,” 1988, pp.369-371
Yves Gaucher
Rouge Noir Gris (1994)
“In these works, an incorporation of additional formal and formatting strategies dissuades the viewer from total absorption in the symmetrical parameters of the quadrate panels. Rather , the uneven bisection of the surface of one or more component panels by the inclusion of attenuated bands, brings to attention once again the rhythmic principles attached to symmetrical and asymmetrical dynamics within the context of a classical vocabulary. In Rouge, noir et gris, for examples, each of the two outer black panels is unevenly divided by a closely valued grey ‘stripe’ on either inner edge, subtly recomposing the structure ‘internally’, so to speak , and thus contributing to the inner pulsation of each canvas and the sustained energy of the work as a whole. In so doing, the artist augments the rhythmic process and expands the movement first initiated by the physical voids. It is important to underline that is as a result of such elaborate or minute formal modulations that the artist renews certain problematics in order to perpetuate his quest for dynamic insight rather than as a means to initiate closure...” (Karen Antaki, Yves Gaucher p.7) 

written by Martine Fournier:

Edmond Dyonnet arrived in Montreal in 1875, and after studying at the School of Arts and Crafts, he went to Italy for four years to gain further instruction under professor Gastaldi. He worked chiefly as a portrait artist in an academic style, although he also painted landscapes of Île d’Orléans, and was instrumental in founding Montreal’s École des Beaux Arts. Ste-Anne de Beaupré is an example of his landscape work, showing rolling green land dotted with cows, a road leading into scattered houses and a glowing sunset sky. A vision of countryside serenity, it invites the viewer into its folds even while its population remains unrevealed.

written by Martine Fournier:

Earning her BFA from University of British Columbia in 1966, and her MFA from York University in Toronto in 1978, Judith Schwartz began her career using images of the body or suggesting it with organic forms, but soon moved on to highly simplified and reductive symbols. Her sculptures of wood and metal usually involve simple symbology familiar to viewers from almost any culture, such as x’s and o’s, ovals, and rings.  With these symbols she navigates the intersection of art, religion, and science, using forms common to all three, and often disrupts the viewer’s sense of space with confusing grids or relief sculpture that operates on both two dimensional and three-dimensional levels. 

-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, p.232
Judith Schwarz: Progression (1994 )
“Incorporating materials that can be characterized as either natural or industrial , her work is informed by an intuitive, abstract, yet rigorous logic which establishes a dialogue between form and material, past and present, memory and time,connotation and denotation, illusion and physicality...Her work has ranged from architectural structures placed outdoors in wooded landscapes to the highly finished, abstract wall works ...Despite these shifts in Schwarz’s activity , the concern that is central to her art, the question of how we come to know what the world is like has remained constant....The principal point of departure for Schwarz’s art , in terms of sculptural traditions, has been Minimalism. (Grant Arnold, Judith Schwarz Art Gallery of Windsor, 1990, p.5)...In keeping with Minimalist principles, Schwarz’s sculptures have a physical presence that relates to the viewer’s body and acknowledges that the viewer’s response unfolds through lived time and space. (Grant Arnold p.6)

...“her sculptural objects are amazing for their duplicity...the deceit is here embedded in the phenomenology of seeing. As perceivers , we are duped, for what seem concrete objects are in fact eminently fluctuating and dissembling structures.
Made from steel, slate, wood or other materials, and varying in geometric shape and scale, from the human to the outsized architectural, her works creatively dissemble, assuming multiple guided to draw the viewer into a perceptual drama. Assumptions about the object and its space are undermined as the ambiguity of the work emerges.... (James D. Campbell, Dissembling Structures: A Survey of Judith Schwarz Sculpture 1989-1998p.6 )...Structurally complex, often formally austere and always consummately ambiguous, they implicate our optic propensities, bodies, kinaesthesia and imagination...Because the object seems to be in a state a preternatural flux, doubt undermines the assumption that we can extrapolate unknown angles from experienced perspectives. Schwarz’s works create a rupture between appearance and reality...the work is formulated and vetted on the sculptor’s sketch pad: the computer screen...Dissembling Structures p.7)...her works are fabricated hybrids executed with remarkable precision- nothing is left to chance...Schwarz coerces us...to resolve ambiguities and achieve a coherent perception of her work. Of course, she knows what the observer slowly comes to recognize; no such resolution is possible. But the process of ongoing resolution is integral to any viewing of her work, teaching as much about her sculptural syntax as about the encoded schemas that structure perception...these objects are phenomenally restless...The manner in which Schwarz manipulates the spatial continuum of her sculptures is itself interesting. Her objects often seem cut out of another space, superimposed upon a backdrop that disappears as the works hold the eye, activating the space around them.  Dissembling Structures p.8)...all lines of projection from the sculpture seem parallel to each other and perpendicular to the two-dimensional plane represented by the surface of the sculpture. Elevation (frontality) and depth (recession) oscillate , as the viewer moves back and forth, in front and to the sides of one of her sculptures, adopting different station points in space and varying from elevation to plan view incessantly...the true genealogy of this work reaches back before Minimalism to the Cubists...The spatial disorientation involves not only optic, but the body and imagination...The specific geometric shape shifts from focus to background, generating a space more fictional than real...The condensation of the sculptural object seems to turn space   against itself , making the viewer self-conscious about both perspective and the integrity of one’s station-point...A self-interrogation of the optic and the imagination is brought on by work that os best understood as an existential catalyst. (   Dissembling Structures p.10)...her objects have always successfully blurred the distinction between the microperceptual structures of the work and the larger macroperceptual context in which it is situated...Her sculptures are important for both their spatial play and their ability to undermine commonplace assumptions about the position of  objects in space;space understood as both concrete and somatic, and purely psychological...  Dissembling Structures p.11) ...The central concerns of Schwarz’s sculptural practice- somatic attraction, living flux and, perhaps most important, the auratic signature-make the objects neither site specific nor discrete...Understood as a spatial cut-out, the workplays upon the tension between the security of an inner (Dissembling Structures p.14) space and the instability of an outer space, and between the stability of the frame (which here is precisely the destabilizing element) and the alien presence (aura) yet material familiarity (wood, steel) of the artifact (Dissembling Structures p.15) ...The sculptures can also be seen as icons of eidetic flux, for her work implicates not just the optic, but the memory that transmits its images into mnemonic icons...the curious ellipse that seems to have arrived ..from some other space- all serve to undermine assumptions about space and time...The role of fluctuation in her work is crucial...Fluctuant representation ensures that the artwork never resolves into stasis...Like the fluctuant representation of synthetic cubism, Schwarz’s art seeks to exacerbate fragmentation, dislocation and omission- in spite of the deceptively simple geometric shapes she uses...**In works which incorporate two shapes, the tension between the shapes, and the observer’s search for parity in terms of measurement and extension, protract the act of looking...  (Dissembling Structures p.17) ...For the perspectival distortions born of flux mean that the stage on which the object is enacted (Dissembling Structures p.18) is not only a fiction being written outside the viewer- in some nameless nether space- but within one’s own intimate sphere of life’ one’s imagination. And this space, like the work, is rife with dialogical meanings...Her roots in Minimalism mean that she mindfully conserves a fidelity to the materials, while developing and economical iconography...Perhaps using the inordinately precise calculations afforded by the computer enabled Schwarz to reconcile illusionism and flux with the concrete existence of the object..**The vivid presence of Schwarz’s sculptural objects is tied to our innate desire to release them from flux, to codify them and render them inert. We strive after constancy, and are greeted with a tension that invigorates our perception even as it denies us perceptual comfort.” 

 (Dissembling Structures p.19)

999.02 a-c.title: Caduta
999.02 a-c.subject: portrait; abstraction
999.02 a-c.description: The left panel has a red rectangular frame mounted vertically on the linen, the central panel depicts a self-portrait of Dorion looking down and leaning forward, the right panel has a drapery rod mounted at the top from which a red curtain hangs.
999.02 a-c.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l'artiste
999.02 a-c.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1999
999.02 a-c.references:
Pierre Dorion is among the most important representatives of contemporary painting in Canada. Over the past fifteen years, he has created an autonomous and complex body of work that has achieved an almost classic maturity in the "Autoportrait" and "Roman Image" paintings of recent years. With great intellectual sharpness, Pierre Dorion reflects the ambiguity of modern existence in the schism between emotional inclinations, openness and empathy, and the simultaneous scepticism and critical distance with regard to what one sees." (Loretta Yarlow, introduction to catalogue "Pierre Dorion") For an extensive, general discussion of Pierre Dorion's Autoportraits see”Rupture of Meaning” by José Lebrero Stals (p 9 - 13) as well as "A Backwards Glance" by Catherine Crowston (p 15 - 21, Pierre Dorion catalogue).
See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See Jessica Bradley and Lesley Johnstone, eds., “Sightlines,” 1994, p.302
Pierre Dorion
Caduta (1994)
“The photographic language is appropriate enough, since these self-portraits do not rely on the traditional method of recording the artist’s reflection in a mirror but rather copy photos he had others take of him. Thus the camera allows him to paint self-portraits where, instead of looking out at the viewer, he looks away or down, asking us to watch him but declining to meet our gaze... The sculptural attachments on the canvas include the paraphernalia of the picture gallery or the church-examples of gilt frames and in one instance, a red velvet curtain of the kind used to protect art from light” ( Kate Taylor, “Dorion conjures fresh magic” Globe and Mail, January 14, 1995, p.C4)

“They embody a fascinating and complex series of ambiguities , in which painting is used to deconstruct its own traditions and question its validity in the age of photography and technology...” (David Liss, “Paintings make statement about what painting is.” The Gazette Saturday April 1, 1995, p.H6)

“Travailler l’autoportrait est un prétexte pour faire de la peinture , refléchir sur elle ...La figure indique la présence de la peinture sans l’incarner pour autant.C’est de garder ce pont avec cette dernière , avec son passé , sans faire de citations directes, amis plutôt en établissant un système de réfèrences personelles... Limitée à un motif , une figure, une couleur, un costume, la peinture viendra déplacer plutôt son discours sur un élément que l’artiste ajoute dans son tableau. Ce sera soit un oculus, ou bien des clés, une poignée , une chute de velours grenat...qui mettent en valeur une réflexion ...”(Marie-Michèle Cron , “Une peinture a haut indice de mélancolie” Le Devoir Samedi et Dimanche 5& 6 novembre, 1994  p.D11)

... “La trentaine d’autoportraits réalisés entre 1990 et 1994 montre sans relâche des entrelacements entre ce qui est peint, ce qui aurait pu l’être, ce qui est visible, ce qui déborder, bref l’autoreprésentation sert à illustrer l’artist méditant sur les limites non seulment de la peinture, mais de l’art en général...” (Colette Tougas, “Le Spéculaire chez Pierre Dorion”   Parachute 91 (July/Aug/Sept 1998 p.6)
... “And in Dorion’s work a painting is no longer a mirror. The artist appears in views that could only have been recorded by someone else...What becomes visible is not his soul pouring out of his face like light but simply his appearance , seen from a point of view that he could never have...No special knowledge of self is revealed and that earlier, apparently secure self-revealing is replaced by an attenuated longing for it, a nostalgia for what was possible...
The paintings have turned away from all the possibilities that were once self-portraiture. (Andy Patton , “A compromised light” C Magazine issue no. 44, Winter 1995, p.43)
“Every image of Dorion is, in one way or another turned away from us...None of the figures explicitly addresses the viewer; none make eye contact...Perhaps what’s important is just this lack of address: if the painter (not the painting) is communicating with anyone, it is with himself or with what is invisible... For if the figure of the artist addresses himself to anyone or anything , it is to that which is invisible and can never make an appearance in the painting...( Andy Patton , “A compromised light” C Magazine issue no. 44, Winter 1995, p.44)... “It could also be that Dorion’s colours are dulled, not to make a work that excites the eye less, but for much the same reason that his figures are turned at least partially away from us- in order to create a sensation if inwardness and separation from the world...” (Andy Patton , “A compromised light” C Magazine issue no. 44, Winter 1995, p.46).

... “Dorion does not disrupt nor perturb the stability of the painting’s design; he avoids excessively personalizing the figure, keeping it static and aloof from the plane of the observer, and preventing it from transmitting a sense of movement within the picture, or from inviting a confrontation with the exterior...” (Jose Lebrero Stals, Pierre Dorion Art Gallery of York University, 1995 p.
9)
...” In Pierre Dorion’s Autoportraits initiated in 1990 and completed in 1994, each of the paintings depicts the figure of the artist posed within the illusionistic space of the canvas...the self-portrait becomes more about a process of figurative representation, than about the subjectivity of the figure represented...” (Catherine Crowston , Pierre Dorion , Art Gallery of York University, 1995 p.15)

“Deep enough only to accommodate the figure of the artist. the space of the Autoportraits is shallow, emphasizing both the physical and theoretical constructedness of the painted surface...Whereas all of the works incorporate the space of the viewer into their indexical frame, the addition of objects onto the surfaces of canvases establishes a different occupation of space and a perceptual experience beyond the parameters of painting. The objects rupture the illusion of spatial depth and force attention instead to the surface of the work, and into the realm of the spectator.” (Catherine Crowston,Pierre Dorion , Art Gallery of York University, 1995, p.17) 
    “...Equally within the Autoportraits  series, Dorion inverts the traditional subject representation within the history of portraiture. The figure does not articulate an image of political or social authority nor does it reveal the psychology of the portrait ...(Catherine Crowston,,Pierre Dorion , Art Gallery of York University, 1995, p.19)
...”Through the collapse of pictorial modes, of illusionism and abstraction, of the genres of portraiture and landscape and their conventions, Dorion invokes these icons of style and genre only to upset their critical readings and to question their relevance within the plurality of scopic regimes possible today. The layering of different orders of reality- photographic, painterly, “real”-troubles the languages of representation and the spaces in which they operate. The works interrogate the limits of representation and suggest the impossibility of establishing determinant meaning, acknowledging instead, that meaning is a complex construction of images, ideological systems and subject positions...” (Catherine Crowston,,Pierre Dorion , Art Gallery of York University, 1995, p.20)... “In Dorion’s work this becomes revealed as a mourning for a loss of meaning, a loss that issues from the limits of representational structures and their discursive inability to approximate the ‘real’. ..The shift from painting to photography does not reveal any truth about the forms themselves, but instead, constitutes a reflexive turn back onto the very nature of their own ability to signify...”(Catherine Crowston,,Pierre Dorion , Art Gallery of York University, 1995, p.20).

999.03.title: The Weight of Memory X
999.03.subject: A person is laying horizontally with stones drawn in the foreground. Actual stones are attached to the shelf.
999.03.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
999.03.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat- Fonds de dontation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1998
999.03.references:
The artwork is number ten of a series of ten.
-See review(s) in Artist’s File
-See David Burnett and Marilyn Schiff, “Contemporary Canadian Art,” 1983, pp.196-197, 229
-See Jessica Bradley and Lesley Johnstone, eds., “Sightlines,” 1994, pp.14, 126-127, 172, 230, 237-240, 244
 The Weight of Memory  “ She is known as an artist of mourning-or rather as an artist who has looked down fathoms of grief. According to Anne Michaels Goodwin’s work expresses “the raw struggle of love trying to break free of loss.”  (Anne Michaels, Introduction of The Art and Life of Betty Goodwin edited by Matthew Teitelbaum and Jessica Bradley P.1) “Betty Goodwin’s work transforms the viewer into a witness. Her work is not a catalogue of distress. It is a record of hope in its most distilled form, potent and fiercely earned. Even the figures that are clearly corpses (though disturbingly too recent to have been buried)-in her series The Weight of Memory- are accompanied by handfuls of stones for remembrance, a traditional token left at a gravesite. The dead are remembered. Someone has remembered them. (Anne Michaels P.4) “The tragedies that obsess Goodwin are current and universal, culled form all those clippings she hoards- starvation, shootings, dictators, holocausts.”

999.04 a-b.title: Cain and Abel
999.04 a-b.subject:
two plates of sand-blasted glass
a) violin inside figure with a pair of hands/arms hovering at the sides of the figure’s head.
b) binoculars inside figure with a gun at the figure’s feet and same hands/arms hovering at the sides of the figure’s head.
999.04 a-b.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
999.04 a-b.source: Purchase- Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat- Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1999
999.04 a-b.references:
written by Martine Fournier:

François Morelli received his DEC in Plastic Arts from Dawson College on 1972, and in 1975 graduated from the BFA programme at Concordia University. Using a variety of media including sculpture, installation, drawing, and performance, Morelli has long been concerned with the everyday object as symbol of both the intimate and the universal, the sacred and the mundane. He also plays with corporeality by both depicting it and suggesting it through objects familiar to the body. In one series, he crafted wings out of wire and attached them to various household objects such as chairs, kitchen knives, pillows, and children’s shoes, at once caging them and giving them flight, his use of both wings and pillows referring to a dream world, a metaphysical realm beyond the physical world we inhabit. In Cain and Abel the references to corporeality are far more explicit, as the two ghostly sand-blasted images of child-like figures hang suspended within their egg-shaped glass realms as though still in the womb. This work refers to the Biblical story of Cain and Abel, the two brothers who vied for their father's attention until Cain killed his brother out of jealousy and was marked on the forehead by God so that for the rest of the life all the world would know of his sin.

999.09.title: Sleeping Bag
999.09.subject: image of a sleeping bag, pocket top right corner with actual thread and image of a zipper along bottom
999.09.credit: Gift of/don de Toronto Dominion Bank
999.09.source: Gift of the Toronto Dominion Bank / don de la Banque Toronto-Dominion, 1999
999.09.references:
written by Martine Fournier for the “Concordia Collects” exhibition: 

One of Quebec’s leading Pop artists, Pierre Ayot graduated from Montreal’s école des Beaux arts in 1963. He made many contributions to the Montreal art scene throughout his career, both as a teacher at the École des Beaux-arts (1964-1972) and the Université de Québec à Montréal (1972-1995), and as one of the founders of the studio Atelier libre 848 in 1966 (Later Galerie Graff).
    Having studied lithography with Albert Dumouchel, Ayot began his career in printmaking, eventually creating silkscreen “assemblages” which combined real objects with two-dimensional imagery. While Ayot’s playful sensibility, use of illogical combinations, and preoccupation with the everyday object have led to his being classified as a Pop artist, he brought a distinctly Quebec flavour to the genre. During a time when this province was torn between the traditions of the Catholic Church and the 1960’s liberal movement, Ayot expressed this tension by juxtaposing the religious and the secular, the sacred and the profane, in his work. Incorporating real objects into his print assemblages, he played with trompe-l’oeil effects, engaging the viewer in a visual game that was both amusing, and deeply serious in its questioning of perception, the power of image, and the changing role of artists who have traditionally represented “reality” to the rest of the world.    
	Sleeping Bag is a pivotal work, as it is one of his earliest trompe-l’oeil attempts. In this image of a mounted sleeping bag, the zipper and the patch of cloth in the upper right-hand corner appear three-dimensional because of the artist’s skillful attachment of real thread to the surface of the work. While engaging in traditional printmaking practice, Ayot challenges the traditional picture plane by adding these three-dimensional elements and playing with viewer’s perception of what is “real” and what is “image.”

Written by Gilles Daigneault in Ayot Museum Circus: “Voici ce qu’on pourrait considérer comme le premier trompe-l’oeil de Pierre Ayot et qui, quelque vingt-canq ans plus tard, n’a rien perdu de son efficacité diabolique. En effet, le spectateur familier des sérigraphies truquées de l’artiste croit d’emblée que tout se passe cette fois du coté de la fermeture éclair; puis, trompé, il s’en veut de ne pas avoir repéré la pièce verte etinée à réparer une hypothétique déchirure en haute à droite. Peine perdue encore: l’élément réel n’est que le fil - à peine visible, à peine en relief - qui donne l’illusion de retenir la fausse fermeture éclair et la fausse pièce.
Tout se passe comme si Ayot, ironiquement, voulait respecter par cet ajout minimal la fameuse planéité de la peinture moderniste: notons, en effet, que Sleeping Bag offre à peu près toutes les apparences d’une oeuvre de la Post-Painterly Abstraction américaine. Ainsi, vis-à-vis les prétentions de la ‘bonne peinture’ greenbergienne, le jeune graveur québécois ne ferait que transposer le regard critique que Rauschenberg, Johns ou Lichtenstein portaient sur celles de l’Action Painting. Par ailleurs, l’image ne respecte pas toute la tradition précoce de l’estampe québécoise, ce qui ne l’empeche pas - comme cela des années soixante - de remporter un prix dans une exposition de gravure internationale.” (p.21)

999.100.subject: two photos juxtaposing an aboriginal tribe with a group of hunters. Text, symbols, and drawings of deer surround the two photos.
999.100.color: red, black, yellow, green, blue, brown
999.100.credit: Purchase/achat - The Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment/Fonds de dotation Leonard et Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art
999.100.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1999
999.100.references:
JANE ASH POITRAS
“Jane Ash Poitras’ use of text began as a form of resistance to a time when her words were reduced to letters on someone else’s blackboard. Reclaiming her native tongue provided a foundation for one part of this artist’s identity. We can also speak of painting’s stylistic languages and, in the work of Poitras, the language of abstraction is operative. But in Poitras’ hands, with design elements derived from pottery shards collected in southwestern United States, the act of pattern repetition takes on the quality of prayer...The prayers, the words, the elements of the design are repeated to gain strength. They establish a bunker for the speaking subject to emerge.” (Judith Mastai, Women and Paint Saskatoon: Mendel Art Gallery,1995, p. p.18) 

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Jane Ash Poitras earned a Bsc in Microbiology from the University of Alberta with the intention of becoming a medical doctor, but changed direction and earned a BFA as well, following that with her MFA in printmaking from Columbia University in New York City. Her multimedia works combine photography with painting, drawing, and printmaking techniques, and involve explorations into the history of her Native people that are both personal and highly political. Deer 2000 combines photography and printmaking with painting and the use of text, exploring the role of the deer in North American culture. On a background of colourful geometric design two photographic images are contrasted. On the bottom is an image of an old American deer camp, white male hunters lined up beside a rack of hanging deer, with a didactic printed caption about how much deer hunting technology has changed over time. This is juxtaposed with the image above it, of a Native tribe in traditional dress, and a hand-written explanation of how sacred the deer is to Native culture. Other drawings of deer and bits of writing fill the image, with messages about deer, the disappearance of the buffalo, and about language itself. In this way Poitras comments not only on political issues between First Nations and European descendents in America, but also on a larger history, and the role language plays in the way we interpret that history.

999.101.title: Untitled (Body Drawing)
999.101.subject: figure crouched on a flat surface
999.101.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l'artiste
999.101.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1999
999.101.references:
From Karen Antaki’s 1999 application for cultural property: “Cathy Daley is a Toronto-based artist whose oeuvre may be located within a contemporary discourse that addresses issues surrounding corporeality and embodiment, as well as related concerns attached to the relationship between the body and states of being in a phenomenological sense. In recent years, body-related art which commonly focused on issues related to the body politic has been superseded with contemporary art currents by notions of embodiment that encompass the fullness of being and which now centre on the notion of the experiential (or emblematic) body. Cathy Daley’s practice in the early and mid-nineties reflected a salient interest in examining the body as a vessel of human experience. The body drawings produced as a series between 1992 and 1994 illustrate this concern in a uniquely evocative manner. Life-sized in scale and soberly rendered, these drawings of recumbant bodies not only maximize the physicality and format of the artist’s chosen medium, but also eloquently suggest a hidden dimension of lived experience: the dynamic force that exists between the huma body and the human spirit, the energy that hovers between conscious and unconscious awareness. They hold a unique place within the artist’s production, preceding a large body of work for which she has become known and which focuses on female dress and iconographic emblem of culturally encoded female identity. In the latter series which focused on depictions of dress and costume, Daley makes invisible the body proper, (in marked contrast to the ‘Body Drawings’ series which made visible the inner dimension of being), and thus raises contemporary social issues surrounding gendered identity and the female body as object of desire and spectacle. Together the two series give expression and eaning to the significances (social and personal) of female identity and experience.
Untitled (Bpdy Drawing) is an excellent example of the production of an important contemporary Canadian artist whose practice holds unique significance within current discourses surrounding artmaking and its analysis in this country.”

From Between Body and Soul catalogue, by Karen Antaki, p.8:  “Cathy Daley’s untitled drawings of recumbent bodies also impart an almost palpable energy that contradicts their seeming inertia. Their physicality and their life size elicit the viewer’s haptic response, wherein he or she responds intuitively to the bodies’ experiential states. The gallery space is infused by the silent stirring of the sleeping figures and the sway of the papers’ surfaces. It is as though living beings have been vertically suspended along the gallery’s walls. Declaring their physicality through the rich substance of material and form (the transparency of the paper support accentuating the dark tactility of the images), the drawings nonetheless appear otherworldly, seeming to hover within the confines of the paper support. The fragile surface of the paper reinforces their evanescent nature, and they recall Fuglem’s nostalgic beings. They ar extroverted, publicly displayed, yet at the same time introversive and self-absorbed, occupying the space of dream and imagination.

999.35.references:
written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Educated at the Montreal École des Beaux Arts from 1959-60, Jacques Hurtubise also went to New York City in 1960, where he was ispired by abstractionists such as Rothko, de Kooning, and Pollock. Sometimes linked with Les Plasticiens, a Montreal non-objective abstractionist group, Hurtubise experimented with many forms of abstract expression. During the 1960’s he created a new method of painting, cutting out shapes, painting them, and then applying them to flat vertical planes of colour. The layering of thick colours that resulted caused him to introduce neon into the work in an attempt to bring light back into it. Working with neon against a dark ground led Hurtubise to the use of fluorescent paint, which he applied to a black ground. By the 1970’s this black ground had become dominant, and he began to work with the process of combining smaller “modules” to create larger paintings, which allowed him to continually rearrange the work, like pieces of a puzzle, until he was satisfied. Barabiche is based on this technique, as it looks as though the artist constructed it using the modules before tranferring his image to print form. The use of vibrant pink and green recalls his experiments with fluorescence, and the highly ordered structure of the panels is contrasted with zig-zaging diagonals and dripping colour that create a sense of freer movement throughout the piece.

999.73.references:
written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Claude Tousignant studied under Gordon Webber and Jacques de Tonnancour at the École des Arts et Graphismes of the Musée des Beaux Arts in Montreal, graduating in 1952. That same year he traveled to Paris to study at the Académie Ranson. Upon his return to Canada he quickly became associated with the Non figurative Artists Association of Montreal, but although he was working with abstraction, he did not fit into either the Automatiste or the Plasticien groups. While questioning the traditional role of pictorial space, Tousignant’s real goal was a return to the supremacy of colour in art, and the only artist with whom he has ever aligned himself is Guido Molinari. During the 1950’s and 60’s Tousignant began this exploration using geometric forms and hard-edge abstraction. He eventually began to work specifically with circles, and even his canvases took on circular form the series of Transformateurs chromatiques, Gongs, and Accélérateurs chromatiques. These are the works for which he is most famous, Op Art circles composed of radiating rings of different colours that appear to spin, bleed together, and pulse outward from the centre while the viewer stares at them. With these works Tousignant sought to create immense fields of colour vibrations, in which the rhythm of colour itself could find a voice. Following this period, during the early seventies, he reduced the number of colours he used to two or three per work, as in Le jaune et le rouge, where simply the relationship between these two colours is explored.  By the end of the decade he was working in monochromatic sequences, and moving into an exploration of the architecture of colour with relief works.

999.81.01-999.81.20.references:
There are five sets of Urformen Der Kunst Blossfeldt/Whittome, 1989. Each contains 20 original drawings over a unique image from Karl Blossfeldt. This piece ties into the Musée du Québec exhibition “Ozeanische Kunst” (1990) which employed the technique of oil drawings on an existing printed page, although its iconography is more akin to the Musée d’art contemporain’s “Creativity; Fertility” (1985).
“Thirty-plus years of formal , metaphysical and even anthropological exploration are rooted in the expressive power of the gesture and trace a certain archeology of knowledge and mythology...Whittome was initially trained in drawing and printmaking in her native Vancouver, and then in Paris. Using found objects, handmade paper, string, encaustic, pigments, and so forth, she recreates a highly personal collection of enigmatic assemblages, placed under glass or display cases , hieratic, totemic sculptures arranged in friezes or on the floor, solemn, austere, minimal paintings, gestural graphic series, presentations mimicking collections of curiosities or drawings- altogether, an extraordinary creative inventory steadfastly dedicated to re-contextualizing the artifact and gesture...If Whittome’s aesthetic and critical project literally encompasses the notion of museum, it is not because it evaluates and reproduces the museum’s ways of listing , arranging, preserving and presenting , but also, and above all, because it is defined and takes shape within the very idea of collection and collecting activities. Whittome’s found, and sought-for, objects are handled classified and transformed so as to attain the characteristics of “work” and, ultimately, acquire its status. Equally important is the artist’s appropriation of the site, of the space or device relating to the object that has been discovered, chosen, shaped and subsequently offered to our gaze.” (Josee Belisle, Irene F. Whittome   du 3 mai au 19 octobre 1997, Musee d’art contemporain de Montreal, p.33)Urformen der kunst blossfeldt/Whittome (1989) 
“Intentionally limited , the two or three-tone palette- black/white and red - fits in with the economy of means and structural rigour of Whittome’s work...These three colours expressive and effective, also contain symbolic connotations of life and death, birth sexuality and femininity.” (Josee Belisle, Irene F. Whittome du 3 mai au 19 octobre 1997, Musee d’Art Contemporain de Montreal p.35)

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Irene Whittome attended the Vancouver School of Art from 1959-63, and from 1963-68 studied printmaking in Paris at Stanley William Hayter’s Atelier 17. Returning to Canada in 1968, she settled in Montreal and began teaching at Concordia University. Since then her work has evolved from printmaking, drawing, and painting, to include installation and the use of architecture, lighting, and sound.  Much of Whittome’s work involves the combination of seemingly random and unrelated objects, including eggs, twine, wire, and wood, in installations that reflect upon the role of the museum in collecting and exhibiting objects. On a larger scale this investigation includes the notion of selection in society, as some objects are valued and others discarded, and a socio-anthropological interest in dichotomies of male/female, sacred/profane, self/other. Urformen Der Kunst Blossfeldt/Whittome is a series in which the artist painted over photographic images made by Karl Blossfeldt. Blossfeldt (1865-1932) was a teacher of art and design in Berlin who believed that the best sources for design lay in nature, particularly in plants, which he photographed repeatedly, creating a huge collection. Whittome’s choice to present them anew, painted over with alkyd oil paint and India ink, recalls an older work, Ozeanische Kunst, in which she painted over images of tribal masks from Africa and the South Pacific, creating what she considered to be masks over masks, revealing a complicated layering of self. Whittome here has painted over Blossfeldt’s images in a gestural manner that both compliments and grates against the German teacher’s composed, organized images of nature. Often resembling blood, her red strokes of colour seem to introduce a decidedly human, and possibly violent, element into Blossfeldt’s world of calm floating plants, bringing flaura and fauna into conflict.

999.83.subject: seated nude

999.83.source: Gift of the artist / don de l'artiste, 1999
999.83.references:
written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

Muhlstock’s Portrait of a Woman reveals his ability to use human form as abstract element. Here he has situated his model against a minimal background, emphasizing the strong diagonal of her figure as it leans to one side, rounding her form with shading and yet flattening her into a series of shapes through strong outline. It is also possible that Muhlstock, with his interest is portraying those victimized by society or the poverty of the Depression, may have drawn this black female model, head bowed down, with particular attention to her situation.

999.85.references: written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition: While abstraction and colour field painting dominated the art scene as Joanne Tod studied at the Ontario College of Art during the early 1970’s, Tod went her own way and continuously worked on figuration despite its lack of popularity. She thus became one of the key exponents of the New Figurative art movement of the 1980’s in Toronto. Tod’s work is characterzied by a jewel-like sense of colour and lush treatment of surface, yet her detailed and decorative interiors usually contain a “barb” to disrupt what would otherwise be unblemished pictorial unity, provoking the viewer into considering political issues of class, race, and gender. Using figures and portraiture, Tod has investigated social roles and signs, questioning the entire history of painting while adhering technically to the strictest academic traditions. Rembrandt in New York, by its very title, also refers to the history of art, and juxtaposes the commercial face of a paper jack-o-lantern hung on someone’s apartment door with the fine art hung just beside it on the wall of the hallway. As is typical of Tod’s work, this irony is couched within a lush treatment of textures and glossiness of surface that lures and disarms the viewer.

999.87.references:
written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

While Cathy Daley has explored subjects as seemingly disparate as the nuclear accident at Chernobyl and women’s evening wear, a consistent theme underlying all her work is the fact of human corporeality. Whether exploring society’s myths and story-telling as in the series Life Stories, or the role of female body and media image as in her series of women’s dresses, body parts, or the suggestion of them, figure strongly in her work as part of an ongoing investigation into public versus private, intimate versus generic. Untitled of 1997 is part of a series of drawings done on transparent paper, creating the effect that Daley’s life-size body parts are hovering in space. This particular drawing, while suggesting skin and hair, refers to our corporeality without limiting itself to any particular part of the body. It also recalls her series on evening gowns in the shape of the dark swirl, which is gathered at the top into what could be the strangely tiny bodice of a swelling ball gown. 

From an exhibition pamphlet on Trames de mémoire/ Materialzing Memory: “Cathy Daly’s (sic) large drawings of voluminous dresses have a hint of unreality about them. They are impossible garments that could never be worn but which relate to glamorous ideals of feminine beauty.” (1998)

999.99.title: Flower Girl’s Dress
999.99.description: The installation piece is made up of a girl’s dress (shoulder-straps, bodice, and skirt), metal garment bag, shoes, and metal enclosure. Wires attached to the straps suspend the dress, with garment bag, above shoes placed on the floor. The work is hung within a three-sided assembly (top, left, and right) of five, square, silver metal grills that carry traces of honeycomb. The single-strap shoes are low-heeled and reddish in hue. The straps of the dress are decorated with leaf-like shapes, and the skirt is made with elliptical petal forms. The light-cyan colored bodice has floral embroidery and honeycombs.
999.99.credit: Gift of the artist/don de l'artiste
999.99.source: Purchase - Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Acquisition Endowment / achat - Fonds de dotation Leonard & Bina Ellen pour l'achat d'oeuvres d'art, 1999
999.99.references:

See Between Body and Soul catalogue
see Mark, Lisa Gabrielle. Aganetha Dyck: Working in the Dark. Toronto:         DeLeon White Gallery, 2000.
See Ordinary Magic: Aspects of Ritual in Contemporary Art catalogue.

Dyck places objects in beehives in order to allow comb to be built on them, referring to transformation and decay, to the labour and organization of the hive.

Part of The Extended Wedding Party  series, in which “bridesmaids. dresses, wedding gifts, shoes and accessories evoked a silent image of transmutation and decay.” (Karen Antaki, Between Body and Soul  catalogue)

The exhibition objects “present a silent, haunting image of decay and development. By emphasizing the absence of the human body Dyck speaks to what is missing. We are transfixed by the phantom limbs, by the transgressive interface between the body and apparel. (...) If these garments are uniforms of the ritual, they are also implements and actors in those rituals. They are not only meant to envelop a body, they are the bodies themselves. The garment bags are not barriers between individual and history, or nidividual and nature. They are bridges between them.” (Shirley Madill,  Winnipeg Art Gallery catalogue)

“Dyck’s wax and resin-coated Wedding Party  garments are like cult objects, or archeological finds, manifesting the highly-orgnized processes of the life of the hive as well as our own complex human rituals.” (Paula Gustafson, Espace article, p. 35)

In an interview with Sigrid Dahle in the Winnipeg Art Gallery catalogue, p. 22, Dyck talks about how when one is working with bees and beekeepers one’s awareness of body is heightened, because of the fear of being stung. This may have led her to connect the idea of the hive with body and clothing, as in the items in the Extended Wedding Party . 

written by Martine Fournier for 25th anniversary “Concordia Collects” exhibition:

From its very early stages, Aganetha Dyck’s artistic career has centred on the transformation of the familiar, domestic object, from her series of shrunken sweaters to her canned buttons. More recently Dyck has been using bees to transform everything from cigarettes to shoes. Placing objects in the hive, Dyck waits for the bees to coat them in combs of wax, creating symbols, sometimes grotesque, of labour, community, and decay. Flower Girl’s Dress is part of a series of these honeycombed objects called The Extended Wedding Party, in which Dyck uses the world of the hive and the Queen Bee to comment on the cult of the bride and female domesticity. All kinds of wedding paraphernalia, such as dresses, food, and shoes, have been subjected to the bees’ work and then presented individually inside bee excluder screens. In this particular piece the absence of the human body is highlighted by the empty dress, and the ritual aspects of the wedding brought forward in the archeological, cultish appearance of the coated clothing, which is also partially spray-painted with gold like an ancient idol.

Article publié dans le Concordia’s Thursday Report, 28 septembre 2000 :

The Flower Girl’s Dress is dripping with congealed beeswax, and it is enclosed by a framework of racks from an apiary, or beehive.

 The artist, Aganetha Dyck, comes from a rural Mennonite community in Manitoba. To quote from the gallery’s catalogue, “Dyck has used bees to transform everything from cigarettes to shoes. Placing objects in the hive, she waits for the bees to coat them in combs of wax, creating symbols, sometimes grotesque, of labour, community and decay.

“The Flower Girl’s Dress is part of a series of these honeycombed objects called The Extended Wedding Party, in which Dyck uses the world of the hive and the queen bee to comment on the cult of the bride and female domesticity.

 “In this particular piece, the absence of the human body is highlighted by the empty dress, and the ritual aspects of the wedding brought forward in the archeological, cultish appearance of the coated clothing, which is also partially spray-painted with gold like an ancient idol.”

 Dyck’s strikingly original work has made her one of Canada’s most admired artists, and it has often been shown in Concordia’s Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery.
